We never even saw the other year on the menu, but he brought it back and sure enough it was at the very bottom; given how quickly it was taken care of, I sort of wonder if they pull this to fleece inattentive tourists out of a few extra bucks.
author: Joshua B.

description:
Came here for lunch and was pleasantly surprised.  I love it's location in the FiDi - we went on a sunny day and sat outdoors (I didn't even go inside so no idea what it's like in there).  Good mix of working professionals and lucky people who did not have to work that day.  Very European style outdoor seating with flower pots and large umbrellas.  Pleasant waiters and hosts to serve us.  Bread is served with olive paste at the start.  The bread was nothing special....save your appetite for the appetizers and entrees!

First, we ordered the caesar salad (freshly baked croutons and tasty dressing) and bruschetta to start.  The bruschetta has anchovies which I was not fond of, so I picked them off.  Otherwise, it was very tasty.  

For entrees, we ordered the salmon, black ink linguini with ahi, and mushroom risotto.  The salmon was well seasoned and over grilled asparagus.  It was a basic dish, but well prepared.  The black ink linguini was very creative and something I had never had before.  The ahi is supposed to be seared, but I have never been a fan of seared fish, so I requested that it be well done.  They had no problem customizing the dish for me.  There is not a lot of flavor in the pasta itself other than a lot of olive oil with some tomato....a little plain but still delicious.  As for the mushroom risotto, I was really impressed with the mushroom flavoring - a lot of places make the mushroom flavor too strong and I get tired of it after a few bites.  However, this was really delicious and I almost wished I had ordered it instead of the linguini.  

As for the portions, the dishes look small but they are very filling.  I found myself slowing down towards the end, but we were all able to finish the entrees.  The dishes were all fulfilling but light....none of us suffered from food coma and were able to be productive at work after :)
author: Naomi P.

description: Food was okay and the service standard. Not going to hurry back.  Ambience was great though and the people watching amusing.  Very busy alley.
author: Sienna L.

description:
It was late on a tuesday night and i was looking for a place to eat near my hotel. A lot of places were closing. I stumbled across this ally with a bunch of restaurants in it. I checked all the menues of the restaurants in the alley and settled on Tiramisu. I was a little scared because it felt a little like a touristy restaurant with over priced bad food. I went in anyway because the menu items sounded the best. 

I ordered 2 appetizers instead of an entree because I wanted to try more than one dish. I ordered the grilled sardines and the squid ink risotto with scallops. WOW! Both dishes were sooooo good. I tried to write the sardine recipe down so I could attempt to replicate when I get home. I don't cook a lot with squid ink so that one is probably out. 

Are the prices a little high? Not really for the area I would guess. I thought the dishes I ordered were worth what I paid. The service started out a little gruff but warmed up as the meal progressed. It wasn't a deal breaker though. I would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Food D.

description:
I was so annoyed with my meal here. The lasting impression I got from this place is all style and no substance. 

We, like so many other people, were sucked into eating here by the pretty lights and European-ish feel to the street it's located on. But of course, because the restaurant can reel in people due to its location, it can under-deliver on taste, service and quality. 

I think people are maybe coloured by their "European" type of experience they have. Perhaps the feeling and ambiance makes people more forgiving of the food they are served? Or perhaps I just made a bad choice. 

I ordered the boar dish - it was a pasta dish so I was expecting something interesting. The first plate that arrived had likely been sitting for a while because it was luke warm. I asked the waiter to send it back, and the second plate that arrived was admittedly warmer but the portion sizes were not reflective of the price I paid. 

The food itself was pretty salty as well as not being hot enough - I'd expect a stronger flavour due to the boar, but it was a bit too much for me. Probably partly my fault for ordering that meat, but I stand by my moan and say it was too salty! My other half said his meal was very bland. Ho hum. 

I was hungry after I'd finished the food - it took me all of three minutes to scarf it. There just wasn't enough there to merit a dinner-sized portion of food, ESPECIALLY in the States!! I'm used to British portion sizes, which are usually about half the size of the US, and even here I was very unhappy. 

After we finished our mains we couldn't wait to leave the place and ended up in a convenience store around the corner buying more food to bolster our bellies. How depressing, because the meal was expensive. Never again. 

I'm so surprised this place scores so highly. Where did I go wrong?! Or is it maybe because I'm from Europe and the whole ambiance thing just doesn't do it for me so much? So annoyed my meal here was bad.
author: Claire C.

description: The mussel in pesto sauce is amazing, the baby short ribs are tender and succulent overall a good experience.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Five stars for service!!!!
Pretty hostess had us seated quickly.
Serbian busser who was also super sweetheart got us bread and water so quickly.
The food was very nice and the bread fresh and fragrant.
Probably the only sit down restaurant in the Financial District that understands that people are on a lunch break.
Thank you!
author: Yo M.

description: Gnocchi of potato is so good... tiramisu is not bad. It's on a small back street near Kearny and Pine. Outdoor seating is really cool and the food is good
author: Li F.

description: Monterey calamari a must have. Great atmosphere on a nice day. Varied, well executed menu. Relaxed, knowledgeable servers. Nice menu variety and its all good. What's not to like!
author: bruce t.

description:
Made 11 person reservation over the phone, headed over, seated immediately, food arrived timely, service was decent.  Ordered caprese salad, lobster risotto, bruschetta, and a bunch of other dishes to share.  My goodness the food was delicious. Service was ok.  Took them a long time to bring out check.

It was 2 weeks ago so I don't remember everything but I don't remember the place being a memorable experience either.  Thus just 4 stars. 

Update: I realized i made it sound like it was so amazing so I'm giving it 5 stars. But it's really 4.5 now that I remember that the service was not fast enough. (Which I updated above).
author: Hanna Y.

description:
I went to Cafe Tiramisu last Saturday to celebrate my bday with my closest girls! We sat outside and it was great to enjoy the mixture of that little French/Italian alley scene!!! Not only that but the food is also amazing, I ordered the Sea Food Mixed Grill and I can tell that the dish is fantastic - the spinach risotto by itself was the best I ever had!!!!!

Btw, great place to suggest a guy to take you out on a date lol
author: Vivian M.

description:
In a quick summary:

Atmosphere is okay, service is okay, flavor is spot on. Among the best Italian food in the city. Wines are awesome and reasonably priced. For apps, you can't go wrong with the bruschetta. Definitely a great option for sit-down dining in Fi-DI
author: Joaquin E.

description:
Some of the food is really salty, probably because the cheese is, then they season it. 

The food isnt very warm, as another Yelper said. 

The chocolate cake is excellent.

The pesto and bread are yummy. 

The lobster ravioli, ho hum. 

I really loved the vibe. We could have done worse.
author: C C.

description:
This cute Italian place with outdoor seating on Belden place, evokes memories of old school Italian restaurants from NYC little Italy... except the food is twice as expensive (well it is San Francisco) and about half as tasty. On the positive side, it is a lot less touristy. 

The wine list is extensive, but their selections for the per glass and half bottles are a little dated. The asparagus and crab Risotto with delicious, but the seared Ahi tuna was overcooked. A very common but novice mistake. The doughnuts filled with Italian custard dessert was pretty sweet, although the sauce was a nice dark chocolate. But personally I think, Bearded Papa is worth the calories a lot more than the ones at Cafe Tiramisu! 

Friends who were from out of town loved it. Great atmosphere, good food, friendly and attentive service. I will be back, but not when I'm the mood for great food.
author: Bushra S.

description: We were a party of 9 and everything we ordered was just delicious. The service was really good and the dessert sampler was amazing. Highly recommend a visit.
author: G G.

description:
The hostess was pleasant and very accommodating.

     The food is mediocre at best..A notch above Olive Garden.
Our waiter disappeared after he served me a glass of wine.The place was not busy yet at 6:30 on a Thursday. I waved to the owner who was chatting with another table's diners.
He ignored us so .I waved down the busboy and asked for the waiter.
The owner, Giuseppe(sp?),eventually came over and was rude and brusque while acting like he was doing us a favor by taking our order.The waiter never apologized for neglecting us.. We tipped accordingly..
     We live in the Bay Area and have eaten in a lot of San Francisco restaurants..
My opinion is that this restaurant is getting much more attention than it deserves..There are so many quality Italian restaurants in San Francisco.Don't waste your time or money here.
author: Barry E.

description: Nice for an outdoor lunch! Order the pumpkin gnocchi! And enjoy the fabulous dipping oil that comes with the bread.
author: Vicki L.

description:
This place reminds me a lot of a much scaled down version of restaurants on Mulberry street  in Manhattan. I'd driven up Kearny countless numbers of times and never knew that this Belden Place existed just a stones throw away. The area is teeming with diners and although not all Italian restaurants, it bustles with a similar NYC Little Italy energy.

There's a good amount of outside seating but since the night was a bit chilly we decided to eat inside. The restaurant is very narrow, closet like, and there's additional dining in a cozy downstairs area where we were seated. Murals and paintings adorn the walls which themselves already have quite of a bit of relief texture. Our waiter introduced himself and then left us to peruse the menus.

We chose to start with two glasses of the Dolcetto and with one of us being keen on dessert, we proceeded to straight to the entrees. It was destined to be a pasta night, so a plate of the ricotta gnocchi and the tagliatelle with wild boar meatballs were chosen. The gnocchi were little mini ones, cooked with a really nice texture (not gummy) and picked up the tomato sauce nicely. The wild boar meatballs and sauce were excellent and I don't think I'd enjoyed a pasta dish this much in a while.  I could probably eat that once a week and never get sick of it. After we polished off our entrees we tackled the dessert sampler which consisted of just about everything; tiramisu, creme brulee,  banana tart, canoli, chocolate cake, profiteroles, and a fruit sorbet. 

The seating of our reservation was prompt and our waiter was very keen. The food also came out surprisingly fast considering it was a Saturday night.  I think some people would be afraid the area is too touristy but I think it's worth giving a try because you can get a fine meal  and it's fairly inexpensive. 4.5 stars for this tucked away gem.
author: Kim N.

description: We ate at a nearby restaurant just feet away the night before and had a good experience, so we wanted to repeat the experience, but with different food. They didn't have any outside seating available, so we sat inside. It was very noisy and people were packed in. Not the kind of experience you want at their price point and type of food. We were given menus and then ignored for ten minutes. A group of six were seated next to us and we had to move seats around to let them in, because things were so tight. Certainly not a good place for an intimate or romantic or for that matter any kind of sit down meal. After about five more minutes, the other group was waited on first. We left and found another Italian restaurant two blocks away that wasn't as upscale, but had decent service and a much more comfortable atmosphere.
author: Larry V.

description:
Delicious food, high prices.

I had lunch here yesterday with a friend. Since the weather was actually sunny and above 60 degrees, we sat outside in the alley.  Between us, we had three glasses of wine.  Each glass cost $11-12, which I thought was overpriced, as I found nothing special about the wine.  But then again, I'm no wine expert, so who knows.

I ordered the Rack of Lamb, which turned out to be delicious.  Even though the meat was cooked to medium well, it was tender.  The rack was flavorful and fragrant in exactly the way a good lamb rack should be.  It was so good that I didn't pay much attention to the sides.  (According to the menu, there were supposed to be garlic chips, herbs, and black truffle; there may have been, but I have no recollection.)  That said, I liked that the mashed potato accompanying the rack seemed lighter than most of the mashed potatoes I've had.

My friend ordered the pork chops (I don't see it on their menu; it could possibly have been the Pork Medallion), which tasted great as well.  He finished his lunch with a cup of coffee.

As much as I enjoyed the food, I was surprised by the $102 bill.  Everything did add up, but I hadn't expected to spend close to $50 on lunch where I had one entree with a glass of wine.

In conclusion: great place to eat, but don't expect to save money.
author: Niya Y.

description: We came here because of the location and saw that it has a nice  little outdoorsy European feel patio. The food on the other hand was just okay.  Nothing to rave about.  The service was definitely lacking.
author: Jacky F.

description: Tasty, authentic Italian seafood. Black ink risotto & angolotti were delicious.  The service was nice and the atmosphere was very pleasant and unique.
author: Michael D.

description:
I've been meaning to give this place a try for a while but never had the chance to come across it. so finally me and my boyfriend came here Friday after work and gave this place a try. 

For those of you who've been to Belden Place know that this is a small alley way with many small restaurants that offers outdoor seating, so it looks super packed. But it sure offers that European feeling while dinning here. The ambiance here is nice, it gives me a nice homey warm feeling while dining and i love the roman murals on the walls. 

The service here is a tad slow, and the servers seems like they're all over the place and kind of lost. The table next to us seem a bit annoyed  that the server hasn't returned with their wine list.
author: Jenny G.

description: I came here not knowing what to expect, I was amaze from my beet salad, squid ink ravioli , and desert was just to die for custard fill donuts with dipping chocolate sauce. Yummy.
author: Mary L.

description: Went for dine about town. Salmon was incredibly moist and fluffy. Made a reservation before going and was seated immediately. Waiter was very attentive. Outdoor seating  is covered and pleasant if the weather holds. Hard to see the names of the different restaurants so it's easy to pass it. It's closer to the entrance of Belden on the Bush street side.
author: Gee H.

description: The Veal Scallopini was so good! Definitely recommend this place, really unique location. I felt like I was in a brasserie in Europe.
author: Rick R.

description: Cafe Tiramisu serves well-executed Italian classics with a bit of flare.  It is not the best or most inventive Italian restaurant in San Francisco by any means, but it is consistent and satisfying -- some of the dishes are excellent. The service is very good and the atmosphere pleasant.
author: Peter H.

description: Good food - great place to go for lunch in the financial district if you want a place to sit outside.
author: Georgina G.

description:
Came here for lunch.  Ordered the chicken sandwich with fries.  The sandwich was ok, the chicken was a bit dry.  Had the creme brulee for dessert.  That was excellent.  

Service was quick.
author: Wendy H.

description:
We came here with 3 other couples, total bill for 8 with gratuity was $430.  The four men involved all left the restaurant still hungry - portions are very small.

My cold italian beer was served in a hot glass fresh out of the diswasher,  the lemon drop martinis were good!

The Salmon and the Striped Bass were the best entrees, the Dover Sole was mediocre and the short rib ravioli was very diasappointing.  

Desert Sampler was very good 

Would not return - Sorry
author: Terry S.

description: Was a tedious experience. Cesaer salad was the smallest portion you can imagine. Cola was not to drink because. the taste of chlorine. The only positive was the atmosphere. A great disappointment
author: Jørn R.

description: The waiters (and the food) made this place.  Went to it with my Italian family and friends and actually went back again for another meal (violating the rule of "you can never go back").  Outstanding italian food, well prepared in its simplicity and taste, in an active and fun setting with terrific waiters whose fluent italian made all of us feel like we were part of the family.  All the food was good so I am not going to pick out any particular one.
author: Paul M.

description: Just had an unbelievable lunch here! Heirloom tomatoe soup was top notch and the grilled swordfish was equally as good. Highly recommended!
author: Peter S.

description:
I came here with 5 other people.  I really enjoyed the ambience.  The walls have "ancient" Roman murals with the effect of peeling paint (except the peels are painted on).  It's located in an alley beside other restaurants and is a little hard to find, but I truly felt like I was in Italy.  There's also patio seating.

I got the orecchiette, which is a flat handmade pasta with sauteed greens and spicy sausage.  It was excellent.  My group also enjoyed the tortellini.  The bread served is room-temperature ciabatta with pesto.

We got a bottle of wine; the waiter told us that he would give us a better bottle for the same price.  When the bill came, the bottle he had recommended was $20 extra - however, when we pointed it out, they reduced it to the price of the original bottle we had wanted.  (Make sure you keep an eye on the bill for tricks like that).

All in all, very reasonable priced - it came to $26 a person for an entree plus wine.  Get a bottle of wine if you are a group.

Parking is difficult, so coming here on public transportation recommended.
author: Bee M.

description: I had the striped sea bass and it was ok.  The shrimp that came with the dish was ok.  Nothing really overwhelmed me.  We had the Tiramisu sampler, which included a small bite of all of the restaurant's dessert.  The tiramisu was great, of course.  The flourless chocolate cake was not delicious at all and all others were just ok.
author: Yun C.

description: This place sucks 500%.  They rejected mine and my colleagues visit because I wanted to have desert and they said only those interested in dinner are being sited. This is the worst customer service ever. Will never visit this place again.
author: Karina S.

description:
Great spot to grab lunch on a day like today, seems like a nice romantic spot for dinner as well.  Its like a little piece of Europe.  Its pretty discreet and I would have never found it on my own, but its absolutely adorable.

I had the buffalo mozarella salad, which was phenomenal.  The Mozarella was super creamy, the prosciutto was super tasty and fresh...and dessert...oh dessert.  

I decided on the warm chocolate cake, the best decision I made ever on a Monday.  It comes with a nice chocolate ice cream in a wafer bowl and a hazelnut soup, which is perfect to dip your warm chocolate cake into.

What a meal...it was more like an event, perfect meal for a sunny Monday.  It got my mind off of work for an hour and put me in a very happy place.  Enjoy.
author: Ronjini M.

description:
Very average 'Italian' food. 4 of is coulnd finish their dish! Guys including "gratuity" 25% without asking of client! 
(I Have experience living in Italy in several cities). 
Wouldn't recommend or come back again.
author: De S.

description: I really loved this place. The food was amazing the service was great and the owner really takes the time to chat and make you feel at home .
author: Alan L.

description:
came here with a friend for a dine about town dinner date.

the restaurant is a very cute and cozy place snuggled in belden pl

we both got the duck ragu orechiette orecchiette and the tiramisu for dessert.  i had the crab ravioli and my friend had the steak. i loved everything except for the crab ravioli. the duck pasta was very tasty and comforting, the steak cooked very nicely and very tender, and the tiramisu was one of the best ive had. the crab ravioli however was pretty disappointing. it lacked depth in flavor and just wasn't a very satisfying dish for me.

overall, good experience!
author: Katherine C.

description:
Came here for the first time during Friday night dinner hours.  My awesome two friends were treating me for my birthday and I had never been to the Belden Place alley before.  All the tables were lined up next to each other outside...restaurant to restaurant with people packed in like sardines.  When we sat down, I literally could hear four conversations around me from adjoining tables since we and most people who sat outside had to raise our voice to be heard.  

Well onto the food.  I ordered the seared ahi which was excellent along with a spicy vegetable risotto that came with it.  My friends had the pork chop and salmon which I also liked.  We ordered a half bottle Mondavi merlot from our waiter but after a few sips, we found out he gave us a Cab...what the f----?  At that point, whatever, the wine was fine.  Despite the wine cock-up, our waiter tried his best to serve us...although the seating arrangement made it hard to talk to him.  For dessert, we got the panna cotta with the fresh fruit.  I liked it and how it was their lightest dessert compared to their biscotti, chocolate cake, or creme brulee options.  

I'd definitely come here again but perhaps during a less crowded lunch service or an early dinner.  There are like five other restaurants on the Belden Row, so I'd probably head to see those first before I try Tiramisu again.
author: Ben H L.

description:
I totally forgot about my last review.. haha that happens.. 

Well I came back to Tiramisu for a business meeting. The food was actually pretty yummy. I tried the risotto with a pumpkin sauce.. creamy, butter with a hint of truffle oil.. mmmmm

I'll come back for more..
author: Monica S.

description: Owner is amazing. Atmosphere is the best in San Fran!!
author: Sage W.

description:
If I could give 5 1/2 stars, I would!
Outstanding service (we sat on the "patio"), fantastic food, and wonderful ambiance!
My husband and I were celebrating our 1 year anniversary.  The restaurant was suggested to us by someone and it sounded great.  We recently returned from Italy and loved that the restaurant took use back to there.  If you love patio dining in Europe, you'll love this place!  The service was top notch, they never missed a beat.  Waters and drinks, always full.  Empty plates didn't linger, and coffee at the end of the meal was propmt.
We ordered bruschetta as an appetizer and it was so delicious!!
I had the Wild Boar Bolagnese and my husband had a steak.  Both were fantastic!  My pasta was tender and fresh and the sauce was fantastic!
We didn't have room for dessert, but the after meal coffee was unexpected and appreciated.
I would most definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone and I would suggest sitting on the patio if you can.
author: Dana B.

description: I'm so glad I tried this place.  It's down the cute Belden Alley.  Service was great from start to finish.  We tried the Black Ink Risotto.  I highly recommend this appetizer!  I was a little bit put off because the word black ink, but I mainly tasted a great blend of the lobster bisque.  Perfect blend of creaminess and so flavorful.  I ordered the Dungeness Crab Agnolotti.  They do not skimp out on the crab!!  They make their own pasta here and you can definitely tell the difference.  I'm actually not a big fan of Italian because usually places usually overload it with sauce and cheese but this place is not that.  Extremely well made food and the ambiance is just warm and loving.  And I didn't even drink wine!!  I definitely recommend this place.
author: Tammy N.

description:
I love eating on Belden Pl. Today we came here for one of my co-worker's going away lunch. Unfortunately our party was too large to be seated outdoors but we had the entire downstairs area to ourselves.

The bread is yummy -- especially the pesto based olive oil.

The big hits for our party of 15 were the hangar steak, seared ahi tuna with shrimp risotto, the rotisserie chicken and the pan roasted salmon.
author: Helen Y.

description:
The European flavor of San Francisco...Italian speaking waiters.
The Starter: Tuna carpaccio with fresh Crab and Avocado. AMAZING! dipping olive oil sauce for bread was wonderful. I had Gnocchi with tomato sauce and eggplant. very "real" tasting and fresh.
author: Debby W.

description:
*****5 STARS****** 

I dined here last Friday with a large group, in spite of which, the service couldn't have been more friendly/professional...dare I say indulgent?? Friday night was one of those dreamy evenings where all the planets were in alignment for amazing things to happen...and oh did they!! First of these...the meal:  

I started with the white asparagus soup and the white anchovies over the zucchini carpaccio... the soup was tasty but one note...the anchovies were delicious and I still lament sharing those with my friend...thats ok, I ate most of his crab cake...which was all a crab cake should be and more!

The Quail! Superb! Wrapped in pancetta that came with grilled polenta!! OMG! The Earth moved! (~_~)  I'm still having flashbacks to that lil bird and it's succulence!  And grilled polenta to die for...the "Five Family's" would be willing to "go to the mattresses"  to gain the bragging rights to the polenta prep method used here!!!!!

Peach tart for dessert, accompanied by a Fog Bank ! Heaven on Earth! Just when I thought I was finished, they dragged me back in...my host insisted I try the Pinto Retiro port! What's a girl to do?  I sipped and swooned!!! A must try if you're a fan of port wine! 

Everyone in our large party was delighted with the food/service/vibe and of course, location of Cafe Tiramisu!  Belden affords some of the best people watching opportunities anywhere in the universe! You really do feel like you're in in Paris or Rome, first time diners constantly remark on this point and long time clients are still charmed by it and definitely why they keep coming back!! 

Gracie Cafe Tiramisu!!! You outdid yourself!!
author: Karen S.

description: Would give this place less if i could - rude and slow service, cold food, bread basket is a joke (stale sandwich roles in a bowl)...way too many good restaurants in the city to pick this one!
author: Wendy J.

description:
Black Ink Risotto with pan seared scallop and lobster bisque.  Sounds like three dishes, doesn't it?  Ah, but it's all one deliciously delightful dish.   The lobster bisque is very thick and served more as a sauce.  
It's wonderful.  Simply wonderful.

Had the short ribs for my entree.  So good!  Fall off the bone tender, the way short ribs should be.  Hubby had the hanger steak, also perfect.

Sadly, no room for dessert.
author: Denise M.

description: Do you like waiting for 30 minutes to be greeted by waitstaff?  Do you like waiting for over an hour for an appetizer?  How about another hour for your entree?  The wait is unbearable.  we watched so many people leave but we stayed and drank an entire bottle of wine before the meal because we were there FOREVER.  I looked forward to the new sea bass edition to the menu but was sadly disappointed when it came.  The "filet of sea bass" was the smallest piece of fried fish that belonged in a paper pirate ship at long john's.  The grilled asparagus was about 4 skinny pieces chopped up and the " sautéed clams" was half of one clam marinated in vinegar and chopped.  The waiter apologized and said the wine was on him and it was, he didn't include the glass of white wine nor the bottle.  We paid cash, gave him a good tip and got the hell out of there.
author: James R.

description: We were on Belden Ave and l was on a hunt for some gnocchi. 3 of the restaurants there had it on the menu but only this one was in a pesto instead of a cream sauce so that made my choice for me. WOW. The texture and flavor were absolutely perfect!!! My husband had the almond chicken ravioli, which he loved too. We also shared the tiramisu which was really good, as you would expect from a place named after it. l think our waiter was the owner- he was a little impersonal but I really don't care because the service was fast and the food was beyond delicious.
author: Laine C.

description: Set up reservations through Open Table now that they are linked to Yelp.  Easty to do.  Nice indoor and outdoor seating area in this alley restaurant.  Heaters under the awning helps especially those closest to the building.  If you are sitting away from the building it can get cold.  Appetizers, pasta dishes all excellent.  Great wine selection especially if going by the bottle.  Tiramisu was outstanding.
author: Marcus K.

description:
Me ordered buffalo mozzarella ravioli that was supposed to have prosciutto somewhere in it but didn't. It also came with these little garlic chips when it said it was going to come with little basil chips. Meh. It was decent, but a little oiley. I didn't pay for it, so that made it a bit better. Yah. The paper on the table was dirty too, like they didnt change it from the last people who sat there. Then they didnt bring the water for one of the people I was with. Hmmm...Did I mention I didn't pay? 

Three stars cus I didn't pay. If I would have paid...two.
author: Danielle L.

description:
I ate here with one of my friends and I felt really sick afterwards.  I thought it was just me but she felt the same too.  We ordered oysters,  crab cake, beef steak and short ribs.  We're thinking it was the oysters..

I'll give it  another try and get pasta instead.
author: Angelica C.

description:
I am pretty opposed to everywhere on Belden Lane.  They're all the same... so beautiful, on this incredibly picturesque little alley of restaurants in the middle of the Financial District.

Thing is that Cafe Tiramisu and the others on this row rely on their location and charm to substitute for quality of food, while still charging a premium price.  Without exception, dishes here have been just average, if not actually unappealing.  My fish for instance was pretty overcooked.  But what can you do, it's Belden Place.

If you want a business lunch in a place that looks beautiful, and quality is not a necessity, then come here.  It'll look great.  But if you want great food...get thee elsewhere.
author: David W.

description: Absolutely fabulous!  Great service, ambience, and atmosphere.
author: C J.

description:
We stopped in on our first night in the city based on the recommendation of the hotel staff.  We sat on the patio at a lopsided table for two.  The hostess was very sweet and checked on us throughout the meal.  However, she was the only one.

Our waitress didn't show up for 20 minutes.  Eventually another waiter came by and said our waitress was overwhelmed and took our order.  We waited over an hour for our food.  It was entertaining watching all the tables get up and leave when they got tired of waiting.  

While waiting on the wood the wine took its course and I made my way to the restroom in the basement.  I noticed that we were not alone as only one table had food on it.  

The food was overpriced and not worth the wait.  Hotel staff fail!  Don't trust the staff at the Taj!
author: Jeff S.

description:
Café Tiramisu used to be my favorite lunch spot.  Love their outdoor seating, especially when it is sunny and warm.  But based on my last two visits, I think the food was going downhill.  It was not as good as before.  

We started with the Caesar Salad.  The salad was fresh.  The complimentary bread was just so so.  You can save room for something else.  

I got the Black ink risotto with seared scallops.  It was good but not great.  It was a little bit salty to me.  My friend ordered the beef short ribs.  She told me it was just ok.  

My last visit was able a month ago......I got the Sea Bass.  The sea bass was tasteless.  

However, the services were still pretty good there.  Sweet, warm, friendly and efficient.  No complaints on that!
author: Liza T.

description:
Food was okay, but service was terrible.  Waiters were knocking into us physically as we were chatting, carried a rude tone of voice with every interaction, and got exasperated when one of our party members waffled on an order.  There are plenty of other restaurants in the alley, none of which could possibly have less courteous staff.

And btw, tapenade in the watermelon and mango salad is just nasty.
author: Sierra M.

description: Worst service ever!!! Waited over an hour and a half for an entree and that's after waiting 30 minutes past our reservation time just to sit down, groups that came in way after us were getting served their entrees before us! the food was good but there are plenty of Italian restaurants in this city with good food and much better service.
author: Ashley L.

description:
The restaurant has a really nice atmosphere. We had reservations and they took us to their downstairs area.. the downside to this was it smelled like mold!! Luckily, the food smell covered it up once it arrived.  

Our server seemed like he didnt want to be there. We asked him about a dish and did not sell it at all. However, all the food we ordered was DELICIOUS!! We also got a bottle of wine and Tiramisu since we felt obligated at a place named after the dessert. It was well worth it! The alley where this is located is also very nice.
author: Melissa W.

description:
Five Star Breakdown:

-Delightful Mushroom Ravioli with Truffle Sauce
-Sexy Italian Waiter
-Hot Bread w/ Pesto Oil
-Ambiance
-Great Conversation (downstairs)

..I have a total crush on this place and Belden!
author: Virgo M.

description:
Horrible.

My butter lettuce salad came with hazelnuts, gorgonzola dolce, and a dusting of sand.  I got more worried with each bite that I was going to chip a tooth so ended up not eating much of it.  The waiter didn't bother to ask if my salad was ok.

I ordered my steak 'medium rare,' and apparently he heard, 'barely pan seared, cold and raw in the middle.'  I ate probably a quarter of my steack, just cutting off the cooked parts and eating that.  Again, the waiter didn't bother to ask if my steak was ok.

Normally, I would have sent both dishes back, but I was dining with the in-laws and didn't want to make a big stink.  Of course, now my mother in law probably thinks I'm anorexic, which I would be if I ever had to dine at Cafe Tiramisu again.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Five stars for the food! The service and atmosphere probably weren't 5 star over the top, but they were as expected.

First off, the bread they give you come with some olive oil/pesto to put on it, which is delicious. 

For my main course I got the salmon with asparagus and rissoto. SO GOOD. Highly recommend. 

For dessert we got the profiteroles. It comes with 5 and some chocolate sauce - perfect for sharing. 

They definitely have beer and wine, not positive about full bar. 
Seemed like a good spot for a work dinner, date, or group friends dinner.
author: Caitlin B.

description: Giuseppe, you're amazing & thank you for being the gracious host you were for my buddy's bday/baby shower luncheon.  The food was amazing & I promise to be back for that limoncello.  I'm already plotting my next visit with hopes that the menu isn't changed!!  Everything from beginning to end was delicious.  For starters we had the bruscetta, calamari, oysters, sardines & beet salad.  I would order them ALL and whatever else is on the appetizer menu again.  I myself had the shrimp & zucchini blossom risotto.  Other entrees that blessed our table were pici, gnocci, the grand ole pork chop & veal.  They make all of their pastas in house & it pays off.  As if the meal and service weren't enough.  They sent out a table full of complimentary desserts.  How can you say no to that?  Especially when there's an espresso creme brulee, chocolate torte/cake & cream puffs with ganache staring you down.  Out of the couple of different cute little places in this famous food alley I'd definitely pay my next visit to Cafe Tiramisu & opt for that sunny table outside again.  More pasta please!!!........and my beet salad (a must!)
author: Stephanie D.

description: This was where I first tried risotto when I was at Cal and I was happy that I was able to share this special restaurant with my family. The risotto dish with seared ahi tuna is the best in town. Prices very competitive. Barramundi fish was prepared very well. Wait staff was nice. Sauteed spanish complimented the food well. My child said the short ribs were good, but the mash potatoes were not good according to their opinion (I didn't try this dish). But the fingerling fried potatos were good. You need to go.
author: Captain S.

description:
Food was good.  Not excellent or memorable, but not dreary or boring either.

DH and I shared the burrata with lobster and that was good.  For dinner, my entree was the risotto with A seared scallop.  My dish was, YUP, you guessed it good, but a bit too salty for my taste.  DH had the wild boar and I thought it was, Ummm, yeah, good; however, he didn't really care for it.

Dessert.  We shared tiramisu.  All I can say is it wasn't that good.  I've had better, much, much better.

Service was "meh."  Our server wasn't very friendly, kinda dry and boring actually.  He wasn't overly attentive, nor was he under attentive.  However, the bus boys were anxious to rid our table of our plates, even with a few bites left.

Overall, perhaps I should give it 2 vs. 3 stars, but things were just okay and good and times, but nothing deserving more or less . .  this place is simply mediocre.
author: Karen B.

description: Pretty good place, I quite enjoyed it.  The service, seating, appetizers and main dish were great.  I've had better Italian food but this place is pretty good.  Keep up the great work little Café Tiramisu.
author: Brad S.

description:
Located in Belden Lane aka one of the most picturesque, cutest alleyways! When you enter, it seriously just feels like you are in Europe.

Food is alright; not really too memorable or exciting, though I DID come during lunch (more casual??). I had pasta, and I had the Tiramisu for dessert (a given, since they named their restaurant AFTER it). I've never really had tiramisu before, but I would admit that it was really good. Melted in my mouth!
author: Melody L.

description: Went to Cafe Tiramisu for lunch yesterday, after seeing it on Check, Please! Homemade pasta! Homemade bread! Homemade lemoncello! We split an order of the grilled calamari. Perfect! Grilled is so much better than battered and deep fried. The grilled calamari had a wonderful slight sear on the outside and the inside was just cooked enough to remain tender. The squid ink drizzle and the zucchini carpaccio & olives set off the dish wonderfully. Next we ordered 2 pasta dishes. The squid ink linguini with mussels, clams and prawns exceeded expectations, with the mussels and clams cooked but not dried out - I think the rapid turnover keeps everything freshen the kitchen. We also had the linguine with seafood which featured a brown mushroom sauce. Both dishes were excellent. The place gets very busy and a bit hectic but we never felt rushed and our waiter, Tony, was very helpful. They have a small but good selection of half bottles of wine which is perfect for lunch for 2. We'll definitely go back, and are planning to bring out of town guests this summer.
author: Mark P.

description:
The place is very small but I was beyond impressed with the variety of dishes they served. All authentic but very particular which are rare in the U.S, I only saw these dishes in Italy.

Get the black ink risotto with scallops, yum...

The waiters also tend to have a sense of humor, especially if you speak Italian
author: Veronica S.

description:
1.5 stars ... but rounding up instead of down because I have fond memories of this place when I came here back when I was young(er) and before they became corrupt with greed.

Let me ask some questions that are sarcastic in tone .....

- why do you have leggy women standing outside trying to drum up business and then ignore them once you seat them?
- why do you have perky women standing outsdie trying to drum up business, but you call us and threaten to cancel our reservation if our entire party does not arrive exactly on time?
- why do you seat people, if you aren't going to serve and feed them?

Sure, I was on edge - it was 6:50 and I had an 8:00 PM Jersey Boys show to catch.  It was my own fault for expecting faster service at a place like that on Friday night ... 25 minutes after drink orders to take your meal order is a tad long no?  Ultimately, we had to get up, go fetch our waiter for him to come take our order. Shame ... SHAME on us. 

I had the ahi tuna and it was prepared perfectly.  I would have enjoyed my meal even more if I didn't have to inhale it.  But the part of of the evening aside from the waiting that actually really PISSED me off is that a restaurant of this type, had NO vegetarian food.  We asked the waiter several different times and his response was ... no, sorry, nothing.  Honestly, you could have made a pasta without seafood ... you're not the one cooking it asshole.

I'm willing to give this place another go ... next time to stay long enough to enjoy the desserts (those are vegetarian no?)... and hopefully I'll get some service before I retire.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
As this was one of the nicer days we've experienced recently, my new manager was kind enough to take the team out for lunch somewhere we could sit outdoors. I had never been to Belden alley before, and it was a pleasant surprise to see so many restaurants off the street in a place where one could dine outside in the sunshine.

Initial Impressions: Good. Each table is provided some crusty Italian bread and some Pesto. This is impressive, as a good pesto is quite the treat, and it took some effort to just not eat an entire loaf of bread with it.

My lunch itself was a wild boar ragout with pasta, and was quite delicious, though was served a little on the cold side. Tasty enough so that I still enjoyed it, it didn't blow me away, and was a little on the expensive side (Had I been paying). However, the portion was perfect lunch sized, and I did not fall into my traditional post-lunch coma.

A co-worker of mine had the braised beef short ribs, which also looked fall-off-the-bone tender, and would certainly be on my list of things to order next time.

3 and a Half Stars if I could provide it. Would go back.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Come here for the outdoor seating area, as it is the real winner. Tiramisu is located in Belden Alley where there are several similar small cafes packed into a little alley way. It kind of gives you a feeling that you are dinning at a bistro in a square in Italy or France. If it is a nice day I would highly recommend you eat out side. Just be aware that it gets pretty crowed and the tables are literally right on top of each other. 

The food is good but there is far better Italian food in the city for a much more reasonable price. I just had their ahi tuna and it was delicious. But at 28 dollars it was hardly worth it. I would rather go to The House if I am going to spend that type of money.  My favorite on the menu is the braised short ribs. If you get them for lunch be prepared to take a nap afterwords since they are so rich.
author: Jeff P.

description:
This is my 5th time at Cafe Tiramisu.. Each time it becomes more and more enjoyable - food is great, ambiance is perfect and in the heart of SF - what more can you ask for ?!?   

Tonight was the first time that I had dinner there for a party larger than 4.  Lisa worked with me on getting a prefixed menu together to make sure we covered all bases for our party of 25 to make sure the evening would be perfect for two of my girlfriends as we were celebrating their birthdays. 

* Pappardelle - Ragout with Boar
* Raviloi - Sage with Garlic Chips
* Pork Chop - Grilled Blueberries and Asparagus
* Chicken Breast 
* Salmon - Pesto and Deep Fried Potato

Followed by a Tiramisu Sampler

Lisa was easy to work with to make sure all i's were dotted and t's were crossed and our evening was meant to be enjoyable and fun! I brought gourmet cupcakes for the two birthday celebrants and our waiter placed it on platters for us and served it to all three of our tables across the room.  

Cafe Tiramisu is small and quaint so to have our large party seated downstairs made it easy for our friends to enjoy our private gathering even with three tables strategically placed separately.  

Nevertheless, I have to say Tiramisu once again has exceeded my expectations of great customer service and excellent consistency on food gives me a reason to always come back! (note: on their regular menu my favorite dish is their beef short ribs and or their pork medallion)
author: Caroline C.

description: Extremely limited menu at Cafe Tiramisu. I had the risotto and it was very good, but I felt like I was being rushed out of there.  My friend and I felt rushed to order, rushed to eat and rushed to get out.  It's a shame because we wanted to order dessert but were stressed out!
author: Sandra P.

description: Incredibly underwhelming experience here. The service was extremely slow and the waiter was down right rude to us and snapped at us twice. He clearly was having a bad evening (broke 3 glasses and complained multiple times about it being too busy with these "picky marathon people") When the food arrived after 1.5 hours, the salad were salty and over-dressed and the entrees lacking in flavor. Stay away from this place...especially on a weekend..they can't seem to manage a full house.
author: Rachel G.

description: Unfortunately, getting two starts because of the service, and it's a good thing the food was actually good or might not get a star at all!  We were a group of 8 at 7:30 during the week. You'd think they were doing us a favor by having us in for dinner.  After sitting for 20 minutes with no food, water or bread, they finally took an order and brough one bottle of wine.  It took another 15 minutes to bring another!  We were a group of 8!  You'd think they were paying for the wine....We were traveling all day and we wanted bread since they weren't in any hurry in taking our order.  They said they don't give bread until you order food; but did anyway and then in the end my husband got yelled at because he got oil on the .30 menu page.  Literally got yelled at~!  For nearly $800 in the end, I just don't understand why they didn't serve us. Food was tasty, but with all the great city choices out there; why go someplace that htey don't think service is needed.  Sorry Cafe Tiramisu....
author: Missy M.

description: Tucked away in what appears to be an ally you will find this little treasure of a restaurant. With an Italian feel and menu to match the food is exquisite. Our experience began with oysters with classic mignonette and fresh horseradish. Typically I'm not a fan of horseradish but the way it was served it made it not only tolerable, but enjoyable.  Our main dishes arrived, I ordered the chicken breast. Don't allow the name alone to fool you, the dish was fulfilling and more. The chicken was juicy and the melted cheese and spinach married the flavor of the truffle sauce together wonderfully. The pumpkin gnocchi were a pleasant match with the dish. I took a few fork fulls of my boyfriend's dish (for review purposes of course ;D ) He ordered the striped sea bass filet which came with lobster, mashed potatoes, and saffron sauce-all of course rich and satisfying. He ordered a side of parmesan risotto just because and that too was wonderful. Truly one of the best meals we have enjoyed in a while.
author: Cyndi S.

description:
I love their medium-rare skirt steak! It is very soft and juicy, and the special sauce is so yummy with the super fine cut fries.

This place is a bit too crowded, and better make reservation in order to sit inside.
author: Polly C.

description:
Dessert gets 5 stars (if you get the dessert sampler you'll be incredibly happy! the chocolate raspberry cake ROCKS :))

Dinner gets 2 stars. I am a sucker for homemade pasta, but it was a little disappointing. The past stuck together, wasn't cooked quite right and the flavors weren't all that exciting either. 

Appetizers get 3 stars. Bruschetta was solid - not amazing, but will be a repeat if I return. 

Overall - slightly pricey for what you get, but still worth checking out once or twice - the atmosphere is nice (definitely a cute date place)
author: linda t.

description: Solid.  Grilled calamari fresh, and tasty.  Ravioli home made, light and fresh! Tiramisu nicely done.  Well done.
author: Rob M.

description:
Delicious food. My foodie parents loved their meals. My dad had the risotto & my mom had the steak I believe.  
I had asparagus ravioli, with asparagus & ricotta filling & fresh asparagus with the pasta.
It was SO delicious. My dad sad that the place reminded him of a restaurant he visited in 
Geneva so that was cool. My only complaint is that the women's restroom could be a little better managed. But go for the food definitely!
author: Jenna K.

description: As always, their food did not disappoint. I had the veal and it was incredible! Everyone else seemed pleased with their food as well.
author: Michelle G.

description: After searching for restaurants in the financial district that serve local food, I decided upon this restaurant, after studying the menu online I planned on ordering the Pancetta wrapped quail, only to find out it wasn't on the menu when I arrived. Disappointed, I decided to try the Sonoma Lamb Loin Chops, which is served with cannelloni beans, salsa verde and swiss chard. I'm not a big fan of beans so substituted extra swiss chard. I've ordered lamb at one other restaurant, and thought it was just okay. This was amazing. This was the best lamb dish I've had, and probably one of the top 5 meals that I've had. The lamb chops paired with the swiss chard and the salsa verde were perfect. The lamb chops were cooked perfectly.  This was one of those meals, where I didn't want to finish it, it was so good. Service was good, a little slow, like being in a restaurant in Europe.
author: Alison M.

description: Ambiance was so so; a bit loud, especially out side. Food was better then I expected; Swordfish was excellent, enjoyed several dessert's shared with friends, steamed muscles were not very good in my opinion and I would get these somewhere else if this is important to you. Service was attentive.
author: Jeff W.

description: Booked a table last min for lunch and they had availabilities. Tried their Sole and it was unmemorable... pretty bland and probably should have come with a side of potatoes or veggies given it was pretty unsubstantial. Of course I had to try their Tiramisu--that almost made up for the dissapointing meal itself! It was pure heaven, YUM.
author: Amy S.

description: I'd easily give this place four stars if not for one thing: the service here is consistently less than it should be.  The wait staff is bored, borderline surly, and just generally an unhappy lot.  The food is actually very good and the location is great (LOVE Belden Place) but the guys who serve you clearly wish they were doing something else.  It detracts from what could otherwise be a perfectly lovely experience.  I've been here three times now and every time, I experience this negative vibe from the wait staff.
author: Jill T.

description: We wanted to find a restaurant that didn't have just a NYE fixed menu and this was it. They had what appeared to be their standard menu or a $85 per person NYE special. I was with a group of  6 and we all went a la carte/no fixed menu. They had setup a special outdoor dining around which is where we sat and dined. It was a little cold outside, especially near the entrance. We had reservations so we were all seated right away. We had the Pear appetizer which was outstanding - A pear marinated in a red wine sauce I believe, very creative and tasty. They also served rolls with Pesto sauce, and the sauce was perfect. My girlfriend and I had the Sea Bass and Steak Medallions. The Sea Bass was ok, but the steak was great - cooked properly and served with a potato and cream of spinach. My sister was with us and she requires a Gluten free diet, so she ordered the Steak as well and asked the waiter if it did not have any wheat or flour and he confirmed. Unfortunately I don't think he fully understood as the steak was served with a sauce, which appeared to be made with flour. He offered another dish, but she was already content with eating the sides and appetizers. It is tough being gluten free and trying to eat out, especially on NYE. We also had desserts, the chocolate/caramel torte which was ok. Shockingly, nobody in our party ordered the Tiramisu, the restaurants name, so we have no idea if it is the best in the city...perhaps it is something to go back and try. 4 of 5 stars, mainly based on the lack of gluten experience, but again, that is a tough one to support, especially on NYE.
author: John P.

description:
Cute, romantic and dimly lit restaurant tucked away in an alley of FiDi.  But you definitely feel like you've stepped into another world once you head inside the restaurant.

Start with the mussels in a choice of either saffron, pesto, or pepperoncini and chive broth.  Go saffron!

Risotto with crayfish, shaved black truffles, and Pecorino cheese.  Yay truffles!

Sea Bass with Tuscan black mussels salad.  Yum sea bass!

And...we had to order the tiramisu for the sake of ordering a tiramisu at Tiramisu.  I admit it's a bit expensive for dessert, but well worth it.
author: Jenny L.

description:
This place is so so. I came here for lunch with some co-workers just before the lunch rush (get there early it will probably get packed). I had the linguine which was good, but nothing extraordinary. The decor is slightly cheesy old-world Italian, but it didn't bother me much. The wait staff is very helpful and the restaurant is conveniently located downtown. Overall, this place is just ok.

Try it. Maybe like it. Maybe repeat.
author: Jenna s.

description:
This USED to be a great place to eat, my last time there (3/3/2012) was a total RIP OFF! I called about getting just dessert, Tiramisu of course, it used to be almost 6" by 6" by almost 3" thick, and VERY tasty. This time it was lass than 3" by 3" and less than an inch thick, and tasted like it came from Costso. LAME!!!!!
I not only will NEVER go back I will tell everyone I know to avoid it.
author: Doug R.

description:
I'm always looking for good Italian restaurant that aren't in North Beach to try out. This one was actually pretty good!

Tucked away in a little alley off of Kearny, we were greeted by French-speaking hostesses and waiters. Makes the atmosphere feel a little more authentic.

I ordered the Risotto which was excellent. Pesto, summer corn, spicy prawns on top of a lobster bisque drizzle. Delish. 

Did not get to try any of the desserts, but will have to come back to try other dishes!
author: Lauren F.

description: Five stars for the actual tiramisu. As for dinner, I had the lobster ravioli and my date had a pasta dish with crab and lobster. My dish was decent, but I tried his and wasn't a fan. Still, sitting outside under the lights was charming....and I'd come back solely for that dessert.
author: A M.

description: So the ambiance of this place is amazing.. really cute with outdoor patio seating, which I always love.  They have heat lamps, but somehow they didn't seem to radiate to our table well and I definitely ended up cold.  The waiter was helpful and accommodating, since I'm vegetarian and asked if certain dishes could be tailored to me.  He even came back and told me what was possible and not, which I appreciated.  I ended up sticking with the menu and getting the gnocchi, which when served hot was good, but as it quickly cooled down, it just felt overly cheesy, heavy, and not flavorful enough.  The bruschetta was really good though, as was the panna cotta.  I was a little irritated that the waiter kept trying to clear my plate when it was apparent I was still working on it, though.  But overall, I had a great time at the restaurant and appreciated the ambiance.
author: Rachana S.

description: The food was very good: carpaccio flavorful, and the calamari appetizer, not fried but sauted and whole, was also very tender. Having been in Tuscany last fall, we have been looking for pici pasta ever since. We found it here, and the seafood sauce was delicious . My wife had rabbit, also hard to find. Guiseppe, the owner, recommended a wine which served us well. Service was excellent, and clean silverware arrived with each course, and exceedingly rare event.
author: george p.

description:
Was put off by the name--imagined an 80s or 90s generic Italian, as well as by the Vegas/ south beach style people standing along belden  place trying to lure you in.  Wld have assumed tourist trap worst but for the fact that it was chosen by my SF foodie friends.  It was really fun--my friends know the owner Giuseppe, who is wonderful and treated us right.  The bruschetta with eggplant paste, roasted red pepper and white anchovy was wonderful-- it helped that Giuseppe told us how he loved anchovies since he was a boy in Italy, steadying the boat as the fishermen dragged in the bulging nets.  Pastas were all fine--go with the ones involving things like veal cheek, boar Ragu, but all seemed really flavorful.  We had a nice primitivo which was appropriate to the food.

Lesson learned: food on belden lane can be excellent--tiramisu will get a return visit from me!
author: Leslie C.

description: I literally felt like I was dining in Rome. The restaurant is one of several Mediterranean eateries located in a charming alley with predominantly outdoor seating. And then there were the highrises of the financial distance topping over me, framing my peripheral vision. The tables are connected and filled--very easy to meet interesting people. Wonderful ambiance. Very delicious foods. They do not take reservations, and it is definitely bustling, but it doesn't take too long to get a table.
author: Djamila D.

description:
The Quail was absolutely delicious here.  I had it months ago and when someone asks me for quail I can't stop thinking about this one dish here.  Going to have to come back and have it again.  

Here's the description from their menu online:
Quail
Pancetta wrapped, Grilled Polenta, Balsamic-Honey, Sage & Garlic chips
 $23

The grilled polenta was yummy, the balsamic-honey was a good compliment and the sage chips were my favorite part of the meal actually.  I love crispy sage as it is unique and flavorful.
author: Alias A.

description: Love this court/area in general.
author: Thao V.

description: Had a table for 2 at 5pm on a Thursday. They gave us cold, hard bread that was definitely not fresh. We ordered the zucchini blossom tempura, scallops and risotto for appetizers. My fiancée liked his scallops but I was disappointed in the zucchini. It was a small size and it was lukewarm. And mind you, there were only 2 other patrons at the time, so I expected the food to be piping hot since none of the staff had much to do but cook, greet, and serve. The staff was very prompt, however. Anyway. So for entrees, we ordered the ravioli beef short ribs and the grilled hawaiian swordfish. Very, very underwhelming. The swordfish tasted like it was frozen then microwaved for too long. Very bland and dry. No flavor whatsoever. The ravioli was just ok but my fiancée's grandma makes it ten times better. Also the portions were both so small compared to the prices they were set at. Finally, we order a tiramisu. This was the best thing we ate. I mean, it wasn't the best tiramisu I've had but it was the best part of the meal. So all in all, we spent $100 for the whole meal, including tip and, unfortunately, I have to say that it was not worth the money, time, or appetite. Save yourself for some real authentic Italian food in north beach.
author: M D.

description:
Nish took the yelpettes to Cafe Tiramisu today for our Holiday lunch, a tiny little restaurant in Belden Lane that would be easy to overlook if you didn't know any better.

The ahi tuna crudo and beef carpaccio were lovely starters, and topped with parmesan and freshly shaved truffles. Yes, truffles! You know when the waiter goes around shaving truffles on everything you're in the right place. I ordered the mussels for a main course, since the weather was soo cold outside, and dipped my bread in the soupy fennel broth. I got a tiny bite of Nish's veal and it was cooked perfectly, Roma style.

Oh, and the desserts! This place isn't joking about their tiramisu. It was the perfect texture with just the right amount of cream and rum-soaked cake. But of course, the molten chocolate cake with hazelnut stole the show. It all paired wonderfully with a bottle of wine from the Barbera region in Italy.

Our waiter was really quick, but not very warm, and not helpful at all when we asked for recommendations. I think his attitude was "everything here is good" which is true, but c'mon! I wish he could have pretended to have been inspired about at least one dish.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Went since Check Please Bay Area everyone loved it! Why!!!!!
I know KQED has a lot of foodies, and it's quality t.v. so while in the City I was dying to try this place.  We were greeted by the hostess, the owner was as my bf. said "kind of an ass', didn't get the friendly vibe like on the show.  We were sat at the very back, people have said " They felt as if they were transported to Italy!" Yea it smelled like the Venice canals.  I get it, its an old building but the smell was off putting and gets worse when you go down stairs to use the bathroom or being punished and actually have to sit at the tables down there...  The owner took our order, didn't go over any specials maybe there weren't any?  The menu wasn't that exciting, I wanted to try the homemade pasta and at the recommendation of the owner I ordered the Paperadelle with meat sauce and the bf had Veal Scallopine.  Truthfully nothing sounded all that great.  I ordered a deeelish Prosecco, the waiter brought out with bread, never caught his name.  The bread is made in house, again nothing exciting rolls that should have been served warm I thought and the dipping oil people raved about on this site was forgettable.   I ate a lot of bread since I knew the entree was gonna tank, it did... My dish was paperdalle noodles that were super thin, maybe that's how they are in Italy but I like my pasta with a bit of substance.  The sauce was kinda tasteless except for an overbearing wine taste.  Meeehhh on my food. The bf loooovvveeed his Veal Scaloppine, I don't eat veal but I tried the Parmesan Risotto and again I have had better.  So I thought I will try the Tiramisu, terrible.  Again made in house but over espresso-ed and the bitter chocolate powder was just that a bitter addition, the dish wasn't overly sweet that the powder needed to be added.  It was super crowded, why who knows.  I'm no food expert but this experience for me was bad.  And to offend all the foodies out there, Maggianos which is a chain has better food and the atmosphere doesn't need to transport me anywhere except to sheer ecstasy.  Their Tiramisu is wonderful, and you get as much as you want!  Some Yelper posted on her review that an appetizer, 6 beers and 3 or 4 entrees was $ 150.00, for 1 salad 2 entrees 1 prosecco and a coke was close to $ 80.00 and for a 20% tip we left $ 100.00 lighter.  It's kinda upscale, maybe since I was wearing a Giants ball cap nice yoga outfit and tennis shoes and the b.f. the same we looked like we didn't belong there?  We had been at a football game all day and wanted to eat a nice meal after, we didn't think we need to change!  Wrap Up, wouldn't go back, wouldn't recommend to anyone I like super disappointed and mad at Bay Area Check Please...
author: RedHighHeels R.

description: I've never been treated so poorly by a waiter.  He was rude, unaccomodating, and blamed us for the restaurant's shortcomings.  Yes, they were busy.  It was a Saturday night.  But does that justify treating a customer like crap?  No.  I am never coming back.
author: Kelly W.

description:
Summary based on several lunches and an occasional dinner over years:
--Generally ok to good food
--Good service
--Seating inside or out is pretty good
--Prices ok for area
--Park in a garage or take BART

Scallop black ink risotto is the dish to get here.  With a lot of wine.
author: Rich H.

description: Came with a large group. Tony, our server, was attentive and friendly. Great experience and overall excellent food and wine. Even with all our apps, people cleared their plates of entrees.
author: Terri B.

description: I ordered bruschetta as an appetizer, the prawn ravioli for my entre and doughnuts with chocolate dipping sauce for dessert.  All three dishes were absolutely delicious and I love the atmosphere of the bustling Belden Place alley way.
author: Matt B.

description: Food and ambience were amazing. I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: Mike B.

description: The service was really bad, the plates dirty and the food cold. They took the food back when we said it wasn't hot, when they bought it out again only one of the dishes out of the two where hot. We just gave up and ate what was given to us. Would definitely not go back.
author: moksh m.

description:
I was a little trepidatious about the service because they had gotten some bad reviews for this, but I found nothing to complain about on an early Sunday evening seating.  No abnormal waits, and I felt the staff was attentive.  

We had a party of 6 and tried a number of dishes.  I had a very good potato leek soup (w/ scallop bits).  The greens (salads) were OK, nothing special.  The star of the entrees was unquestionably the short ribs:  Very tender, no knife needed, it falls apart and tasty sauce, on mashed potatoes.  A must have if you are a meat eater.  I had the cioppino, which was good, though the prawns were a little rubbery.  The pasta (large tubes, called paccieri) with a spicy tomato based sauce and seafood was good, and the "spiciness' was mild.  

We ordered the dessert sampler ("for 2", even though we were 6, we were pretty full), and this was a fun way to have some dessert.  It does turn into a free-for-all. I probably liked the creme brulee the best.

The wine menu selection was pretty good, more Italian than California, but not overwhelming in volume.  We had a very nice Sicilian (Nero d'Avola) wine which went well with everything.

We all enjoyed the evening and would definitely return.
author: Shan H.

description: went back for lunch 5 days later and ordered "Just" the pan seared scallops and a glass of wine. They were again very tasty. However, only 2 of my 4 scallops were actually seared with the same crust as the other two. seemed as if the chef was in a hurry to get them out. My waiter was not quite on the mark. as the person that I (assumed) to be the owner asked me if i needed anything else. I asked to see the desert menu. Before he could get it to me , My waiter was putting my check on my table without asking if I wanted desert. Think he got scolded for that error by the assumed owner.. I did enjoy my desert. the triple vanilla dish was delightful. and I look forward to returning again.
author: Judy B.

description: This restaurant is a hidden gem in San Francisco. They have many great Italian dishes and their tiramisu is divine.  My favorite dish, and the reason I often go there for lunch,  is the branzino, which is truly the best I've had anywhere.  I was disappointed to find on my last visit that they removed it from the menu because someone complained that they found a bone in the fish.  I've had that fish many times and never had any issues.  The chef debones it perfectly but this is a fish that is cooked whole and so to miss a single one is not unreasonable.  I think it's reasonable to always check as you eat any fish, after all this is not a McDonald's fish filet.  I really hope they bring the Branzino back as it's a genuine taste of Italy in downtown SF.
author: Annie W.

description:
Ok seriously I have to come here again. What I had here just did not make justice for what I saw my co-workers have.

Zeeky had the risotto with prawn? it looked like prawn.
Jeremiah had the rack of lamb which they also came and topped
off with garlic and something else
And I had the stupid capellini, I failed to notice that it said Scallop not Scallops..so I only got one scallop wrapped in pancetta which tasted pretty good.

But anways, Jean also had the same thing and I want to apologize to the people working here for the attitude she gave off. She was all worried about work and lunch time and all these things. I thought it was ridiculous. But whatever..

Now the Capalleni, well the pasta kind of sucked, the scallop was good but the pasta sucked. It was hard in some parts like maybe it was undercooked? and I have to say kind of bland. A little more flavor just a little bit more. 

Overall the service was good, food was not good for me but I knew it would of been good if I ordered something else. Everyone elses dish seemed to be better than mine.....  =_=
author: phillip w.

description:
Do not eat here.

The service and the food were both horrible!    This is a tourist attraction, and that's all there is to it, with their prime location near Union Square, and their classical modern feel of their ambiance with fancy paintings. 

I ordered the Veel with lemon sauce during dinner time, but it was just thinly sliced veel that did not really have any moisture or taste left, after they tried to tenderize it by pounding on it or something. The lemon sauce was, just lemon??  Where's the complexity to it?  It was served with plainly boiled spinach, with some hard and untasty risotto, which wasn't even a risotto, as the rice was so hard. 
We had a 15 people birthday party, and ordered over $300 or $400 worth of food, and I went up and asked our waiter if they could do something special, maybe a little complimentary dessert on the house, and he plainly refused, as it probably comes out of his own pocket. I was saying "Dude, we're giving you automatic 20%+ tip on the bill with over $300 balance. And you can't give the birthday boy a small dessert??"

I looked in the kitchen, and saw several hispanic looking chefs, and didn't seem very authentic at all, or seemed like they knew what they were doing. The service was lousy too, as all the server did was take our orders, came back maybe only 3 times for water refills and bringing us some breads (it was so hard that I thought it was some bread from couple days ago).

It was a joke alright. And for what? Over priced lousy meal.
author: Bay A.

description: We always enjoy Cafe Tiramisu.  As usual the service was good, the food was tasty and prepared well, the atmosphere is relaxed and inviting. We ate inside, but they do have outside seating.  I love the squash blossoms, my daughter loves the tiramisu.  Cafe Tiramisu continues to be on our list each time we're visiting SF.  I suggest making a reservation, just to be sure.  The alley can get a little cold if you have to wait for a table.
author: Susan B.

description:
I ate here a few nights ago with the GF. The setting is really nice, all outside and everything. It did get a bit cold towards the end of the night, however, and the heaters didn't seem to be placed on. In SF, sometimes you need heaters even in the middle of June. 

The food was pretty good. I had risotto, which I liked. But it wasn't exactly anything crazy good, either. 

The service was acceptable, but far from greater. While the waiter seemed to be a good guy, he mostly ignored out table. I'll chalk it up to the fact that we look young, compared to the rest of the oh-so-sophisticated crowd that was currently eating dinner. Nevertheless, the fact that the waiter forgot that we ordered sides is not a great thing. He really should write the orders down in the future, instead of trying and failing to remember them all in his head. 

Overall, I like the idea of this place much more than I liked it in execution.
author: Chris C.

description:
Went again tonight. For the first time ever sent something back which I never do (the risotto), but everything else was spot on. Just outstanding. I can still taste it... those short ribs are incredible in the Red Wine Sauce Served with Horseradish Mashed Potatoes as was the Ultra-Wide Fettuccine with Wild Mushrooms and Wild Boar Ragu.  Steaming hot and wonderful.

do it... do it.
author: Adam X.

description:
Ish. 
Definitely not all that.
The interior, though nice looking, is cramped and waiters and passers-by are always knocking into chairs and tables with large plates of hot food.  If you choose the outdoor seating be prepared for drafts on a cool night.

There are very few vegetarian options and be wary even if you do order something vegetarian... there was crab cake in my tomato soup (not listed as such on the menu!).  Ugh.  Which brings me to our waiter... though he was friendly in a I'm-trying-too-hard-to-be-funny way it would have been nicer if he had just done his job rather than try to become chums with us.

Point is for the good buffalo mozzarella, decent desserts, and nicely painted walls... otherwise, you could skip this place, not miss a thing and keep your wallet fat and happy.
author: Rashmi N.

description: The food was great and they even put up with us post St. P's day drinking.  The calamari app is delicious!!!  Ambiance is nice...plan on returning...
author: Melanie Z.

description:
I really felt like I was in a little Italian bistro walking into this place. It was small and antiquey looking. One of the cutest little alley-way restaurants I've been to. 

The food was good, not amazing, but enjoyable. I had the mahi mahi which tasted a little flavorless, but it was alright. 

The waiter was very helpful and nice. He made a big effort to be sure we were comfortable with our meal. But, he wasn't annoyingly vigilant. 

I'd come back, but it wouldn't be the first place on my mind.
author: Jon C.

description:
Came here with family including our two young daughters. Discovered the following:
1) the food is very good,
2) the service is slow,
3) the wine prices are exorbitant (none under $40, most over $80; and since they carry seemingly 100's of wines, I can't understand not having some wines that are more reasonable),
4) and if you bring children, they'll be charged $12 for a bowl of penne with butter and cheese.
I didn't want to dislike Cafe Tiramisu because the food is very good, however, the experience was frustrating and overpriced.
author: Robert H.

description:
YUM.  I am guessing I now have been to a true Italian restaurant.

In addition to the standard french bread and yummy pesto dipping sauce, we had for appetizers: the calamari and some oysters.  The oysters were divine, and came with two little sauces that were both really good.  Calamari though I thought was fried, wasn't.  (I guess I need to read my menu more carefully.).  It was stuffed though with a creamy sauce and served on top of bread.  Yummy.  

Entree-wise we had risotto and a rigatoni.  Both were delicious.  The risotto was the perfect amount of creaminess and flavor and the beef rigatoni was a hearty complement to the bottle of wine the waiter had recommended.  

You can't go to a restaurant named Cafe Tiramisu without ordering the tiramisu, which though we were full, we didn't regret ordering.  It was the best ever!!  

Not really a tourist trap: there are some, but also tons of locals, and during the week, lots of people that work in the financial district downtown.  

Service was impeccable and food was great.  Add that to dining outside on a leisurely Saturday evening, and you can't go wrong.
author: Denise B.

description:
We went to Cafe Tiramisu for a team lunch and the overall dining experience was pretty awesome.

We sat outside since it was a pretty nice sunny day and not too cold.

For starters, we had:
- Mozzarella & Tomato - Yummy Mozzarella, super fresh, soft, and bouncy.  Delissshh
- Crab cake - it was alright.... I had better crab cake before...  Not enough crabmeat or something
- Mussels in Saffron-Fennel Broth - great delicious sauce!  Large portion for the price, but the mussels are a little too soft for my taste.
- Artichoke blossoms - pretty good, wasn't that memorable.

Entrees:
- I had the Lobster Ciopinno, and there was really a lobster in there! (half)  The lobster was delish!  The sauce was great!  Very generous amount of seafood - scallops, shrimps, clams, mussels, fish.  And for the price of $20, it's a great deal!
And I had a taste of:
- Black Peppered Seared Ahi - done the way it supposed to be.  Black pepper ahi pan seared to perfection
- Caesar Salad -Fresh Dungeness Crab Meat & Chile Croutons - for $13, it's awesome.  Fresh crab meat on top of refreshing caesar salad, yum!

Desserts - we shared:
- Tiramisu - IT WAS DELISHHH!  tiramisu in thin chocolate box, yum!  
- Trio of Creme Brulee - very very good, wasn't too heavy.  I liked the cherry and mandarin flavor lots.  Don't really care about the lemon one
- White Peach Tart with Vanilla Ice Cream - pretty good, nothing EXTRAODINARY to rave about though
- Warm Chocolate Cake with Hazelnut Sauce and Ice cream on the side - omg, the sauce is delicious! I have a feeling they made the sauce themselves!  I love the hazelnut flavor, soo sooo sooooo good.

Yep, well deserved 4 strong stars!
author: Gigi T.

description:
Two stars earned for good rustic Italian food, tasty desserts and a very nice birthday song. 
     That being said, the manager at this restaurant needs a serious lesson in hospitality.
