After waiting an unacceptable amount of time for entree orders to be taken (first courses over half finished with LARGE menus still on our laps), and after waiting equally as long for drinks, I finally said something to the manager who was also doubling as our server for some reason. Order was then taken, but over the course of the meal the manager repeatedly approached the host of our party and very condescendingly commented on how I was "confused" over the timing and dining experience and essentially apologizing for MY behavior. 
     At the conclusion of our meal, I said something(granted not very nice) to him as I walked out the door. He proceeded to follow me out and try to explain how I was WRONG about all the problems I had with our service. A bastardized quote is "If you want timely service, come for lunch" Not once was an apology issued for our bad service and his unacceptable behavior. 
     As someone who spends their career working in the high-end food service industry, I can tell you that almost every night I have a table unhappy about their service, and whether they deserve it or not I apologize profusely, treat them like gold and abide by the notion that the customer is always right.This is clearly a lesson that the manager of Tiramisu needs to learn. And soon.
author: roger t.

description:
Went here with my co-workers for lunch today. Pretty damn good I'd say. I HIGHLY recommend the dessert sampler. Awesome!!

I had the sand dabs for my entree, which was not bad. I do like my sand dabs a bit crispier.

The crabcake wasn't fantabulous, but the sauce that went with it was pretty good.

The other girls had the ahi tuna which they raved over, and the one guy we were with had the sea bass which he hated because the green olives it was served with overpowered the taste of the fish.
author: Jessica O.

description: I really like this place. I ordered the Chicken. It was very juicy and plentiful. The plate came with two pieces of chicken, delicious roasted potatoes, and veggies. It was really good. I couldn't finish so I ended up packing the other half to go.... (and then throwing it away bc i didnt end up eating it).... Pretty decent. I think i'll be back!
author: Linda P.

description:
Not vegetarian friendly. Italian is so easy to make vegetarian and yet nothing on the menu was meat-less or seafood-less. 
I was hoping for outside seats however it looked like it was reserved for large parties.  And sure enough we were lead toward the inside of the restaurant toward the corner area right in the middle of an older couple and an older aged group. I don't know if my hair was out of place or did I have something stuck in my teeth but they kept staring over at us.  Either that or they were out of town and they've never seen asian people. I don't know so I was extremely irritated when I normally wouldn't be b/c when I'm hungry my fuse is shortened.
Anyway, back to the restaurant. Service was extremely slow that night. We waited nearly an hour for our food to arrive and when it finally did, our neighbors with the staring problem was at it again. I know when you're sitting at a restaurant you look over and check out the food that others nearby order but these people were STRAIGHT gawking. We later found out why they were staring when we got our food. They were seated earlier than we were however they were not served their food and those poor people were probably starving. I already felt like it took an eternity for us to get our food. As soon as we devoured and paid for our food those people were just getting served their order. WOW.. I'd probably would have walked out by now. 
Anyway, my buffalo mozzerella salad and my seafood pasta with the seafood on the side ended up being just alright. Nothing exceptional but our waiter was great which is why I'm granting this place an extra star.
author: Esther A.

description:
Fun spot for a lively lunch during the work week! I really enjoy lunching in Belden Lane every now and then. Get there early (like 11:30AM) if you don't want to get rushed... my group did and left right when people started lining up for tables. 

Service is friendly/efficient... food is good for the value... if only I could order a glass of red wine during lunch (but I've got this annoying work thing that prevents me). BOO.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
We went to Cafe Tiramisu for a company luncheon.  The oysters were delicious and so were the salmon and beef carpaccio.  The main entree I ordered wasn't so good though.  It was the Ahi Tuna.  The tuna was a little dry.   However, I did get to sample other dishes like the beef short ribs and the pastas.  They were excellent.  The best part was the dessert!  We ordered the dessert sampler and everything was gone in less than 10 mins.   My top picks from the dessert sampler were the tiramisu, creme burlee, and the zuppa inglese ice cream!

Great place for large parties (as long as you made reservations) or small groups.  Convenient location if you work in downtown or if you want to come at night for a romantic dinner.
author: Anna L.

description:
While I'm sure there are better Italian restaurants in such a great city like San Francisco, I've found Cafe Tiramisu to be consistently good every time I've eaten there. I agree with other reviewers that the waiters can be rushed and a bit rude at times, but the food is always fresh and well seasoned. 

One time, when I dined alone one time outside, I started with an appetizer of thinly sliced prosciutto and figs. The weather was perfect and the gnochi that I ordered as my entree was sublimely paired with a great pinot noir recommended by the waiter. Since I am not a huge fan of big desserts, I finished off my meal with a couple of biscotti and a perfect Italian coffee. A perfect night!
author: Peter G.

description:
I went there for a restaurant review and it was an enjoyable experience.  We got a pasta dish, rabbit dish and a seafood dish.  The rabbit dish was the most enjoyable, followed by the salmon, and the pasta was the least favorite.  The reason for this was that the pasta had no flavoring and was a little overcooked.  The dessert was also very delicous, we had the small variety of desserts.
I highly recommend this restaurant and plan to go again soon!

P.S.  Sitting outside on a full-moon night is a nice bonus.
author: Adam S.

description: Came here with friends and the kids while visiting San Fran. We've been here for 9 days and eaten at many places. This Is by far the best dinner and lunch we have had. They make the pasta themselves. The sauces are excellent. The service is top notch. Our party had a variety of starters , pasta, meat and seafood entree and desert. Everyone was raving about the food. Good value. Good food, good service. Clean restrooms. We are heading back in 2 nights.
author: Scott J.

description:
Again, this is a place in the FiDi, where at lunchtime alot of people have lunch meetings!  I had a lunch "date/meeting" (I wish it were a date). with a BEAUTIFUL woman. We were going to discuss business stuff and get to know each other as well.  Service was efficient, food was excellent, and prices weren't ridiculous.  we both had the roasted chicken and it was JUICY, flavorful, beyond satisfying.  Will DEFINATELY eat there again! =)

2 Stars goes away for the server we had!  He seemed to wanna get us in and out of there quick!  We sat down, were handed our menus, and were brought water w/lemon and bread with dish of Olive Oil.  Good so far, but 20 second later the guy asked it we were ready to order...We hadn't even opened our menus up yet!  we told him we'll need some time and will let him know when we're ready.  We continued to talk business, and while talking I could see the waiter just staring at us, as if to say "c'mon, order already!"  So, I opened up the menu, and so did my company.  We then asked him suggestions and he suggested that chicken we ordered, which almost made up for giving us the sense of being rushed.  But overall, he seemed to rush us.  

I DID love the food, though, and will come here again!  The dessert looked great, but I wasn't in the mood.
author: Gio G.

description:
We always do lunch on New Year's Eve in the city and we try a new place to see if we'll come back in the new year.  Well, we will never be coming back here again, and definitely won't be recommending this place to any of our friends or family.  

First of all the service was horrible. Our waiter made eye contact with us several times but never came by... no water... no bread... nothing.  There were only 4 other tables in the entire place @ 1PM and the 3 tables were being serviced by another waiter who definitely seemed more attentive (made sure we got our tabasco sauce for the oysters when we couldn't find our waiter).  

So we ordered raw oysters and that was a big mistake-- when it came, it smelled like sewage...  and sure enough, the second oyster we had was bad-- it smelled like poop! and when we pointed this out (to one of the bus boys as our waiter was nowhere to be seen), and after a long wait, our waiter comes sauntering to our table, brings us 1 new oyster (offers no apologies) and says "What was wrong with it?  We just got the shipment today.  Who got the short end of the stick?" Unbelievable... 

Rissoto with blank ink and scallops-- you expect to get at least 2 or more scallops right?  Wrong.  This dish comes with one scallop cut in half (the scallop itself was good) but the rissoto was way too salty...  it needed more scallops!

We had high hopes for dessert but unfortunately the tiramisu wasn't anything to rave about. The only dish we had that was good was the mussels with calabrese pepperoncini (the sauce was great) but the whole time we ate it, we were paranoid we'd come across another rotten, putrified morsel...

There are so many wonderful Italian restaurants in the city-- don't waste your time or money here.  Unfortunately for us, we learned it the hard way:  the service is poor (our waiter was truly pompous and a big bully) and the standard of food just wasn't there...
author: Sunny K.

description:
I don't understand all these 4/5 star ratings.  This is by far the worst Italian food I've had in a while.  This restaurant is tourist trap that tries to gussy up bad food with colorful sauce squirts and liberal dustings of microgreens all over your plate.   

I was weary about this place to begin with but my friend had such a craving for Italian and she was in high heels, I decided to chance it anyway.  Per the yelp review summary, we both tried the risotto dishes.  I had the ahi tuna with spicy risotto and my friend had the black squid ink risotto.  If  Uncle Ben could make risotto, he evidently set up shop at Cafe Tiramisu.   The risotto was NOT creamy and rich, but tasted super chewy and grainy, like a converted rice would taste.  And the spicy sauce combination in my tuna risotto was just plain weird.  I can't say anything much better about the squid ink risotto.

By the way, the men's room at this restaurant was not working, so you had go down 2 store fronts to their "sister" restauant Taverna next door.  If Tiramisu's any indication of Taverna's cooking, I'd avoid Taverna too.

Skip this place and go to Plouf next door for some quality French.
author: Tom K.

description: All five diners in our group were VERY IMPRESSED with their entrees, salads, sides and dessert, which was some of the BEST TIRAMISU any of us (who have all been to Italy) ever tasted! The homemade bread was light and delicate tasting, and everything from the Petrale Sole, Grilled Salmon, New York Strip Steak to the Veal Scaloppini, was PERFECT! Salads were light and flavorful and the wines were excellent and reasonable. We the most personable, pleasant and efficient service and can't WAIT to return!
author: Loreli B.

description:
Been here three times for lunch and guess what?  Ordered the same thing THRICE.

"Sea food Mixed Grill over Roasted Shallots Mashed Potatoes & Lemon Caper Sauce" - $22

This basically comes with 3 major pieces.  One filet of whitefish (i think either trout or maybe bass), a filet of grilled salmon, and then one big ass cousin of a lobster (it's one of those BALCO steroid tiger prawns).   All looking like cooked over a open flame seasoned grill.  The marination on all three were light but seductive.  The whitefish had a touch of lemon, the salmon was great (though I hate salmon), and the prawn was delicious.  All on a bed of creamy mash and spinach.  You can actually taste the wood on the char points of the seafood - tasty.    See picture four in this yelp photo gallery.

From my ventures, my counterparts ordered other things, which I can briefly describe:

The mussels are yum.   But still standard issue.
The tasting trio of crab is very misleading - you get itsy bitsy size portions for $16... pass.
The Buffalo Mozzarella with Roasted Bell Peppers, Toasted Pine Nut and Prosciutto Di Parma is actually good - fresh, and large, i mean large portion - share with someone.
Pappardelle with Moroccan Spiced Lamb Ragout and Grilled Corn Pesto - looked like a stew with untied ribbons.
The crispy chicken looked pretty damn smoking.  Smoking meaning it was kinda charred and black.  But supposed it was very tasty.

I don't know.  But whatever the case, it always tastes good when it's paid by the company.

Oh, btw, if at all possible, request top side seating.  The room downstairs smells like a toilet.  That's because the tables are literally feet from the bathroom.
author: Isaac L.

description:
I really like this place.  I think it's because I love risotto and the risotto here is good.  

I've been here a couple times.  It's pretty fancy and quite pricey but I've always enjoyed the food, wine and company every time I've been.  I've had fun every time I've been here so I guess I like it.  I like the whole Belden Lane area though.  Eating outside in the cool San Francisco air.  What more can you except from life (except lots of other stuff).

Last time I went, our little group got everything from oysters, mussels (in saffron-fennel sauce), lobster cioppino (which included scallops, salmon and shrimps), veal and a bottle of chianti.  I liked it all but there are a few things to keep in mind:

(1)  I'm in the middle of a love affair with oysters so my opinion may be biased.  It was AWESOME!

(2)  I don't really know what either saffron or fennel are (I'm guessing they're herbs of some sort) but I liked the food.

(3)  Lobster cioppino was overall good.  I'm decent with seafood quality so my opinion on this point is not totally off the mark.

(4)  I know nothing about wine.  I like saying the word "chianti" but I couldn't tell it apart from a "cabernet sauvignon" (which I also like saying because it makes me sound cool).

In conclusion:  Yay! I'm a fan.  So speaketh Yelp.  So speaketh I.
author: Aron L.

description:
Sometimes winging it for dinner in the city can be fun, but sometimes overwhelming and hard to choose. Lucky for me I live close to the FIDI and was strolling down belden lane looking at menus trying to find a place with a good menu, nice ambiance, and an open table.

Lucky for me we finally managed to stumble upon Cafe Tiramisu, usually i wont eat italian since i work at an Italian restaurant in Nob hill, but the menu was different and interesting.

We ordered the black ink risotto to share - amazing!! I ordered seabass and my boyfriend ordered a pasta dish. Both were equally good, not amazing   but very enjoyable. The wine list is extensive, however we brought our own ( special occasion) and the corkage was $20. 

The reason for 3 stars instead of 4? The service! Ive been a server for 5 years so I am very understanding, however not being greeted for ten minutes... Then no hello, no personality at all-- not understandable. I asked about making a decision between two dishes and got a dismissive eyeroll. No one asked how our dinners were , and even though we were beyond polite, left 20 % and enjoyed our meal the service is what will probably keep me from coming back. I guess being young is cause for dismissal and bad service. 

So great food, awful service! You pick
author: Rach O.

description: Oh how I want to like you, Cafe Tiramisu! Awesome location, impressive menu, full and happy looking restaurant. We came here with some friends thinking it would be a good place for a variety of dietary restricted people. Ordered the gnocchi without panchetta....it came out with panchetta... ordered the squash blossoms...never came... asked for more bread for the table and was given an eye-roll before muttering the obligatory "yeah, sure". Didn't stay for dessert, didn't even entertain the idea of coming back.
author: Kalie M.

description:
Surprisingly, this place didn't suck.

I must confess that, touristy as it may be,  I do love the ink squid Paella at B44, so I never considered foregoing the tongue-blackening dish to try Cafe Tiramisu.  I've never heard anything fantastic about this place, but when I found out I had out of town family to entertain who were craving cioppino, including two kids, I decided to give it a shot. Tiramisu met our needs perfectly. Sitting outdoors was casual enough for the little guys, yet quaint enough for the grown up Minnesotans. Service wasn't at all notable and the price was reasonable. And get this, the cioppino was actually pretty damn yummy!
author: Michelle D.

description: Ooooh, we were steered wrong...a biz colleague told my husband that this was a locals hangout...I don't think so. There were a lot of tourists but then again, so are we! So I guess it makes it ok! Anyhow, our service/server was awesome! Just awesome! The food was average.....not bad...not out of this world. Heavy on the seafood dishes, not a lot of veggie choices. I wouldn't go back but I wouldn't tell someone else they shouldn't go.
author: Cassie P.

description:
Okay... so first things first, I had lunch at Caf Tiramsu with one of my favorite people AND (despite strenuous objections on my part) didn't even pay for my meal. So, right off the bat: great company, free. 

A meal has a long, long way to fall to trip my "Bad Time" meter after these kinds of framing details.

This said, I think I could have arrived with an entourage from the Republican National convention AND had to foot the bill and I still would have enjoyed my meal. 

Caf Tiramisu is in a cute little alleyway in the financial district which (at least at lunch time) is filled with little tables, umbrellas and old school waiters in white aprons.  It almost has that 1950s men's club feel (in a good way... you know, the way Taddich Grill does). It's wonderful little corner of the world on a long workday.

The seating is European, meaning the tables are long and you just sit where you can in the mix...which is actually pretty cool unless the guy to your left starts slurping his pasta or the guy to your right starts yelling at his buddy, both of which happened while we were there (my only complaint) .  I can't (and won't) fault a restaurant because the guys next to me never learned a thing from their mamas, but  seriously? My God. I would have been served my ass for breakfast if my grandma had seen me do either of those things.  

Anyway, the food was gorgeous and delicious... fresh fish, perfectly prepared pasta, flawless service and satisfying desserts.  Even the coffee was good.

It is definitely an expense account kind of lunch, so I would say it is more of a treat place...but worth it if you are up that way.
author: Shannon W.

description: Not bad. Could be four stars but dropped on service. I stopped in on a Tuesday night. Place was packed and after being seated waited ten minutes to be acknowledged. Ordered the veal scalopini with risotto and asparagus. Food came quickly and tasted good. Large portions priced somewhat above moderate. Great wines. Despite a rough start this place ended on a positive note. Would not RCA to come back anytime soon but glad I tried it!
author: Chuck K.

description:
I'm not really sure why I love this place so much.  It was one of the first restaurants I ever went to in San Francisco.  The whole little Belden alley way is just so cute with its string lights and sidewalk dining.  When you go to Tiramisu, you cannot leave without having the dessert plate.  It costs $7 per person (minimum 2 people) but you MUST have it...even if you are too full...you must!  

Cafe Tiramisu is best on a sunny afternoon because it can get a little chilly outside and the seating is best outside.  The restaurant also has really good ravioli at North Beach prices.
author: Tabatha Y.

description:
Yeah, I dig it.

They make a black ink risotto in a lobster bisque that is so ridiculous, you'll want to slap somebody!  Another favorite is the braised beef short ribs .... the lamb dish is spectacular too!

grand finale?  three words - dessert menu sampler.

ridiculous.  seriously.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I went in September and there was a little scuffle between the hostess and the manager... it was uncalled for.  Food was good... service ok, would I go back... not for awhile... another place with tainted memories.. scuffles in front of costumers are NOT cool!

Oh... the bathroom is located in the lower level... when you have had drinks and wearing heels because you wanted to look fierce... it seems so far away.... but it was clean...

Overall... it is a nice place, overpriced, it is Belden Ct.  So... it is convenient to the after work crowd.  You can go elsewhere and get superior food..
author: Amelia M.

description:
Located in cute Belden Place in the city, I  must hand it to this restaurant for its location.  Treated a friend here for his birthday the other night.  Really enjoyed the location with outdoor seating and the lively atmostphere.  Food was decent-  I enjoyed the bacon wrapped pork medallion with mashed potatoes, my friend tried the sea bass, and the birthday boy had the peppered seared ahi tuna...  that was good.

Service in my opinion was a little abrupt, but my company didn't seem to mind.   We ordered a bottle of merlot, but didn't notice until halfway through the dinner they had brought us the cabernet.  

Overall, I enjoyed myself with good food and good company.  I would return again, great for groups or a nice date  =)
author: Vickie Y.

description:
The food was delicious, but the service was...strange.  

I initially placed my order for a salad and a main course, but changed my mind a moment later when my friend ordered a different salad that sounded tastier.  I told the waiter I'd like to change my salad order (from mozzarella and tomato to beets and goat cheese, if you care) and he smiled and laughed and said, "i'm sorry, you can't have that.  there is no changing your order".  Or something along those lines.  I pouted a big cutesy fake pout and we sort of laughed and that was that.

When our salads came - sure enough I had the mozzarella and tomato.  DUDE WASN'T KIDDING!!  he wouldn't let me change my salad order!  I don't know if he just misunderstood what I was asking or if he was being silly but then forgot to actually change it or what - but we all just looked at each other cause it was the strangest thing ever.  Luckily the boys decided the mozzarella looked good and I got to share the beets with my gal pal.   But, um, WHAT?!?!  strange, right?

Anyhow, one of us had ordered a glass of wine that just never showed, and the waiter came rushing over asking, "Did you never get your wine???" when we were already done dinner, at which point we said, "no, we didn't, but nevermind".  He could have brought it anyhow and not charged us or something, but whatever - that part didn't bother me so much as the NEVER GETTING IT IN THE FIRST PLACE!

Ahem.

PS at one point during our meal a waiter (not our own) rushed by making a large loud sound in Italian that cracked us up with its resemblance to the sea lions at Fisherman's Wharf.  

The beef spare ribs and mashed potatoes were about the tastiest thing I've ever eaten in my life and the beets with goat cheese - delicious!  Beldon Place is, of course, as preciously adorable as always and they were one of the only places we could find in that whole part of town that would let us sit down for dinner at 9:45pm on a Wednesday night.
author: Sharon M.

description:
Overall: 4
Just like Italy, a can't miss when dining al fresco on a beautiful day.

Food: 4
Every dessert is amazing and not too big. Some great traditional dishes with some California ingredients adding a slight twist. As expected, a long wine list.

Service: 4
Italian servers and owners dishing out warm casual service.

Decor: 5
Outside dining can't be beat, so eat outside if you can.  On a brisk night the heat lamps will keep you warm enough.

Value: 3
It's hard getting a deal in the financial district but I certainly felt like I got my money's worth.
author: Roger H.

description:
One night I had an extraordinary meal (split down the middle with a friend):  a salad to start, a risotto as a second, and  a meat course (probably a filet mignon), with a glass of champagne to start, and an excellent bottle of Italian cab that wasn't cheap, but it wasn't horrifying.  One of my rules of dining is that most restaurants can't do most things all that well.  Choose simply, and choose meat (because it's hard to mess up a good cut of meat unless you cook it beyond edibility).  So I think that's why the meal was so good.  

My other forays generally have been at lunch, when I'm zipping downtownish for lunch with my downtown friends, and on two other occasions, for dinner.  Not so good.  Not bad, just . .. not great.   When I prefer my Tenderloin meals, not because they are inexpensive, but because they are truly good, well, that causes me to question many of my fancier dine-out experiences.  So on a nice day, outside?  I'm sure if you select something simple, you can have a good meal.  Otherwise, there are other much better places to go.
author: Laurel B.

description: Cafe Tiramisu is a must stop for me when I visit San Francisco. Thanks to my buddy John M for taking me the first time. The food if excellent my favorite gnocchi anywhere. Be sure to bring a jacket and eat in the Belden Alley its the only way to experience the place. I took my wife here to celebrate our 15th anniversary.
author: Shawn R.

description:
Apart from the great atmosphere of Belden Lane and pleasant decor of this restaurant, I wouldn't say this is one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  It is certainly not the best Italian place, but just OK.

I'd advise against being seated in the basement seating area.  Although the decor is nice (it used to feel like you're in a wine cave, if that's attractive to you...) we were extremely turned off by the sanitized air freshner smells emanating from the nearby restrooms.  It got old after a while---people would come down the stairs, look around, and we were in direct line of pointing them to the restrooms.

Take non-foodie guests here from out of town for the Belden Lane experience, but when looking for a cozy and romantic dinner for two, keep looking...
author: Penny P.

description:
It has been a really, really long time since I've eaten here -- so long it's probably not very cool of me to even write a review.  Oh, well.

My memories are of a beautiful spring evening sitting at a table out in the Lane, feeling like I'm in Europe or something, loving the food, the wine, and the company.  Every night should be like that, yes?
author: Jim C.

description: Food was good but service is another story.   Our waiter hounded us about what we wanted and would not stop talking.  It took my father, who I only see once a month, about 10 minutes to order because our waiter kept questioning him like he commited a crime.  Food was ok not as good as I thought.  Bottom line I would not come back to this restaurant.
author: Matthew T.

description:
I was hesitant to take my mom here the other night because of the heavy tourist population, but she really liked Belden Place and wanted Italian... So, Cafe Tiramisu it was. We had a nice time and enjoyed the food. My mom had the sea bass, which she said was great, and my aunt had the short ribs, which are HUGE. The risotto was ok, but I probably wouldn't order it again. The veggie options were not very extensive.

The service was nice, although quite a bit slow. It was a Thursday night, so it was pretty busy. The alley way is great for evenings. This is a great place to take relatives from out of town for lunch or dinner, but the seating is way too jam packed and you sit shoulder-to-shoulder with the other diners. I think the prices are a bit too high for what you get, but I guess you are paying for the atmosphere and they are targeting tourists. Alli in all, its cute and the food is decent.
author: Syd V.

description:
For our anniversary, Mr took me to Cafe Tiramisu.
It was cold and drizzling Saturday night and the place was packed.

We had a 8 PM dinner reservation and we didn't get seated til almost 8:20 PM. The hostess lacked hospitality, she could of apologize for us waiting in the cold but she kept on ignoring us. As you can see, I had become one angry Asian girl. But for the sake of my bf I kept my cool. 

As we walked in the restaurant, we were seated in the basement on the base of the stairs (were all the patrons that needs to use the bathroom and waiters running up & down, it's a bit daunting - I literally have a picture of a waiter landing in our table) . Wow, what a romantic setting they placed us in.  On top of that we got stucked listening to one drunk girl who's loud, cursing  and obnoxious, she was a teacher mind you. Right next to our table was a mom and 2 kids.

I am so glad though that at least their food made up for the lack of service. Not even the customary glass of water was given to us, we have to asked twice. When we finally rcvd our water, one glass had hair in it. 

Mr went ahead ordered a bottle of Sangiovese to calm my ass down. 

For dinner:
Venison Carpaccio "Alla Rossini" 
with Foie Gras & Black Truffle $18

Ravioli with Dungeness Crab 
& Potato,Saffron, Crab Bisque & Caviar $19

Sand Dabs over a Bed of Artichokes, 
White Wine Sauce, Balsamic Reduction $24

and we had Tiramisu for dessert. The food was delicious. I give them that. so my verdict on Cafe Tiramisu, just go there eat, do not expect A+ service coz you are not going to get it.
author: jubi l.

description:
My hubby and I recently lunched here.  I remembered the caesar salad with crab from a previous visit and wanted to come back for another taste.  We shared the beef carpacio, caesar salad with dungeness crab, pan seared ahi over risotto, and warm peach tart.  The salad was as I remembered, crispy, creamy, crabby, and delicious!  The ahi was done just right (seared and still rare) and the risotto was very tasty.  The peach tart was beautifully presented (we had to take a picture on our phone) and yummy!

We sat at a table inside the restaurant, which was nice and much roomier than being packed in with everyone outside.  Plus we were able to enjoy our own conversation (not everyone else's).  The service was good and the staff was friendly.  I will definitely return again for my favorite caesar salad and next time we're trying the dessert sampler!
author: Angela O.

description:
This eatery is in a quiet little alley around all the good stores.  The walls are Pompeii-esque and the cafe is run by authentic Italians.  

There is a lot of room outside the cafe.  Inside is kind of tight but comfy.

I recommend the "brick" chicken, which is so tender and juicy.  The chocolate gelato and souffle and hazelnut soup (or on their menu, hezelnut) are so rich and yummie.  You can't go wrong.
author: Gina E.

description:
Great Atmosphere. Super cute cafe with a feeling of Europe. Great people whatching area. Food was ok. 

We had Raw Oysters - ok
Mussels in Saffron - YUMMY
The Dessert sampler - ok

The best part was the Saffron sauce soaked up with the bread, but they took the bread and bowl away before we had a chance to finish. We felt just a bit rushed even though they were not trying to turn tables over. It was late in the afternoon and not crazy busy at all.

I would definity go back again as I enjoy the atmosphere.
author: Sue Ann M.

description:
I can't get full on five truffle raviolis...I'm a small portion eater and I was no where near full.  I even ate a salad before.  They were really good though...maybe i just wanted more.

But anwyays, It sucks when an entree doesn't make you full.
Whats the point if I'm not full, especially when you spent $20 on one dish.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Here's the rundown:

Don't get the lemonade; its water with bits of lemon juice with little to no flavor. Do get the mussels, but be wary, a full order will fill up a party of two before the main dishes are served. The short ribs melt off the bone. The tiramisu - the cake soaked in alcohol. Nice! If you eat in the inside, it gets a bit cozy.
author: Judy L.

description:
I was really unimpressed. The food was okay, but not great. That in and of itself was not enough to earn a 2-star rating.

During my meal one of the resident roaches was kind enough to pay a visit to my table. The host was kind enough to quickly come over and snatch the offending roach off my table with a napkin. The fact that he barely batted an eye upon doing so led me to believe that this was not the first time such a thing had happened.  He assured me that there were no roaches in the kitchen.

No kitchen is perfect, but I expect them to at least bat an eyebrow when a roach crawls on your table. The rest of my meal was very blah and it took forever to get the check.

Judging by other people's scores, I hope this visit was an anomaly. There are much better restaurants in Belden if you are in the mood for eats.
author: Charles H.

description:
First, keep in mind that I came here for a work lunch that my firm paid for, so I may have had a slightly different take if I had actually forked over cash for the meal myself. I thought it was really good. I ordered the orichette with white beans and mussels. The mussels were huge and very tasty, and the pasta was very good, but could have used a little more tangy taste; maybe some lemon juice or parsley would have added to it. The tiramisu is awesome! It had just the right amount of cake to cream/liquor ratio. Maybe I'm crazy, but I thought it was some of the best tiramisu I've ever had! They served it with generous pieces of dark chocolate around the edges, too. Yum!
We sat inside. If I return, I'll definitely want to sit outside...Belden Place is cool.
author: Jenny R.

description:
I went to Cafe Tiramisu for lunch. Ordered a salas, appetizer and a main dish. The Salad was amazing with just the right dressing. The appetizer had mozarella de bufalla which is made from buffalo milk instead of cow milk so it tasted great. 

The entree took forever and we finally got bored and left. I wish they were a little more sharp and quick... but the food was amazing. Beware that the portions are not "Olive Garden" sized.
author: Soham K.

description:
We came here on Saturday to celebrate our good friends upcoming marriage. It was very cozy which made it feel like we were really in Italy.
Everyone we are with throughly enjoyed their meals and everything I tasted was great.
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Pretty good. The food was delicious. I had the black pepper seared ahi, which came on a bed of risotto and some mild miso sauce. 
I was told that the gnocchi tasted definitely machine made (vs handmade) but the sauce was good.
The lava in the chocolate lava cake was great, as was the accompanying hazelnut ice cream. The service was fine.
author: Rennie L.

description: I saw poor reviews, but Belden Place is wayyyyyyyyy cool and I had a great dinner as well as my party....It is not cheap, but warm, cozy and great food.
author: Steve C.

description: The sand dabs were pretty good, with artichoke hearts.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Came here for dinner on a nice Thursday evening and couldnt have been more pleased.  The outdoor seating reminds me of little italy in NYC.  There are several other Italian restaurants so it was hard to choose which one to eat at but cant complain about this restaurant.  The ambiance is great and I am coming back this weekend with friends who are in town and the following weekend to take my mom and sister. Food is good, smaller portions that expected but tasty and the service is attentive.
author: Mookie L.

description:
Belden place is adorable in its size. Blink as you drive past and you've missed it. So I felt as if I found some sort of niche in San Francisco that no one else had explored.

Wrong. Belden Place can get pretty crowded. I do love how the restaurants have chairs and tables spilling out into the alleyway. The ambiance and charm of Belden Place is inescapable.

Cafe Tiramisu fits perfectly into Belden Place. My group of 8 was squeezed inside, near the tiny kitchen. (Honestly, we marveled at how they must be very efficient with their serving/cooking skills with such a small space. 

For the amount of food we got, I felt like it was a bit overpriced. My ravioli contained about five (semi) large pieces of pasta in a (semi) spiced creme sauce. The bread appetizer left me more fulfilled.

For dessert, we each ordered our own creme brulee, based on the sizes of our entrees. Mistake. The desserts were bigger than the meals! We easily could have shared the dessert between two people. 

So, while the ambiance and the idea of Belden Place seems attractive, Cafe Tiramisu did not deliver. Instead, just walk down the alley, take a picture of the lights and find a decent place to eat, instead.
author: Bryan B.

description:
If you need a choice for a romantic anniversary dinner, consider this. Tucked into Belden place, together with a few other bistro-style eateries, it's like a mini-version of a European sidewalk restaurant street. If your girl likes Europe (who doesn't), you've already scored some brownie points.

The interior adds emphasis to Tiramisu's European/Italian theme. The walls are painted to look like antique marble, and there are faux-marble facades everywhere to remind you of Rome. At nighttime, the conversation is noisy and lively in a warm, comfortable way without being intrusive. If your girl likes Italian, more brownie points.

Girlfriend and I had the black risotto with scallops as first course, roasted quail and sand dabs for entrees. Sand dabs were slightly disappointing because usually they are buttery rather than dry, but the quail was excellent--crispy, sweet, and succulent.

This place also gets kudos for service. The waitress/manager gave us two glasses of champagne "on the house," and the waitress was very attentive throughout the evening.
author: Richard Z.

description:
Along with its sister restaurant Brindisi at the end of Beldon Pl., Tiramisu is one the few first rate Italian restaurants in S.F. 
While most S.F. Italian dining establishments are virtually interchangeable, as are their menus, Tiramisu consistently offers surprising and sometimes even adventurous choices which are always delicious and thoughtfully designed. The waitstaff is always congenial and good humored and it is rare when one of the owners is not on site to welcome customers and supervise the quality. Highly recommended especially when the weather allows for al fresco dining.
author: Dr. B.

description:
My girlfriend and i had a gift certificate, so decided to go out for dinner on a Friday night. We were a little worried it would by touristy but were pleasantly surprised.

I had the squab wrapped in grape leaves with pumpkin risotto (served in a small pumpkin). The pairing was great, and the flavors really complemented each other.

My gf had the duck ravioli, which was also excellent, with a hint of orange in the sauce that was too delicious to resist sopping up with the bread (which wasn't impressive although the dipping sauce was great)

The tiramisu itself was pretty good (not extraordinary), but overpriced at $10/slice

The ambiance was interesting- outdoors with xmas lights above it was romantic but we were packed in like sardines next to our neighbors.

A little pricey, but a good date restaurant
author: Chris  F.

description:
I'm tempted to award five stars because for me, unless a service experience is disastrous, FOOD is really the key factor.  However, I should mention that this place can be raucous which is sometimes due to the hosts/hostesses taking extended time to seat diners.  For this reason alone, I can't extend five stars.  (However, '5' stars is silly; Michelin awards a maximum of 3.)

Peter G; no in terms of food, there probably isn't a better Italian
restaurant.  And I'm sorry; I'm very skeptical of negative service 
reviews; there are, shall I say, a lot of 'flighty' people come to Tiramisu and I wager those are the people who perceive bad service.  Folks; if the server is terrible, get the manager, a great guy and tell him you want another server.   (This will probably never come up but if it does ...)  My final word on service; there are some native Italian waiters who are well, Italian, not American and they are of course from another culture.  In the common language of good food however, there will be an accommodation.

Without fail- from venison to boar- to various pastas the food has been excellent to truly great in the years I've been going here, about eight.  (Deserts are also incroyable as are the cheese 'courses.')  

I can't really say more, yes, of an evening, (I've never eaten lunch) the place can be very loud indeed and as Frank Zappa observed San Francisco is infuriatingly "cute and hippern than thou," but that's hardly the fault of Cafe Tiramisu.

Superb, memorable food.
author: Allan C.

description: Tiramisu was a big disappointment.  The service was so slow we considered leaving.  The waitress seemed overworked and didn't apologize for the slow service at all.  Salads were wilted.  Main courses were okay, but we were so anxious to get out of there by that time it didn't matter.  Won't recommend it or go back.  There are so many other choices in that neighborhood!
author: cristina m.

description: One of the worst meals I've had in San Francisco. Pour food quality, noisy atmosphere, and inferior service with quite an attitude.
author: Philip N.

description:
Was here last night for a business dinner. We were a large group of approx. 12 people. We were seated right away. The host was very nice and we were able to get the downstairs area all to ourselves, which made the dinner quite enjoyable because we could talk about anything, be as loud as we wanted and we had plenty of space. 

In terms of the food, I have to say that while Italian food is wonderful, it's not my favorite due to the fact that everything involves too much pasta. It's just too filling for me. However, I must say that while this place has a small menu, the appetizers and courses were very tasty and the portions were not too big and not too small. 

Starters -- We had the following for the table: Blackened "Kobe Style" Carpaccio. Sauteed Dungeness Crab Cakes. Ahi Burschetta on Risotto Cake. I would pass On the Ahi, but the other two were very good. 

In terms of entrees. I am a big fan of minimal pasta dishes. So, I had the Cioppino (which I buy at Trader Joes all the time; it's wonderful). The waiter said the seafood is brought in fresh everyday at this place. Well, it was absolutely delicious, fresh and cooked to perfection. I couldn't finish it (generous portion). I recommend it for those trying to ease up on the carbs and those who love seafood and tomatoes. 

Others at the table had the Ravioli w/Roasted Eggplant. They liked it very much. And someone had the Gnocchi with meat sauce. She said it was good, but again very generous serving--good for two. 

Desert --We tried Yogurt Panna Cotta. Wonderufl! I recommend this. Light and rich at the same time with fresh fruit. A great finish. The table also ordered the Warm Chocolate Cake w/Hazelnut ice cream -- pass. 

Lastly, wine.. we had a Pinot Grigio and Pinot Noir. I didn't taste the Grigio as I am not a fan of white wine. But, for the Red, we had one from Sonoma (sorry can't recall the name). It was excellent. 

I'd come here again for the Cioppino.
author: Becky O.

description:
What have they done with the Spanish place?

That's how we ended up at Cafe Tiramisu.  Belden place was crammed from wall to wall with mostly 20-something girls in discouragingly slutty dress (honey, you HAVE the goods, you don't NEED to package them like old sausage...).  

The hipsters were slinking by.  The waiters looking bored (lined up like gangstas against the bus station).  Hostess was polite and seated us right away.  Obsequious Sicilian with oddly Northern accent took the order, got it wrong, and forgot to bring my glass of wine.  Thank god my date was physically huge enough to be seen over the throngs gesticulating.  He's Sicilian too so hey - he's allowed.

Wrong Risotto but - quite good.  Overpriced.  Wine - too warm (aaaaack! you do NOT store wine under halogen bar lights!!! Jaysus!!!).  

Utterly charming atmosphere - even with the throngs of silly kids.  Harmless little dears having fun.  Could have used a few myself to help bus the table and bring my wine.

I'd do Belden Place again for sure - but on a week night that's warm.  Not weekend in summer.  Yikes!

As for Cafe Tiramisu in particular.  Pass.  The other reviewer who pegged it as touristy is right on.  Feels like one of those places in Venice that Rick Steves tells you to stay away from.  (Como se dice "clip joint?")
author: Juliana C.

description:
Cafe Tiramisu has 243 reviews before this one.  Do I have anything to say that hasn't been asserted, disputed or yawned at before?
Probably not.
That should stop me but it won't.
Maybe it will stop you.  If so, no hard feelings.  Go with grace.  
Who's Grace?

The coolest thing about Cafe Tiramisu is walking down the alleyway called Belden Place.  It has been closed off to traffic for years so its half dozen restaurants can expand into the outdoors, side by side.  
Early on a weeknight in February there aren't too many people to crowd in your way, so you can stop at each restaurant, read the menu and talk with their respective personage on the sidewalk.  These personages are stylishly dressed, articulate and attractive young women.  I'm not sure whether they are maitre d's, managers, hostesses, hawkers or harpies -- whatever they are, they succeed in making you feel you should pick one eaterie and eat there.
But wait, it's February and there's a chill -- so let's sit inside.  OK, inside at Cafe Tiramisu is old looking plaster-ish walls with 2-color fresco like Roman scenes.  Probably not real since we had a shortage of Roman invaders in San Francisco -- but close enough, if you don't look too close.

The Belding neighborhood is the cool part, the Cafe Tiramisu Roman motif is semi-cool, the food is OK and you get what you pay for.  Except downstairs.  The restroom does not meet ADA standard.
So, hold it.
author: Peter N.

description:
Terrible service. Hostess made us feel guilty for wanting to get only dessert (we wanted only dessert because the dessert menu looked good). The waiter didn't help us for like 10-15 minutes. They criticized us for only wanting desserts and we wanted more than 1 dessert and some wines. Waiters/hostess were really rude. Waiter didn't even help recommend a wine for our dessert. They may have even spit in our port. Treated us terribly. Ruined our night. Worst experience ever. We are pretty understanding when someone has a bad night but all the waiters and the hostess and manager didn't even want to serve us. DON'T GO HERE. THE FOOD IS NOT WORTH THE TERRIBLY RUDE SERVICE.

First, we were planning to spend just as much on desserts and wines as if we were to go there for dinner, but we already ate dinner and only wanted dessert. Second, I understand that some restaurants want customers to order more than just dessert or just a salad/appetizer or whatever, but if they don't want customers to do that then they should have a minimum amount per person (which they don't). They shouldn't have discriminated just because we didn't want dinner foods. They made us feel awkward and unwanted, when we were the customers.

The dessert on the otherhand was just alright, but the service totally killed the experience for us.
author: Breck O.

description:
ok so i LOVE the location, this is street is so European perfect for that "small street packed with tons of restaurants and people" feel... unfortunately unlike Europe this is not a cultural escape but more of a tourist trap. 
yea ok i might be a snob when it comes to food italian especially, but if you're a place like beldon representing the culture of europe in your restaurant style and street... why wouldn't u go the whole mile and represent the food properly as well?
anyway, i was disspointed with the food, it was like eating at olive garden for 3x the price, was the location worth it? maybe? but i def wont go back to eat again... maybe just some drinks and good company.
author: Shadi N.

description: My wife and I enjoyed a nice evening here!  The cioppino is was absolutely remarkable! For desert we shared the tiramisu and found out why they named the cafe after it, to die for!  I highly recommend Cafe Tiramisu especially for couples looking for a romantic, quaint and delicious experience in San Francisco.  It's location in Belden Place is like walking down a cafe-filled narrow street it Italy.  Just an all around great place!
author: Kevin B.

description:
I had a huge dinner party at Cafe Tiramisu for my birthday.  The service was fantastic! They even gave me my own private room downstairs for no additional charge.  With a party of 25, we obviously did not make the reservation time, but they happily waited.  Parking is a little tough but there's a parking lot that isn't too expensive.  I had crab cakes and oysters for the appetizer, which were pretty good.  For dinner I shared the rotisserie chicken, lobster ravioli and veal.  The veal was actually my favorite.  

If on a date, I suggest sitting outdoors. Its really cute
author: Joanne H.

description:
Great place!  This is a 5 star dining experience!!

My good friend took me to this restaurant to celebrate my birthday.  I was a bit apprehensive given the recent reviews, but fortunately someone in our office had gone to this place and raved about the ambiance, food, and service.

We could have dined on the patio, but chose an inside table.  The place was packed but I felt very comfortable with the size of our space.  The seating was comfortable and our conversation was in no way impaired by other diners.  The interior of Cafe Tiramisu includes frescoes, sculptures and other decorative features that inspired initial conversation as well as giving comfortable feeling of good things to come.  

The waiter was quick to take our drink order then gave us time to check out the incredible menu.  There was so many interesting dishes that we needed more time to review our choices. Our waiter had extensive knowledge of the menu and made recommendations in which we were in agreement.

When the food came, we were like, "Oh you have to try this ..."  Yum!

We will be back - this is a great place for business, celebration, and general merriment.  We both loved this place - outstanding!!
author: Jeff B.

description:
Its Valentines Day. I had been drooling over the menu at Cafe Tiramisu for months because I just happened to notice them on OpenTable and it looks sooooooo good. So I made a reservation for this special night and found a hotel close by (The Executive Hotel Vintage Court http://www.yelp.com/biz/executive-hotel-vintage-court-san-francisco#hrid:iiS_EE6i0H3H18UQNFJnHQ) and booked a room at the last minute. 
So we walk from the hotel, which is just about a 3 block walk downhill. 
When we get to the restaurant we come up to the patio entrance where there is a hostess standing outside of this giant plastic cover thing that encloses the entire patio area. The hostess tells us she has a seat for us outside. She unzips the plastic thing and brings us into the patio area (which seems nicely heated) and walks us to a table that is right up against the plastic. 
Ok fine. Then she seats someone next to us, and since the tables are packed in soooo tight this basically means she might as well say "this couple will be joining you for dinner this evening." 
Ok fine. So after a few minutes the waiter comes over. He has such a thick Italian accent I can barely understand him. We order two glasses of wine (two of the SAME wine- seriously, we were making it easy for him) and an appetizer (I cant exactly remember what). Ok for the record, I HATE when the waiter or waitress doesn't write anything down. I seriously hate it. It stresses me out. I get anxiety thinking they are going to mess this up but sometimes they surprise me and its all ok. This guy? Yeah who knows. He was gone for about 20 minutes, then came back and took the order of the people next to us. No wine for us, no appetizer. 
Ok, fine. A few more minutes go by. He comes over with the wine for the people next to us and then steps over to our table and looks at us blankly. 
"Uh..." he says. Yep nothing. Nothing going on up there in that head. I remind him that we ordered wine and an appetizer. He asks me which wine and which appetizer, so I tell him. 
He runs back to the kitchen. 20 minutes later our wine arrives. He tells us there is something wrong with the computer and runs off again. 
I'm slightly irritated at this point, but its the plastic cover thingy that's more annoying that the waiter, because I am freezing my butt off next to this thing. I'm wearing the most adorable dress with a sweater over and ex bfs jacket over my legs to keep from hypothermia. I'm little ok? No meat on these bones! lol 
Alright so the appetizer never came. We finally flag the man down and order our dinners, because at this point we are starvatious. He takes the order and leaves without time for us to ask about our appetizer, but we are so over it at this point. The people next to us are eating their entrees. A few minutes later, here comes Mr. Ding Dong Waiter again. 
"Uh... uh... you uh order uh..." he says. 
I remind him AGAIN of what we ordered. We are trying to make conversation, and trying not to think about our grumbly stomachs, when 10 minutes later the waiter comes back. 
"So sorry, your order?" CONFUSION look on his face. 
This is when the guy sitting at the table next to us says "He ordered the gnocchi and she ordered the risotto!" lol 
Waiter looks in shock. 
"Oh sorry sorry something wrong with computer..." as he runs away again. 
We finally get our food when the people next to us are finishing their desserts. In my opinion, the food was EXCELLENT, but the service was insanely bad. Took us another 30 minutes after we were finished and our plates had been taken for us to get the check, and we were never offered coffee or dessert. Totally ridiculous. 
Thanks for the worst Valentines Day dinner EVER Cafe Tiramisu. Could have been a great experience. Good food plus beautiful atmosphere, why oh why did that server have to screw it all up?
author: Tori E.

description:
We stopped by this Belden Alley "trap" on a Friday evening after an afternoon of shopping around Union Square.  I work nearby and some coworkers had good things to say.  The dinner rush had yet to develop and we had our choice of the outdoor seating.  The seating outside can be a bit cramped, but focus on your date across the table and do not throw any elbows.  We were warmly greeted and our server was quick with the drink orders.  I had a glass of Chianti Riserva, which may or may not have been overpriced, but was certainly on par with any other restaurant in the city.  We had a moment of apprehension when we discovered the water tasted like it had been mixed with flat Sprite/7-UP.  The replacement glasses were fine.

I was not particularly hungry, having gouged at lunch at Nordstrom.  I committed the faux pas of only ordering a single course.  My wife, more considerate of Italian custom, indulged in a mixed greens salad with a citrus dressing.  "It was o.k."

The bread was fresh and the olive tapenade was habit-forming.

We were most impressed with our entrees.  The wife went for broke and ordered up the beef short ribs.  Cooked to perfection, the meat fell away from the bone like France from international relevance.  I tried to keep things somewhat light and sampled the pappardelle with mushroom and wild boar ragout.  My first wild boar.  I was happy.  The meat was like sweet sausage.  The pasta, if not made in-house, tasted like fresh-made.

We skipped dessert, not falling for the $9 tiramisu, tempting as it was.  We settled for coffees at Starbucks, which cost $39.95.

Having limited ourselves to Italian fare at Milano on Russian Hill, we were pleasantly surprised to find a downtown alternative.  The service was excellent and attentive.  This was a good experience.  Solid.

Price tag for one glass of wine, one appetizer, and two entrees:  $72 (with tip).
author: Daryl E.

description:
Walking into this place made me want to brush up on Italian - and I'm not just speaking about my language skills ... ;)

Everything from the decor to the wait staff to the food selections and wine pairings - authentic Italian!  From the outside, Belden looks like a typical tourist trap - bright twinkling lights, cheap tables and chairs lined beneath even cheaper umbrellas, hostesses soliciting your patronage flashing menus, etc...  Nevertheless, Belden, and most importantly Cafe Tiramisu are fabulous and delectable dining experiences!

As we walked down the narrow restaurant to a table nestled in between two tables of two (we were a loud table of 4, okay maybe I was the only real loud one), we quickly realized we were in for a treat.  We were greeted quickly by one of many waiters asking to get us started with a nice bottle of wine.  Our waiter, looking a lot like Giovanni Ribisi, made a wonderful recommendation on a nice Italian red - surprisingly was inexpensive at $54.  

We started with the Beef and Salmon Carpaccio - both wonderful with very unique and delicious flavors.  I had the Risotto with half lobster:  not as rich as expected, which was graciously appreciated and oh-so yummy!  Being the prima-dona that I am blamed at being, I asked the waiter to take the lobster meat from the shell for me - he didn't even flinch and quickly returned with what looked like the equivalent of meat from a prawn, but nonetheless, made it easier for me...  Being at Cafe Tiramisu, we HAD to try the Tiramisu - very light and full of flavor.

We probably overstayed our welcome as we started into a few sales v. marketing battles (I won of course), two bottles of wine emptied and the table cleared... 

I am looking forward to coming back and enjoying the ambiance during a less rainy night - you know, taking in some of the chintzy twinkling lights under the outdoor umbrellas while sipping a fine Chianti... Gratzi! ; )
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description:
Worst Black Ink Risotto that I've ever had. $12?! What a farce. 
My Veal Scaloppini was mediocre. I also tried the Sea Bass which was way over-cooked. To top the night off, one of my Italian-speaking friends warms the waiters up to giving us a "complimentary" bottle of wine for the table. To our surprise the check came back with the wine surcharge. At that point the waiter said "No worries, just cross out the old total and write in the adjusted one." Low and behold a few weeks later, I notice the surcharge still on my credit card statement. Bastardio, siete molto ingannevoli! I'm getting distraught just trying to finish this review. The only nice thing was the cozy little Belden Place atmosphere which you can get at any of the restaurants up this alley. I'd highly recommend B44 instead.
author: Tom B.

description:
My visit to Cafe Tiramisu happened to be a beautiful sun-laden day, which meant, of course, that sitting outside was an absolute must. The lunch was a catch-up semi-working lunch and the atmosphere was completely conducive to our needs. 

The menu is a bit on the limited side and the appetizers are not really meant to share. However, every meal at our table of 5 looked great and there were nothing but clean plates to be found after the meal. I had the Ahi tuna over Lobster Risotto was truly excellent. I will go back just to get the same lunch! 

It was only after the lunch that I found out that the Belden alley is famous!
author: Charles B.

description:
I LOVE Tiramisu. When my boyfriend and I lived in San Francisco, this was our go-to spot for romantic dinners and special nights. I had been to Pleuf (also excellent) with co-workers, but wanted to try out another restaurant in Belden Place, so my boyfriend and I went here after our first major date together. 

Like all the restaurants in Belden Place, you have the choice of outdoors seating (usually heated by heat lamps) or indoors, and at times you may feel that the outdoor seating is a little cramped. I prefer to think of it as cozy, myself, and generally don't mind it. 

I have had so much delicious food at Tiramisu it is difficult to know where to start. They had for a delicious zucchini floweret appetiser I particularly loved, and their risottos were almost always flawless. (I'm a big risotto freak, btw.) Their caprese salad is simple but delish. But one of the things I love best is their dessert tray. You can get a sampling of nearly every dessert on their menu--there are usually seven or eight options at any given time--for about nine dollars a person. And since the desserts are so rich, the variety of the sampler tray lets you savor each dessert before you get overwhelmed with that particular flavour. 

I've generally had very good service from the Tiramisu people, and when we had to move out of SF, my boyfriend and I made a point of hitting Tiramisu one last time before we left. 

(I also have enjoyed Pleuf and Taverna among the restaurants of Belden Place, but Cafe Tiramisu is my fav.)
author: Lis M.

description: Came here for dinner while on a weekend getaway to SF. I was looking for a place that was not too far from where we where staying and it had decent reviews on yelp so I made reservations to this place. We got seated right away but it took sometime before our server appeared and get our order. Let's just say whatever the service was lacking in, the food made up for it, thankfully. I don't remember what the hubby got but I did enjoy my Risotto. We also got their Dessert Menu sampler to get a taste of everything. Boy was it good!
author: Ida M.

description:
Charming place for five girls to hang....before partying like Rock Stars!

Food was great, the steak and beef madallion dishes were exellent! 

Service was a little lacking....but still fair for a really busy Saturday nite,
 
I liked the energy of the place, decor, lighting, etc...nice and romantic for a little date. I could be going back. 

It's a little pricey - $86, pp but, we had drinks, appetizers, entrees, dessert and dessert wine....so all told it was typical dinning in San Francisco.
author: Kristina A.

description:
I was a bit unsure when my company chose Tiramisu as its location for a dinner of 30+ guests on its first night of an international conference in San Francisco.


 Having had more intimate dinners there before, I couldn't imagine what it would be like to have a throng of jet-lagged computer geeks jammed into such a cozy space. After all, what waiter enjoys serving such a monstrous group? And really, what business did our huge group have invading the quaint, European charm of Belden Place?


 I doubted, but Cafe Tiramisu delivered.


 The waitstaff somehow made it so our group didn't feel so damn large, providing prompt and attentive service. Despite the growing boisterousness among some guests, they never slowed down in bringing out the wine, grappa, and port to keep the party going. And the main attraction, the food, was excellent. Between the osso bucco primavera, the gigantic steaks, seared tuna, and brick-baked chicken, everything was top notch and well presented - and surprisingly served in great synchronization, which is no small feat for such a huge group.


 Based on their outstanding service alone, I give top marks to the place. The brick-baked chicken puts it over the top.


 Oddly enough, tiramisu is one of the few desserts I've never cared for, but the 30 others told me it was excellent.
author: Omid T.

description:
Great, great food. I had the seafood mixed grill, and was really happy with it. We also had the black ink  risotto and something with arugula (sorry, can't remember...) as appetizers, and all were impressive. Both appetizers had white truffle shavings, which can never hurt a meal (I know, truffles are so 2000, but I still love the mushroomy yumminess). 

The service, on the other hand, was weird (as evidenced by my 3.75 stars, rounded up to 4). For example, my water glass was almost never full (I'm a huge imbiber of the H2O), but when I returned to the table from the ladies' room, the maitre'd was there ready with my napkin to position it perfectly on my now seated lap. Also, they took absolutely forever to clear our table, and were in no rush to take our orders. Strange, right?

Overall, it was a good experieince. One warning, though, which you must take to heart: Do not, under any circumstances, accept a table downstairs. The musty basement smell is bound to ruin your meal.
author: Sahra H.

description:
I'd give this place 3.5 stars for nice ambiance and decent food.  The service is a bit lacking though.  

It's inside a really cool alley where a bunch of restaurants are located near the financial district.  There's a bunch of communal tables outside that make it a festive environment.  

My salmon was a little over-cooked but the veggies and sauce was good.  The service could be better as we had a wrong dish delivered to our table.
author: Hui C.

description:
My bon voyage party was here as a table of 10 for lunch. Had the crab cake starters. Not fantastic but well made. Sauce was a touch more salty than preferred and the crab cake was not intended as a 'sharing" appetizer. The Antipasti was delicious although the roasted bell peppers, not being a fan of them, were everywhere.  The main course, the salmon encrusted with a crab and pesto was tasty on top of a bed of wax beans and a very delicate flavored sauce from squash blossoms. The salmon was cooked quite right and was a perfect serving. 
Dessert was actually a clever departure. Not off the wall, but I ordered the molten chocolate (cup) cake, the scoop of gelato and all accompanied by a warm pureed hazelnut chocolate soup. That was a very key and nice approach. 

The house Pinot Noir was pleasant on the first bottle and a little less complex on the second. 

The service was excellent and very warm, and the weather matched.

As far as wine goes, I think I may start bringing my own to any restaurant and pay the corkage of $12-20... That would still almost be worth it.
author: Dave S.

description: AMAZING. I was simply stunned with every bite I ate at Cafe Tiramisu. My boyfriend took me here for a classy pre-Valentine's day dinner. His boss is a friend of the owners and surprised us by paying for the entire meal....lucky for us, because it is VERY expensive. I got the Pepper Crusted Ribeye steak and it was probably the best I've ever had. For the appetizers we had the fresh mozzarella with salad and prosciutto, as well as some buffalo cheese that I do believe was fried and combined with short ribs. It was INCREDIBLE. The waiter was very professional and took his job very seriously. It is a high-end place, and was also very crowded. I really enjoyed sitting outside, it made for a lively experience, and the musicians were entertaining. I wouldn't mind going back if I could afford to!
author: Katie S.

description:
I came on Saturday for dinner and thought to try without a reservation. I was all excited since the last time I was here the food was great and the service was wonderful. We were met by the host and she was not very nice. She kept trying to sell me a table outside even though it was freezing cold in the city and the wind was blowing. She told me it was under the heat lamps. That was not true cuz it was just partly under the heat lamps so only half of you was warm and the other half was cold. I wanted to sit inside but the top floor seems to be filled but they had empty tables downstairs which I didn't understand why she told me she didn't have any tables available inside. 

We finally got a table downstairs and out of the cold. End up ordering the Blackened 'Kobe Style' Carpaccio which I thought was alright, I was expecting it to be better since it had Foie Gras and Truffles in it. The Heirloom Tomato Salad was good and it came deconstructed. I end up ordering the Pappardelle which pretty much taste like Bonalese Spaghetti. My dining partner order the Orecchiette and that was better tasting than mine but a bit on the spicy side. Overall dinner was okay. I thought it would be better but dessert totally made up for it. We ordered Panna Cotta and well they ran out of the Vanilla one so we end up getting a White Chocolate one. Boy was it good and it literally taste like you were eating a bar of White Chocolate. We also ordered drinks too. The 7 on 7 is good here, it taste more like a mojito. My Cosmo was okay. Our waiter was very nice and attentive. I would come back but I think there seafood dishes are better.
author: Donna Y.

description:
On a recent visit to San Francisco from Rhode Island we asked the concierge at our hotel (SF Marriot) about a good local place for dinner. He recommended the Cafe Tiramisu on Belden Place. We had been to the same little alley the night before at a different restaurant.
It took a little while for us to get served, but when we did the manager himself took care of us. 
I have to say that the mussels in peppercini was insanely good. Probably the best I ever had.
My wife and daughter had the salmon which was coked to perfection and I had the pasta with swordfish and it was delicious.
We live in a place that has no shortage of Italian restaurants and this one was on par with the best of RI.
author: Lee K.

description:
The dinner here is very fancy schmancy, got the dim lights and outside seating. However, I have to give it a 3 stars because the food was not that great. Some dishes were good and some dishes weren't so good. The portion also varies as well, I think it's best to ask the waitress or waiter to see what dish offers more bang for the buck. I ordered the ravioli and ended up with 3 very small portions for $20+ which is crazy. 

If you are going here for the ambience, it's a great place, but I go to restaurants to enjoy the food, if I get shafted with 3 pieces of ravioli that's $20+ it's not worth 5 stars on yelp.
author: Chris L.

description:
This was the first restaurant I visited in Belden Place and I ate there for the 3rd time yesterday night.  The food was good but not as fantastic as I remembered but the service was excellent.  We had the crab cake w/arugula appetizer, which was served to us at the table.  It was very crabby, little breading, and spicy arugula.  For the main course, I had the salmon which was surprisingly moist and also flaky but not very flavorful.  My husband hand the steak with foie gras.  The steak was kind of tough but the foie gras was very good.  The touch of truffle gave it an interesting texture.

The dessert sampler is $9 per person, minimum of 2 people, and had 11 different samples.  My favorites were the pear tart, creme brulee, tiramisu, and ice cream in sugar shell.

Our waiter made a good choice of wine for me and was very attentive with removing our plates after finishing.  The food is a little pricey, each entree was $22, and the portions weren't very big.  If I have room for dessert, then the entree is small.  But the dessert sampler is the best since you get such a large variety.  If you ordered the regular desserts individually, they are $9 each so why not get the whole sampler if you don't know what you want?  The outdoor seating with heat lamps is nice too.
author: Jenn T.

description:
(3.5 Stars)  I have to go here a lot on business lunches and dinners.  Very cool ambiance and makes you feel like you are not in SF.  Nice warm days and nights, eat outside.  

IF the Osso Bucco is on the menu, order it, given that you don't have any political problems with veal.  Here they have a contemporary take on a traditional dish, and serve it on a bed of creamy polenta.  It is done very well.  The fish here is ok.  Much of the other stuff actually here goes from ok to pretty good, but the Osso Bucco was the most notable dish on the menu.

Update:  The seared Ahi with Spicy prawn risotto is amazing!
author: Kapeli M.

description:
I can't remember the last time I had a meal where I enjoyed every aspect of the meal. 

This restaurant is typical European when it comes to the service. The meals was long, the conversation was good, and the recommendations were excellent. Our waiter was straight out of Italy and recommended an excellent pairing of food and wine. 

Four of us went to dinner, and we all ordered different items. We all shared and all agreed we couldn't decide who had the best meal. After a lot of thought I decided my favorite was the seared ahi. It was to die for, and the shrimp risotto that accompanied it was the best I've had since I returned from Italy last January. In addition to the ahi, our table had the salmon (fabulous), the sandabs with asparagus (yummy), and steak (awesome). With so many great choices I suggest sharing.

The deserts were equally amazing, and I'm glad we saved room. Again, we each had something different, and all were equally as good!

This restaurant is on the pricier side, but every bite is worth it. I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Aubrey W.

description:
Cafe Tiramisu is the first restaurant on Belden Place just off of Bush.  Like many of the restaurants on Belden Place, it suffers from having a greeter (pusher?) who tries to get you to go in.  Once inside, the staff was very easygoing, and the food ranged from satisfying to exceptional.  

First, about the exceptional, I would go so far as to say that their crab chowder was the best I have ever had (thanks for ordering that, Patty!).   

The tagliatelle was good, although not memorable  -- it was soft and with the mushroom sauce it tasted more like a Swedish stroganoff than an Italian dish.
author: Tim G.

description:
I really like this place, great food, good service (for a busy lunch joint in the middle of all the SF FiDi action). Only reason I will hold back one star is that the outside tables are so packed in that it leaves a little to be desired. While my salmon was super tasty, the chick sitting behind me bumping into me every 15 seconds kinda broke the yummy mode. 

I am all about going to a lunch joint that makes you feel like you are not at work anymore and let's you chill a bit and Cafe Tiramisu definitely fits the bill on that front. 

There dessert menu looks devine so I recommend saving some room. I'll be back Cafe Tiramisu, just leave me a little room at the end, I get a bit claustrophobic.
author: Julie C.

description:
Belden Lane is quite charming especially for a workday lunch.  No one seems to be in a rush to get back to work.  Especially when the weather is nice and you get to sit outside.  I see glasses and glasses of Sangria or wine ordered like it's already Happy Hour. 

However, I would probably choose B44 or Plouf over Cafe Tiramisu.  There is just nothing really special about the food here.  Among the four of us, two of us had Gargeneli with scallop (for the price of $17, you get one single scallop).  I appreciate the "home made" pasta, but the flavor is a bit on the bland side.  Another friend had the porkchop which came in a formidable size.  She thought it was okay.  One friend picked the linguini with clams that she saw on the online website but we didn't realize that the menu changes everyday.  However, the waiter was nice enough to accomodate us and served linguini with clams even though it wasn't on the menu.   For dessert, we shared the profiterolles with vanilla ice cream which was good.  

Service was good and friendly, and price is what you expect for Belden Lane: about $20 an entree.  But overall, it was just alright.  Do we really need another "alright" Italian place in the Financial District?
author: Candice B.

description:
I love the atmosphere in Belden Alley so much, why oh why can't their restaurants measure up to the excitement my taste buds expect when I walk down the narrow passageway being accosted by the hosts with menus??

Like B44 and Taverna, Tiramisu was "eh". Cramped, nothing really to write home about. I had just started my vegetarianism when I came here and was excited to learn how the other side of the food chain picks items out from the menu. There wasn't ANYTHING vegetarian except for maybe a side garden salad. I decided then and there that I would continue eating fish for now. None of this vegan nonesense just yet.

SO I ordered the sanddabs, not realizing that they were going to be coming out literally swimming in pure butter. SWIMMING! It was like a really unhealthy sand dab soup. And the flavor was nothing to write home about. Sauce was on menu as "wine reduction" ... tasted some wine, but was too overpowered by the pure butter to notice any other flavors. Did I mention it probably had about 3 sticks of butter in 1 single dish? I felt so sick after eating there, I had to go home from work early. Not a bad thing unless you have painful stomach cramps well into the night. Most humans shouldn't consume that much butter and fat in one sitting. Really.

Too much money for a poorly executed menu.
author: Sarah P.

description:
Cafe Tiramisu...I might have over paid...you be the judge...

I first walked along the narrow alley way charmed by the countless Italian choices...I LOVE Italian food..

I was on my lunch break and i felt like spending..i walked over to a table being stared by the hostess.."you need a table"..."why yes i do..just for one please"
She hands me a menu..WOW..pretty pricey but hey i wanted to splurge

I ordered the risotto appetizer with squid ink and scallops..THIS MY FRIEND IS ALONE WORTH THE PRICE..5 stars
(im no food connoisseur though)

My main dish was the risotto meal with a coke (no refills!!!)
The main dish was nothing compared to the appetizer..i could have only wished...

Overall it turned out to be 40 bucks with tip and tax..

To add to my review  i felt I was hated the whole time because i was all alone and everyone around me was there for some business lunch with clients..."hey at least i was dressed in a suit and tie people"

I guess it would have been great if i was there with someone..but as for being by myself..it hurt its own rating...THEY WERE LUCKY WITH THE APPETIZER..I WOULD HAVE GIVEN IT A 1 START IF I DIDNT ORDER IT..
author: Bernardo C.

description:
I had the venison carpaccio and one of the mixed seafood dishes. The carpaccio was good however the seafood dish was another story. The lobster was tender and moist but the fish was definitely overcooked- dry, and tough. Everyone else said they loved their dishes so maybe it was just unlucky.
