Overall, I would return on my next trip to San Francisco. Maybe they will be more consistent next time.
author: Mike S.

description:
Belden Place is just a wonderful place to eat, and I love eating at Cafe Tiramisu.
It's nearby sister restaurant "Brindisi" is about the same, but Brindisi is more Seafood centered and generally isn't as busy.

They have a wonderful roast chicken dish here, and their pasta is wonderful.
author: Oren F.

description:
It's good, but Brindisi di Cucina Mare on Belden Place is better.

Two stars for the food with an extra star for getting to eat outside.
author: Adam Z.

description: Belden Alley near Market St. Great service and food; Had the cioppino with a generous amount of shellfish, salmon and a huge scallop; Also had the homemade arugula pasta with grilled shrimp; since the cook piled the bottarga on top of my pasta, the owner, Guiseppe, came over to mix it with the whole dish. the tiramisu was excellent. The only downside was the noise and the cramped seating. Otherwise a gem.
author: Phil G.

description:
I went here for Valentine's Day and my husband and I got the 4 course Valentine's Day dinner. It was superb! I honestly can't remember everything that I had since it's in Italian and didn't have the chance to steal the menu =). 

The appetizer I got the butternut squash soup and I thought it would be yucky as butternut isn't exactly my favorite but it was really good. Rich and creamy. My husband had the crab cakes that comes with a little crab salad and it was good! I love shell fish. 

I think the theme might be seafood cause for the second course we had crab ravioli, which is amazing, and I had the half lobster with risotto. Have I told you I love shell fish? It's a little bit hard to eat cause they don't have the cracker (is that the right word?) for the claw. I had to pick the meat with the little fork they gave me. Nonetheless, I was in heaven. I think the only words can describe their food are good and amazing. So let me be redundant here. 

The third course, we had the medallion beef steak and sea bass. I don't particularly like this fish but the way they cooked it made this dish exceptionally good. 

The 4th course is the dessert, my favorite. My husband got the fried bananas with caramel and vanilla ice cream. I got the chocolate cake with raspberry sauce? Guess what? Yep, the desserts were good. They are to die for! Especially the chocolate cake. 

The place is really cute and I think if you come here, you should seat outside. Yeah, no matter how cold it is. They have outdoor heater. Actually the four restaurant on Belden does look very european with the location in the alley, the tables are very close to each other, and the christmas lights above. Funny thing, the couple who sat next to us, they're around mid-40's, the husband had an objection that their table was so close to ours and another couple. He insisted to be moved to another bigger table but the waiter told him that table was for 4 people. Begrudgingly he accepted his table. Kudos for the waiter. 

I understand that he might want some privacy as many americans hate being close to each other but come on,  the whole point of the tables are being so close to each other is to create the communal dinner atmosphere like many restaurants in Europe. Plus, it's not like I was gonna continue eavesdropping after I found out they were talking about work. 

The service was excellent and I didn't feel like I was hurried. I will definitely come back. I heard this place has amazing desserts, so maybe next time I should go just for desserts.
author: Perry S.

description:
I really enjoy going to Belden Place.  It's a fun place to go with friends.  So we tried out this restaurant; and I was soooo hungry.  We were promptly seated, but downstairs.  I felt like I was in the maid's quarters.  Well, not really; but we were away from the rest of the restaurant.  I ordered the risotto with a 1/2 lobster.  It had asparagus, and pesto.  It was okay.  For $24, I expected a bit "more." Not necessarily in quantity, but in quality.  There was not much of a "melt in your mouth" factor.  The flavors were not really refined; kind of bland.  

I am disappointed, b/c the other Yelp reviews are really good!  Maybe I just went on an off night.  However, our waiter was sooo nice.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Belden alley always takes me back to Europe....this is one of my fav places to eat at when I'm in San Francisco. To be honest, I was hesitant to eat here as the name sounded so cheesy (cafe tiramisu...really!!)...I was scared I would be eating American Italian which is way too greasy and cheesy. I was really happy with the food and the wine...we sat outside and I felt like I was back in Italy.

My husband had the Lobster broth with asparagus and porcini crusted Cod over Polenta... he loved it!! I had the Ravioli....simply done and melted in my mouth...the server was from Italy, a little stuffy but pleasant. Overall, I loved our dinner and the ambiance....perfect spot for a romantic date!
author: Ariana W.

description:
Came here to dine on NYE even though I was feeling under the weather, the boyfriend still wanted to treat me out to a nice dinner. It didn't turn out to be the case despite his good intentions, however. Dinner for two came out to about $100, a little pricey considering the food was just "ok," nothing memorable, and I found a fruit fly struggling for its life on my piece of bread. Wasn't sure if it was already on the bread or from the olive oil mixture, either way, it didn't help my already miniscule appetite. Service was extremely slow, which is understandable given that it was NYE but we were seated without reservations and no wait soooo..........

The atmosphere of the restaurant was extremely loud and stuffy. I didn't want to sit outside since I was feeling under the weather, but 30 minutes inside the restaurant made me wish I had given the outdoor seating a chance. I had to go downstairs into the basement to catch a breather several times since it was a lot cooler down there. We were seated near the kitchen so it was a bit chaotic with waiters carrying around plates of food, looking unsure of where they were supposed to go. One of them almost ran into me with a plate of food as I was coming up from one of my breathers. 

And then we get to our obnoxious waiter....

After my boyfriend paid the bill and tipped, our waiter, who had barely paid any attention to us throughout the night, came up to us and very rudely asked us how long we have been in the states. The hell????? After we politely told him that we were both born in the states, he just left, leaving not only us sitting, uncomfortably scratching our heads wondering what the hell just happened, but the people dining around us as well who witnessed this entire interaction.
The boyfriend and I spoke English throughout the entire meal, nary an accent when ever we addressed our waiter. We were both born and bred in California and although, I have encountered my share of eye-slanting and bigotry in less urban places, I was completely taken off-guard by a supposed "fine-dining" restaurant in San Francisco. The snide way this man asked the question told me that it wasn't just innocent curiosity, it was just offensive and unprofessional. 

One star for the decent calamari appetizer  (I wish the rest of the meal lived up to the bar set by this dish but alas..) and one star to the kind people dining around us who asked us how we were enjoying our meal way more than our obnoxious waiter ever did. If his aim was to make us feel unwelcome then congratulations, he achieved it. I will not be returning and I'll advise everyone I know to just pay a little bit more for a truly exceptional experience at Farallon.
author: Angie H.

description:
In my opinion, this is the best italian restaurant in san francisco. The pasta is to die for. If you ever see fresh spaghetti as a special, do not hesitate to order it. It is the best spaghetti I have ever had. Ever.
I would have given this place 5 stars if it weren't for the habit of overbooking reservations. Twice, we had to wait close to an hour even though we had reservations. Once can happen to any restaurant but twice shows a pattern of overbooking. But once seated, it easy to forget because the food is fantastic.
author: bill E.

description:
I had avoided this place because I thought it was a tourist trap.

OK, people. Let me fill you in. The Cheesecake Factory is a tourist trap. The Stinking Rose is a tourist trap. The Rainforest Cafe is (was?) a tourist trap.

But although this place is not the best restaurant in the city, it is not a tourist trap.A little on the pricey side (in my opinion), but higher prices do not always translate to tourist trap.

I'm giving it three stars.

Service was attentive, but bordered on accidentally obstrusive. Maybe it was the amount of food we ordered, but it seemed like every two minutes something was being brought to or taken away from our table. 

And sometimes they would just appear out of nowhere,. My mom was almost stabbed with a knife because the waiter didn't announce he was behind her. She also almost knocked over a plate of oysters because she didn't see him coming (okay, maybe it's just my mom).

The family loved their veal and chicken. I opted for the gnocchi with sea urchin. It was pretty good, although way too salty for me. Also, I was expecting nice, fat gnocchi, but got something closer to cavatelli. Oh well.

Wine selection seemed decent. Atmosphere was okay, nothing great.

Overall, just pretty okay. I wouldn't rush back but I wouldn't never go again.
author: David F.

description:
The first time i went to Tiramisu i had to admit that i didn't like the space of this place because the tables and the restaraunt itself was too small but once i tried the food the space didn't matter at all to me. 

Tiramisu is a great place to have dinner with that special someone and enjoy a glass of wine or two, ;-) ...

The sampler sorbet is a must to have at the end of a perfect dinner and the servers are always at your service.

I think i might go back for the 3rd time to celebrate my bday with my hunny =D
author: Earl C.

description:
This is a great place for delicious and comforting food. The atmosphere was perfect for a casual but romantic dinner; my date and I were happy to share a meal here.

I thought their lobster risotto was perfection, as was the beef carpaccio and short ribs. Their namesake wasn't bad either.
author: Sarah M.

description: A date took me here one night during the week, it turned out to be a great little place. Its a quaint little place that offers outdoor seating. Once the weather warms up a bit it will be lovley. The food was wonderful and a good wine selection. We were not rushed to get out and the owner of the place came out to say hello. I will be coming back here!
author: A. A.

description:
Took a coworker to lunch here to discuss their annual review and goals for this next year. Made reservations the same morning on www.opentable.com for 12:15 and was able to get in with no problems. Was seated inside immediately and I ordered the Risotto -Summer Porcini Mushrooms & Asparagus with Sage Garlic Chips Crust $20 and my coworker ordered the Sea Food Mixed Grill - Roasted Shallots Mashed Potatoes & Lemon Caper Sauce $23.

My food came out lukewarm, but tasty. I didn't bother sending it back because it took a little bit of time to come out and I was too busy talking to my coworker.

We shared the Tiramisu and it was very good. I'd probably go back just for dessert, as the risotto was just ok and a tad on the expensive side.
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
I love the "feel" of this place. The menu-hawking-restaurant employees and outdoor dining make the experience oh-so European.

My dinner (lobster ravioli) was delicious, and I didn't hear complaints from my dining companions. 

My only complaint? Our server was very pretentious and a little frustrating.
author: Sherry M.

description: Excellent ambiance (you MUST sit outside).  Decent service.  Most importantly, GREAT food.  We had a reservation but still had to wait an hour for a table outside.  While we were waiting, we chatted with a restaurant regular and he gave us his recommendations.  We tried the black squid ink risotto with scallops...AMAZING!  Beef carpacio was really good.  Fettucine with scallops was good but probably my least favorite of what we ordered.   The boneless sea bream was prepared in such a simple manner but it really delivered on taste.  This is the PERFECT place to go on a nice night in the city.
author: Mary P.

description: We were kicked out of the restaurant (well, kicked may be a bit harsh, it was done politely), after we were already seated inside, as we decided we just wanted dessert and coffee, no entrée. The restaurant was about 60% full.
author: D. O.

description: Don't get a refill on your coke - at $3 a pop, you're better off spending $6 on a glass of wine. This place was average - food was decent, Tiramisu was good, but the ambiance felt awkward. The waiter wasn't very attentive, mostly because the table next to us had the bigger group, who were ordering all three courses and wine. As a result, service was slow and we started zoning out as we waited for our check. This place seems welcoming if you're a regular, but otherwise, I felt like we were treated as a one and done. Probably will not come back and will not recommend.
author: Emily N.

description: Service in this place sucks. The staff is very rude.  These guys ruined my night. Stay away.
author: Ilya P.

description: I could write an entire review just based on superlatives and adjectives for this place.  This is a must visit destination for me whenever I am in the city on business or pleasure travel.  I have referred many friends to this place and they all rave about Cafe Tiramisu.  The food is incredible, and the atmosphere is even better.
author: Kevin L.

description:
The key to enjoying this landmark, is looking for the seasonal asterisks
on the menu for , what's thoughtful and hip ingredient wise!
This will increase your value,with your dining experience!
author: dave g.

description: Who's my server?  Hey, any more wine?  The wine on the wine list vintage was not what was brought to the table.  Pork chop was dry and flavorless.  Other entrees with my group were better.  The basement where the bathroom is located reeks of mold and mildew.  Service was slow and disorganized. I won't go back.  Way too many better places than this, although Belden Ct. is very charming.
author: Mr. Helper L.

description: I love their ahi tuna...and of course...their tiramisu! It's a cute little place on Belden Lane. Nice place to visit. One piece of advice though, don't go there when it's a hot day (yes, it can get hot in San Francisco once in awhile), because besides the fact that there's no a/c, there's only 1 window! My friends and I were dying in there! BUT....good Italian food.
author: Ang L.

description:
I had the most amazing piece of salmon at this restaurant that I have ever had.  It was a fleeting thing, though.  I took my wife back to experience this bliss.  They had salmon and it was very good, but it was not that peak experience.  The menu changes regularly and the specific dish I had was no longer on the menu.  Still, every time I have been to this place, I have not been disappointed.  

I have had lunch here half a dozen times or more with people from work.  I have had dinner a couple of times.  I sat outside, I sat inside upstairs, I sat inside downstairs.  Outside is nice on a warm day when you want to people watch.  I actually prefer inside.  Yes, the inside is a little bit kitschy.  I don't mind.  Yes, it is Belden Alley.  It is often crowded and bit chaotic.  The people trying to lure you into each of the places on the alley can be a bit pushy.  Despite this, I like Belden Alley.

I have had various pasta dishes.  Always good.  One time I ordered clams with linguine.  I don't know what came over me.  I was surprised when it came to the table with the clams in the shells -- no reason I should have been surprised.  Even though I would not order it again, I ate it and thought it was very good.  One of the people from the office is vegetarian and always wants a menu item prepared in some special way.  They happily accommodate.  In fact, sometimes what she orders sounds so good that I tell the server to do the same for me.

This place is not inexpensive and it can be hard to get seated at times.  it is still one of my favorites.
author: Roy C.

description: This place has amazing fresh seafood and pasta!  not dried pasta folks, fresh pasta!   I came here for mussel after a disastrous stinky/rank/spoiled mussel encounter at Plouf next door-  the owner of Tiramisu was amazing, Giuseppe- he greeted us, sat us, recommended wine, and served us amazing pasta carbonara, saffron mussels, and amazing red wine from Montepulciano.  GO TO TIRAMISU,  !! SO MUCH BETTER MUSSELS THAN PLOUF!!
author: Tina C.

description: This place is GOOD!  Funny place to find, in an alleyway of other Italian restaurants.  Charming atmosphere and delicious food.  Very friendly servers, we were very happy!
author: Magic M.

description:
as the menu changes its hard to specify what my favorite is but don't miss the saffron mussels. out of this world good. 

great wine selection and i have yet to have a bad meal here. 

as for atmosphere, Its belden lane! great place to people watch or be watched.
author: Dennis K.

description: Atrocious service. I'm amazed at how this place is even in business. My friend and I arrived here last night around 7 and got a table on the patio which wasn't at all busy. It took about 15 minutes for a waiter to finally come over and throw menus at us. He didn't greet us, make eye contact or say anything just gave us menus and walked away. So as we peruse the menus another waiter walks over and drops off a couple glasses of water and my friend asks if they have any warm bread. He returns with a basket of room temperature dinner rolls and so my friend asks again politely if he could warm them up. This asshole gives her a cold hard stare, takes the dinner rolls and shoves them onto the wait station near our table and walks away. Wtf? So eventually another waiter (a bald older gentleman) comes over and takes our order. No smiles, no specials, no greetings just another hard stare that said "Wtf do you want?" At this point I suggest to my friend about blowing out of this place but she really wants Italian so we order two apps and two entrees. About ten minutes later another waiter comes by and drops off another basket of dinner rolls, room temperature, whatever. It takes almost half an hour for our first appetizer to appear, a caprese salad which was mediocre at best. The fennel mussels came next which were decent, and our entrees when they finally arrived (tortellini & lamb shank) were actually quite tasty. My gripe with this place was really just the horrible service. I had to ask multiple times to get these guys to clear our table, asked three times for the check and every time I kept getting attitude like "what now, why are you bothering us?!" Seriously, this kind of service for $130 meal? Never again, these guys can go f**k themselves.
author: Stephen B.

description:
This place is a tourist trap.  It reminded me of going to the "Little Italy" type area on pretty much any vacation I have even been on, and getting menu's shoved in my face, while overzealous hosts are claiming how fabulous the food is.  I was immediately turned off, and really just wanted to hit the Irish Bank for a veggie burger and a Guinness.  But that's another review.
Anyway, we were seated and our menu's were taken, but they forgot to actually take our order.  I had to bring someone to our table.  Physically.  I grabbed on to one of the Italian waiter's earlobes and dragged his tight little ass over to our table to at least take our drink order.  I did that in my head, really.  I also made him naked and jumping out of a giant piece of cheesecake.  
So, our food came (finally) which sucked.  I will spare you the gory details.  Just these phrases "tasted mushy" and "too much butter" pretty much recap the meal.  Oh, and the heat lamps were too damn hot.  And it was too red.  I felt like I was in hell.  Or at Sbarro's in Serramonte Mall.
author: Starla D.

description: The first time I was there I had an amazing time, good food good wine good atmosphere but the second time It felt too overcrowded and the food was not as good... service was poor, our server wasnt the most friendly and the food was overpriced for the taste. I had better and less expensive. I dont think im going back... even thought i had good and bad experiences i rather check out other places than go back.
author: Cintia G.

description: Wait service was great, food was outstanding!  Two minor complaints: 1) beer was flat.  Waiter graciously swapped it out for a better one, which was still slightly flat but an improvement, you're better off sticking to wine, as that was fantastic.  2) I made a reservation  for the 4 of us to sit outside under a heat lamp as we had a dog and a baby with us, which the heat lamps, like the rest of the restaurants at beldan alley, are closest to the entrances. We were told it is a health code violation to have a dog outside that close to the main entrance by the hostess.  Sorry, but we frequent beldan, and have never been told this and always are seated closest to heat lamps when reservations are made in advance.  The hostess should check her facts or just be honest about not wanting a dog close to the doors, looks bad to be so incorrect on your "facts".  We would give them a second chance as the food was great, but double check your outside seating standards.
author: Joshua M.

description:
Food good.  Service not good.
7pm reservation, didn't get food until 9pm.

Waiter came out with two  wrong orders for our table of 5 and when we looked confused at why he was serving this dish to us, he realized he got the wrong order.  He never admitted the mistake but blamed it on a lot of people coming in all at once at the time we ordered.

Regardless of how inundated a waiter is, we would have appreciated him admitting he got the order wrong for our table.  And being served two hours after our reservation warrants an offer for a free dessert, perhaps?  

Just because it is a popular restaurant, doesn't mean good old fashioned speedy, attentive and polite service should be disregarded.
author: A C.

description: The location is really great.  I call it Euro-Alley.  I love the food at Cafe Tiramisu.  The owner is a great fellow, and he always offers us kind smile when we walk through the door.  The service is really good.  The food?  Well, it's inconsistent, but well-intentioned.  There's a lot on the menu that reminds me of comfort food.  It's a good place to try if you're stuck downtown and don't want to eat at the Cheesecake Factory (yuk.)
author: Kristina R.

description: Busy and a bit loud, but in a great Italian bear hug kinda way. The scallops with linguine in squid-ink sauce was off the hook, as was the hospitality. The desserts are good, too. It's a great place to hang with friends on a nice evening. The owner has a fondness for old Italian motorcycles, so you get extra points for riding your Guzzi, Ducati, Morini, etc..
author: Andy R.

description: Unlike most of its neighbors, the accent in this Belden Place dining spot is mostly Italian. Highly recommended is the lamb pappardelle, which could have been prepared in my grandmother's kitchen. If you're ordering dessert, the excellent tiramisu is mandatory.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I really really wanted to give this place a high rating, but the lonnnnnnnnnnng ass wait just killed it for everyone. We arrived around 8pm and were told there would be a 10 mins wait. That 10 min wait turned out to be an hour wait! We finally got a seat inside. The place looks authentic, clean and welcoming. Our waiter has a cool italian accent and was super nice. I was drooling over the ravioli only to find out that they ran out. So I ordered the pork chop. The waiter came back and told me they just ran out of that too. I was like damn wtf! So I ended up getting the veal osuboco or something. We ordered a nice shirah and the table next to us donated their leftover wine that they couldn't finish. Turned out to be some $150 worth of chardonnay. Score! Anyways we devoured the bread, and the zucchini appetizer was yum. When the food finally arrived about 30 mins after we ordered, it tasted like heaven. The veal was so tender, it fell off the bone. Excellent! Bf ordered the dover sole with calms, that was ok. Actually I ordered the sole but when I realized it came with calms he took it off my hands since clams give me hives. I saved him some of my veal since he had to eat my original dish. And yes we couldn't resist saying no the to tiramisu which was very very tasty! Not too heavy or rich. Overall the meal was very very good...however the wait just killed it big time....
author: Kim l.

description:
I was here on July 3, 2010.  The food was okay, but service was terrible.   I believe the owner or manager waited on our table and he wasn't very nice.  There were only two other people inside the restaurant at the time were were there and he was so nice and friendly to those people and even offered complementary limoncello, but very short with us.  The experience was so bad that we chose not to have dessert here.  We went to Gitane and had the best experience even though we were only ordering dessert.

There are plenty of other restaurants in the alley, none of which could possibly have less courteous staff.  I would not return to this restaurant and would never recommend them to anyone.
author: Katy B.

description: The dessert sampler is simply amazing!!!!!!  Go there on an empty stomach and enjoy.  I'm not a fan of Italian food, but the ravioli with truffle oil is very yummy.
author: Ramoners D.

description: A quite hidden, authentic Italian restaurant with good food, home made pasta, and a great atmosphere. And the best thing is that they are open late, so we could go there after our Alcatraz night tour! The staff was a little tired, but we did not even order until 10.15 pm, so that can be forgiven easily. Ahhh - the beauty of European style late dining ...
author: Phil J.

description: The wine list is not bad, the staff is so so.  I had veal and it was very good.  Second only to the veal I had in Italy.  I think the atmosphere is worth the trip alone.  Be prepared to have nice espresso and a lovely dessert to finished, save room.  A nice place for a first date.
author: Jess S.

description:
I had an encounter with the owner (or may be manager) of this place and highly disrecommend it. We were customers of the neighboring Café Bastille at around 4-5 pm. The owner of café Tiramisu had terrorized us because of our baby stroller - they just started to setup their tables and there was not a single customer in the café tiramisu. He did not care at all that we were customers in the neighboring café, who already ordered and we had the small baby with us. He just wanted to push one of his 20+ tables within 5 centimeters to ours. We moved our stroller several times and told him that we are leaving soon, but he was really committed to making our life miserable.
One of the phrases that he told us when we asked him to wait for a few minutes until we leave was that " we have no respect for people who are working".
author: Natasha S.

description:
I have a funny story how I came to know Cafe Tiramisu. Read on.

My grandfather hails from Scalea, Italy. A tiny port town on the coast in Southern Italy. One day he was driving through Oakland and spots a license plate that says "SCALEA". At a stoplight he jumps out of the car and knocks on the window of a very frightened lady. She cracks her window as il mio nonno asks "Does your license plate have anything to do with the town in Italy?"

Lucky for us, it did. She was the wife of the owner of Cafe Tiramisu who also is from Scalea. Now knowing that, my family celebrates every and any occasion we can here.

The food is great, the desserts are made in house and cannot be overlooked (I am not even a dessert person at all).

I deducted one star because I was hoping the waiters would know more Italian so I could use it.

But how can you pass up this little piece of Italia that is Belan Place?
author: LJ S.

description: Thank goodness for corporate boondoggles!  We had the new big boss in town to meet us and picked this spot for lunch.  I was worried upon reading some of the comments here, but on a whole, it was a great meal.  At first, I was put off by the rather brusk hostess seating us who didn't seem that friendly.  But everything after was great.  Excellent bread.  My knife fell on the ground (table was a bit sloped sitting outside) and the head guy noticed and in a second yelled out for a waiter to bring me another.  I got the Lobster Cioppino ($19) and it was jam-packed with all sorts of sea creatures in addition to a nice amount of lobster and the sauce was delectable.  I had never had this dish before and liked it tremendously.  We all got the dessert sampler even though we were full.  It was an enormous amt of small tastes of about 8 or 9 desserts and they were mostly all excellent.  Not a cheap place, but I think my entree and the dessert ($8 per person) were priced fairly for the quantity and quality.
author: Marc S.

description:
For a Thursday work lunch this is as close as you can get to the cobblestone alleys of Rome. The advantage of a late lunch was not bumping elbows with the neighboring table. Good service although they weren't that busy at all.

The crab caesar was dressed very very lightly, so the crab wasn't overpowered, as if often the case with shrimp and crab caesars. Good fresh shaved parmesan. The lettuce didn't taste picked-that-day fresh, but a decent salad nevertheless.

I didn't try the pork medallions, but they're wrapped in bacon and served with glazed apples over impossibly smooth mashed potatoes. A large portion for serious eaters.

The chocolate cheesecake was light and mouselike, surrounded by hazelnuts and peppered with unexpected raisons. Dollops of raspberry reserve and rich shaved chocolate made this chocolate-lovers dessert pure heaven. We were way too full for the dessert sampler everyone raves about; I'll have to go back.

Dryish bread means only four stars though. About $35/ea for lunch.
author: Debbie K.

description:
So I had some last minute guest come to town and I had no time to get a reservation. It was a pretty nice night out, so we headed over to Belden Lane. The street was pretty crowded, but Cafe Tiramisu had some open tables out front. We asked the hostess if there was a table for four available and she said yes. But then she headed indoors and told us to follow. First she tried to put us in the basement, but I said that would not do. Then they moved us to the corner, right next  to the kitchen.
The waiter was nice enough, but service was very slow. I could not believe how hot it was inside the dinning room. My guest and I literally were sweating just sitting there! I think if we had not been so hungry, we would have left, but we decided to wait it out.
The food was good, but not great. The big hit was the lamb chops, unfortunately I had the dry chicken cooked under a brick. Really needed some sauce, as it just tasted completely dried out. To top things off, while we were eating, my friend noticed a little critter run behind me.  As I turned to see what he was looking at, I notice three of them. That was pretty much the breaking point. We got our check and made a line straight for the door. As we left, I tried to discreetly tell the hostess and she looked at me like I was crazy. Needless to say, I won't be coming back!
author: Lisa A.

description: I fell in love with this place the first time I laid eyes on it. The open air seating and tiny lights strung over the top reminded me of Paris. This was the first place I ever tasted gnocci, and I absolutely loved it! The waiter was attentive and friendly. However, the tables are smushed one next to the other, making you feel like you're sitting at your neighbors table. Cozy, if you like cozying up to strangers.
author: Jennifer L.

description: We had been to Cafe Tiramisu for a family celebration a few years ago and had a nice experience.  There is a private room in the restaurant which was perfect for our large and rather boisterous Italian family. Since many of us would be back in the area for a college graduation in June, we decided to, once again, have it at Cafe Tiramisu.  I had no trouble reserving the room several months ago, but when I tried to discuss the details, I was directed to call the events manager.   Even after repeated calls, I never got a call back.  I ended up talking with the owner when I called the restaurant and discussed all the details with him.  He was very accommodating and agreed to all our requests.  When the day came, we all converged on the restaurant with the usual mayhem of our extended family.  But I quickly realized that not one of my requested accommodations had been made.  It was if we had just walked in off the street.  We were terribly overcharged, which we didn't realize at the time. The food was good and the service was ok, but I will not go back.  And if you have a large party, count your wine bottles (which is hard with a big group).  It's too bad- it could have been a nice family tradition.
author: J M.

description:
the beef ribs with horseradish mash and asparagus was very good.  the meat was very tender, and you don't need to use a knife if you want, but that's kind of barbaric at a nice restaurant.

the dipping sauce for the bread is pretty good.  the bread is just run of the mill.  the sampler plate was worth getting for a group, but the canolis left something to be desired.  have never been, but will definitely come back.  the seafood mix plate definitely left something to be desired, i would probably stay away from that, its pretty meager portions.  just get the damn ribs already.  also, some ppl in our party said the ravioli was very good.
author: Jason J.

description:
So I thought yesterday was my first time at Cafe Tiramisu but when I got there, I realized I had been there once before. Anyway, I can't remember last time, so here's my review of yesterday's lunch.

First of all, I love the atmospere of Belden lane... so the location is great. We started with the appetizer crab cake... and yes, cake is singular. There is only one but it was pretty good. I had the Linguini with clams which was excellent. My buddy Sam had the Rigatoni which he loved. Bread... appetizer... entrees... are we done? Nope. Gotta have dessert, hello?! So of course, we just can't try the Tiramisu... we get the Dessert Sampler for two. It was the highlight of the lunch... we got to taste the Tiramisu, Creme Brulee, Rasberry Gelato, Canoli, Cream puff, Biscotti, and a chocolate cake of some sort. Fabulous dessert! Overall, a fantastic lunch.
author: Michelle R.

description:
I would give this place zero stars if I could.  I brought a copule of friends from out of town here the other night since they hadn't yet been to Belden Place. What a complete letdown. We were all seriously disappointed.  The meal started with my *trying* to order a reasonably priced - think under $40 - bottle of Sangiovese.  The waiter rudely countered they were out of it and suggested a $70 bottle of Chianti. When I politely said that we weren't interested in a Chianti, he walked away and someone else came up to talk to us about the wine. They were out of our first two choices and we finally settled on a reasonbly priced bottle of Syrah (in the $35-40 price range), which our waiter commented "wasn't very good" when he realized what we ordered. Ok, um, then why do you have it on your menu if it's "not very good"??! Does this mean that the only wines that are "good" are the ones that are over fifty bucks!? Anyway, moving on. The wine turned out to be decent, and then it was time to order. They had only one veggie option (ravioli), which I wasn't really in the mood for. Since they had several other pasta options, I asked if the meat could be left out of one of them (since they had other veggies in the ingredients). He (again, in a very rude tone of voice) informed me that, no, the kitchen could NOT leave the meat out because it was put together in advance! Huh!!?? Pre-made meals!? Really!? Were we at Applebees?! Then, he pointed to ONE dish they could leave meat out of: a pasta with tomato sauce. I asked if, since they were leaving the meat out, they could throw some mushrooms (or any veggies) on in its place, and he said yes. Well, surprise, surprise, the dish comes out with only pasta and tomato sauce (and the small amount of goat cheese that came on top). When I asked about the veggies, he replied that they didn't have any. HUH??? The kitchen doesn't have a single vegetable!!?? REALLY??! Well, by then, I was so annoyed by his rudeness and the absurdity of it all (I do NOT intend to pay in the neighborhood of $20 for some boiled pasta with a little bit of sub-par tomato sauce slapped on top), that I told him I was sure the kitchen could find SOME veggies somewhere. He abruptly snatched my plate, took it to the kitchen and brought it back a few minutes later with some asparagus thrown in. And, surprise, surprise, the only other ingredient (besides the pasta and tomato sauce) - the goat cheese- had disappeared! I asked him if they could put this back on there and he replied: "You want MORE cheese!?" As if I was asking too much because I wanted the cheese that was SUPPOSE to come on the dish AND a few pieces of vegetables in the place of the meat that was left off!!!!! 

After it was all said and done, the food was maybe a 2.5 or 3, but the service renders it a zero! My friends' meals were equally average, and they were so astounded at the terrible service that they asked me if service is "usually like this in SF". Thanks, Tiramisu, you ruined the night out with my out of town friends and made me look like an idiot for taking them to this place that they commented "must be for tourists since they certainly don't seem to care about repeat business". This is one of the worst dining experiences I've had in years. I will NOT, I repeat NOT be back.
author: SL N.

description: Cute little place in the middle of Belden Place in the Financial District. Good eats and great ambiance.  They have really great oysters and the raviolis is to die for!  So glad that I got a chance to check this place out.  Funny thing is, as you walk through Belden Place during lunch, there are hostesses and waiters waiting outside trying to get you to come to their restaurant and eat.  It's like being in France all over again not speaking a lick of their language and trying to nicely say no as you walk through to get to where you need to be.  Love the area though.
author: Jin B.

description: If you're looking for friendly service and decent Italian food, this is the place to go to. The crab ravioli is very good and comes with a nice bisque sauce. The wine selection is about 30 pages long and overwhelming to choose from. Overall, an excellent experience albeit a little too pricey.
author: Abhi S.

description:
Lovely place that was recommended by my friend's hotel frontdesk. Atmosphere was great, was a little bit cold for outdoor dining, but would not mind going back when it warms up. Indoors was a little bit cramped in space, and might get loud with large parties. Waitstaff was very attentive, informative and nice. They all seemed to speak italian among themselves which added some authenticity to this place.

I got the Ravioli, and it was delicious! Unlike many italian + faux-italian restraunts, the dishes weren't overwhelming you with spices, chees,e and creme. Portion was average, but with the unlimited bread + olive oil, I was full.  Only thing holding me back from going again is the price.
author: Pope A.

description:
Great place to share a long table with other people and enjoy the outdoor seating while people watching. I like the festive lights the line the alley at night and how you can pretty much smell and check out other people's plates from the restaurant next door from where you're seating. 
My roommates and I had dinner here on a Friday night for my birthday.  I'm glad that it's only a few blocks from the Montgomery Bart station. We had some really good stuffed calamari and squids for appetizer and it's probably the cheapest item in the menu (~$12). The price range is about $12 to $32.  Anna liked the Cioppino ($18 - stew of local rockfish, Tomales Bay Manila clams & mussels, Dungeness crab in Lobster broth) - lots of seafood in a light broth. Annie thought that her sole dover ($24) is kind of bland and it has no pasta in it. I tried the Crocchette ($25, I'm not sure if I spell this right) and I love it! Just enough seafood (clams, Dungeness crab, and shrimp) and thickness of the red sauce and it has some pasta! Very filling and yummy. We tried the house wine and had some Merlot and they're ok. We split a $20 for two dessert sampler (Tiramisu, Warm  chocolate cake, Biscotti, Cannoli, Creme Brulee, Ice cream in a home made sugar cone bowl, Lemon Meringue Tart, Yogurt Panna Cotta, and Profiteroles). The only ones that I really like are the creme brulee and the yogurt panna cotta. Overall, the food is okay but pricey but the ambiance is awesome! The wallpaper inside the restaurant is reminiscent of Pompeii. They haev a very nice, intimate setting and bar inside and I'm just glad that they have a restroom, unlike the other restaurant next door.
author: Joselita T.

description: Love having dinner on Belden lane, feels like I'm in Europe, strolling down the lane as the hosts are coaxing you into their establishment. Cafe Tiramisu has a cosy, romantic feel to it. Bring a first date there guys, if it doesn't work out you haven't broke the bank...:-)
author: Laurie K.

description: My boss bought me lunch there for my birthday.  We have a very pleasure meal there - pan seared ahi tuna with lemon sauce over spicy shrimp risotto is really delicious.  My boss got steamed black mussels with choice of three sauces.  Since I was too full, I did not order any tiramisu.  The service was okay - the receptionist could be more hospitalized but she was not but the waiter was very nice.  I have a very good lunch for my day.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
First time at Belden Place Alley - loved it. So cute and very European (Spanish, Madrid, Plaza de Santa Ana) feel. We waited to get outdoor seating which was worth it considering the beautiful weather.

The pre-meal bread was good, the olive oil with basil/pesto was yummy but could have had more garlic.

As for the meal, the risotto was tasty but the shrimp was too dry. We also had the Capellini (with proschetto wrapped scallop) and it was good...however, when they say scallop they mean scallop, as in one, singular, not plural ;-)

Anyways, minus 1 star for the slightly drunken waiter that was rushing us...and minus the other star for not entirely superb food.

I will definitely be checking out some more restaurants on this cute little alley because the ambiente is great :)
author: Evelyn B.

description: We went here with some native Californians.  If you have never been to Belden Place you should go there the next time you are in San Fran. Service was very accomadating.  I ordered a pasta dish that was not on the menu.  No problem.  The food was great.  The people watching was also a treat.
author: Tim K.

description: I love the vibes of Belden Lane, very European feel and in good weather the alley is temperate and windproof (a definite plus). As for the restaurant the service was decent, if a little clumsy (cork pieces in my wine glass and empty desert menu). That said I personally like the smaller portions since I'm a small eater (tapas is my thing) and I enjoyed the lobster ravioli. I agree with other reviewers that desert is a must. Also pretty pricey for lunch.
author: Jane K.

description: I liked my rabbit with foie gras and black truffle polenta entree.  Menu rotates.  This is one of the better restaurants on Belden.
author: Rob C.

description:
I must be blind! I have been on this strip many times and I always seem to find two places but when I was celebrating Bastille Day I came across this place. I walked in the door and didn't even realize it was a place since the register was right there. Don't let that throw you off. The food is delicious. I think we may have had the owner waiting on us as well. Always love it when the owners get there hands dirty.  

Even though the place was packed, they were able to find us a table for two near the front of the restaurant. They give you bread with oil that has pesto in it. Finally a place that realizes that dipping bread in just oil is boring and bland. We ordered the beef carpaccio, the dungeness crab, the pesto mussel and as the entree the pesto risotto. 

My husband and I shared all the plates and we were not disappointed on anything. We even ordered dessert ..the warm chocolate cake with hazelnut ice cream. Yummy...i can't wait to go back.
author: Kalifornia S.

description: 2.5 stars.  In a city full of delectable, extraordinary restaurants, Cafe Tiramisu is swallowed by its own mediocrity.  Even if it were less expensive, there are still many much better places that rival it.  We went last night for Bastille Day, and although the food was good, it wasn't anything special.  The service was kind of frantic and scattered... we asked for water for the table 6 times before we got ONE glass.  Its saving graces: a solid Italian wine list and the mozzarella heirloom tomato salad.  Mmmm.  Good mozarella.
author: Serena Y.

description: Of course Belden Place is always cute. Tiramisu had pretty good mussels. Portions were a little on the small side, but other than that, I enjoyed it.
author: Beth W.

description: I took a client here for lunch and was impressed. The food was fabulous. The atmopshere is a little cramped though.
author: Amber B.

description: I really like the atmosphere of the Belden Alley.  What I don't like is the mediocre service.  The menu is enticing, but better written than delivered.  My better half ordered their gnochi dish, and I the seabass.  The food was not bad.... but not great either.  It was an entirely forgetable meal.  The tiramisu, however, is outstanding and fresh.  This place won't be hurt by my review, as its always busy, but I have to say, steer to one of the other alley establishments, for the price, I expect more.
author: Matthew F.

description:
I forget how I stumbled on this place years ago with my then boss, but I have been going to Tiramisu for years, with friends, clients, boyfriend, etc.  And it never fails to please.  

You would think by looking at this place tucked admist a number of other restaurants in the alley that this is a tourist trap.  

However they serve excellent authentic Italian food with homemade pastas, great pastas, etc.  The staff is pleasant and they all speak Italian! 

If I had to pick at anything it would probably be the portion size which is small for the prices.

Don't forget to try the Tiramisu which is very light and yummy!
author: Julie C.

description: Great food and attentive staff I feel like I am in Italy! Their outdoor seating on a warm night is wonderful and also a great place for a long and lingering meal - as Italians will tell you is the only way to eat a meal.
author: Maggie M.

description: We had a group of 20 or so people and were relegated downstairs which was a little dim and claustrophobic with no windows. I ordered the seared scallops on a pea risotto. Bad choice. The three scallops were nicely seared, but the risotto was bad. It was under seasoned and far too tight, easily holding it's trapezoidal shape, rather than "oozy".  However, others in our group really enjoyed the wild mushroom ravioli (which looked more like an appetizer sized serving).  I'm inclined to think it's just what I ordered so I may revisit this restaurant in the future.
author: Jason C.

description: Phenomenal food!  Exceptional service!  We had a party of 13 "foodies" and all of us give this restaurant 4 stars.  Special recognition to Monica and Walter.  If you appreciate authentic and delicious Italian cuisine, you must go to Cafe Tiramisu.  Prices are reasonable - We will be back.
author: Kristine G.

description: I don't know if tonite was randomly a HIT, but i have no complaints about this cute restaurant in Belden Place.  This European-esque alleyway has a lot of adorable restaurants and stuff.  So I picked Italian cuz all my friends were vegetarian.  Our waiter was so nice!  We had a lot of requests and he was trying very hard to make us feel comfortable.  First, we were seated near the door, where there was a draft, so immediately he moved us to another table when we complained.  Then we asked for a bottle of wine which they happened not to have, so he gave us a more expensive one for the same price!  SCORE!  It was really good too.  All of our dishes were delicious... I got the Ahi Tuna w/ Spicy shrimp risotto, and one of my friends got Mushroom risotto.  I think someone else had ravioli.  Anyway, awesome service, awesome food.  I would definitely recommend it, and would go back.
author: Labonee M.

description: This place is located in an alley in the finacial district. Based on the lunch crowd and outdoor seating, the street reminded me of cafes in Europe. I had high expectations for the food. I was a bit surprised to see that the entree lunch selections were limited and basic and that there were no specials. Despite that, my dish of sausage penne was very good. For 3 for lunch with beverages and coffee/tea after lunch, it was about $80.00. This place was good, but there was nothing amazing about it for me to go back if I am not in the financial district.
author: Vanessa B.

description: My new colleagues took me out for a welcome lunch on my first day to work a week ago.  The office is very close to Belden Place so we decided to go to Tiramisu for lunch.  Belden Place reminds me a lot of Paris - very European.  It's great to sit outside on a nice sunny day!  I had a delicious veal dish and a healthy green salad.  The highlight of the welcome lunch was to run into old colleagues and the gossips followed the incidence.  It's all good.  It's a small world, you know?
author: Michelle H.

description: Every now and then I go out on dates, remarkable, huh? well, I always choose Tiramisu due to the warm romantic atmosphere and the laid back staff, I say laid back because they kinda ignore me all the time, I think it's because how I dress! Aanyway, I go late, like at 9:15pm, this way the alley way is thinned out and you can talk amongst your girl to where it doesn't seem like you are yelling at her. I always eat the Crab cake for starters, then I munch on a grilled Salmon dish. When you are done dining, if you choose, you can continue to enjoy the atmosphere with some drinks, or if the date is going bad, you can blame it on the weather and how cold it is to cut it off short, anyway, nice vibe with a romantic chill feel, I really like this place.
author: John A.

description: Wow what a great place!!  I had never seen such a charming little alley as this one! We had the stuffed zucchini flowers lightly fried as well as the seared tuna bruschetta, really great!  The quail is  outstanding and the homemade Limoncello is definitely worth it. Coming from a Northern Italian, this is some darn good Italian food for a really reasonable price!!   We will definitely come back next time the parents come to town.  I just wish we had enough room for dessert!
author: jessica b.

description:
I would give this place ZERO star if there is an option in yelp.
I brought a couple of out-of-town guests here the past Saturday night ; I've been here a couple of time in the past years so I knew much about the "reservation-a-must" routine.
This time, our 8pm reservation didn't really get honored but only watching ppl eating for 45 mins. So pissed!!  
Detail story:  we were there 8pm sharp; and talked with the hostess about our reservation; there she said the first apology for maybe 10-15 mins more wait time.  OK... since we already there... and I've been there with the similar routine... it's fine for the 10-15 mins wait.  Then, after 15 mins, she said the table should be done in 5 mins... Yeah.. I'll wait further... Another 10 mins past...and she kept sitting table-for-two'ers; and kept us waiting there... and finally; we were so frustrated and cold waiting there; watching ppl eating the so-so food... up till 8:45p; I couldn't see anywhere the hostess or the messy, unorganized, unprofessional, customer-care-less management there would get us anything indoor/outdoor or they never care about making the effort too.  SO WE LEFT!    I mean, I've been eating all these years everywhere in the bayarea from all kinds of zagat/michelin/etc etc restaurants... never have such bad experience on a restaurant.  Not just I will not go to Tiramisu again... never will my family nor my friends (which I hightly un-recommended!!!!) nor any of my online facebooker's, twitters, yelpers' friends... This is one of the worst dining experiences I've had in years. I will NOT, I repeat NOT be back.

THIS RESTAURANT IS JUST A SHAME FOR THE RESTAURANT SCENE!
author: jc p.

description: This place is soo good that I'm still thinking about it.  All of their pastas are homemade and that is the key to a yummy plate of pasta.  My friends and I got seated pretty quickly, so I guess that depends on the day that you go.  I ordered the black ink linguini with king crab leg.  I can't begin to tell you how good this taste.  Everyone got a little weird out because of the word "black ink" but it was so tasty.  I could eat that every night.  I did order the oyster and I wasn't that please with it.  I was a little fishy taste and I usually means that it is not very fresh.  Fresh seafood has no fishy taste.  My other friend order a chicken dish and she said it was really moist and tender.  I think every one enjoyed their food because there wasn't a whole lot of talking after the food arrived.  And when I looked up, everyone dish was empty.  Can't wait to go back to SF for their HOMEMADE black ink linguini.
author: Liting F.

description: I have been to this place a couple times, and I always have fun there. The atmosphere is great, it feels like a little alley way in Europe. There is lots of good people watching, and the foods pretty good too. Lots of cute Italians here!
author: Mary B.

description: The TIRAMISU is delicious! But hey, the name kind of hints it already...The food is good, but nothing special and a bit over priced for what it is. The portions are getting smaller and smaller! It also seems that the owner has his "favorites" .
author: Bogee B.

description: The BEST meal I've had in San Francisco!  My friend and I were eating a Christmas/birthday dinner here last year.  Ever since, the meal has gone down in our life's story, the BEST MEAL EVER!  The wild boar was amazing and the taste/sensation lingered with me for days.  The truffle venison was wonderful.  And the final cappuccino was lovely.  My only complaint isn't really a complaint, just a mistake of my own...I should have stuck with my gut feeling and ordered the Pinot Noir, not the Sangiovese.  The deeper, richer flavor of the Pinot would have complimented the sweeter, richer flavor of the boar, rather than the complex fruity/oakiness of the Sangiovese.  My bad, not yours.  Anyway I look at it, the night was to be remembered...food and all.  Bravo!
author: Scott N.

description:
We really wanted to go to Taverna (owned by the same people as Tiramisu), but it was closed. We called ahead to Taverna - recording said you can make reservations on their website. So we did, only to arrive and find the place dark, empty and locked. 

So we went to Cafe Tiramisu, two doors down. Pro: We were seated right away - party of 4 on a Saturday night at 8:30pm. Con: SERVICE. Our waitress was awful. She had to be new and or slammed with other tables. We ordered 3 different bottles of white wine before we got one they had in stock (of course they were out of any bottle less than $50). Food was decent but overpriced. 

The other couple we were with know the owner "Pino". He came by and offered us free champagne or port at the end of our meal which was nice. The champagne was warm though. He told us they had closed Taverna because they didn't have any reservations for the night... (even though we had one). 

I've had much better Italian in the city, so I don't think I'll be back. The dessert was the best part of the meal, some sort of chocolate soufle with ice cream.
author: Amanda L.

description: The food was pretty good, the wine was great, and the tiramisu was awesome.  The crispy salmon was served in an asparagus cream sauce that complimented the fish well.  The sea bass with polenta and clams was not quite as good as the salmon, but the clams stood out.  Unfortunately, we didn't get to try the muscles so I can't comfortably compare the food here to Plouf's offerings.  The wine selection was great and the two wines we tried were a good match with the food.  The tiramisu is overpriced at $10.50, but it is delicious.  The service was okay, but a little too aggressive.
author: Ian G.

description:
ah, eurotrash alley (a/k/a belden).  tiramisu is a nice spot for lunch especially when the weather's nice and you feel like sitting outside and pretending that you're not in san francisco.  it is not the best italian place in the city but it is good.  the scene is lively and loud.  

word to the wise though - it is popular with tourists and the business crowd so check your receipt.  last time i went we had an additional entree on our check.  i discovered this only after paying.  after 10 minutes of waiting for the waiter, he was kind enough to void the first transaction and re-run my credit card for the total minus the entree (which means that he actually still ripped me off by charging tax on the non-existent entree but i didn't have time to wait any longer).
author: Eric L.

description: The Ahi tuna is amazing! Great service, great atmosphere, great food!
author: Ernesto O.

description: It was my girlfriend's birthday and came here to celebrate it with a big group of people. I ordered the mixed baby lettuce salad and the seared ahi tuna. The salad was really good, light and delicious. The seared ahi tuna was fabulous. The tuna is seared just right--cooked on the outside and rare in the inside and when you mixed it with the sauce there is a melt in your mouth kind of feeling. For dessert we ordered the hot chocolate cake and a sampler. The hot chocolate cake is so good second to Roy's.
author: Allison H.

description: Don't quite understand all the hype about this place -- really really mediocre Italian food and even more mediocre service.  The prices look reasonable on the menu, but the quality is completely lacking.  I've eaten at this restaurant at least half a dozen times, everytime trying something new and trying to see what makes so many people like this place.  I just don't see it.
author: J K.

description: I have been to this place a couple of times.  The food is always great and the staff are very courteous and swift with drink refills, etc.  The music is usually a little too loud for my taste for business lunches but for lunch with the crew, it's hard to beat.
author: B G.

description:
Word of advice: in this economy, with restaurants so desperate for business, DON'T be rude to potential customers, especially when there are 20 restaurants just like yours next door.

I've no idea what the food is like because we walked out immediately due to the incredibly rude service. He may have been the owner and he barked at us because two of our party were on their way and we asked to have a table outside. There were TONS of empty tables but still he yelled at us as though we were being unreasonable.

We went to another restaurant in the alley where we had good food, not so good service, but a good time nonetheless.
author: Jaz S.

description: Went here last night with friends from out of town and felt like we were in Europe.  Tucked away in the cutest little alley there are a string of restaurants with adorable outdoor seating that was lovely in the Indian Summer weather last night.  I had the seasonal Pumpkin Tortellini and they were awesome.  Good wine good food, great atmosphere.  Definitely a little hidden treasure
author: Leigh B.

description: I was at dinner with Kavita et al after the Yelp party and I concur with her review. We all split plates and I was starving like marvin.  I wasn't the only one scarfing the bread and pesto olive oil concoction. On a positive note the service was pretty great. 10 of us came in drunk after 10pm and our waiter was very patient with us and dealt with our drunken mayhem.  Bruno was in top notch form winding up the staff and owner. Overall the food was subpar for the price, not bad but meager servings. The dessert was excellent, but it's hard to screw up dessert. Skip it for dinner unless your filthy rich and trying to lose weight.  Dessert and coffee with your new european exchange student girlfriend.
author: Phil M.

description: This is a definate GET THE TIRAMISU place.  The food is pretty good, portions are pretty small but it's in Belden Lane.  There's nothing better than eatting outside on a warm day and having a great glass of wine and good friends.  Total have to try, just to say you idid place.
author: Grace K.

description:
Giuseppe,

You've got it nailed. The gnocchi was superb and my guest quickly ate is Panicchi. It's all good. The hospitality is the icing on the cake.
I'll be back. Thanks
author: Craig M.

description:
at the time, Cafe Tiramisu felt charming and oh-so-authentic (italian speaking waiters, the cobblestone street with al fresca dining, and cuttlefish-ink pasta reminiscent of our recent trip to venice).

but just as i had to take a second glance at our final bill in shock, this second glance at the restaurant uncovered similar takes.

the food is fine - it's made with fresh ingredients and is presented prettily. the menu tries hard to be fancy italian, given the financial district setting, but delivers only mediocre flavor. i really liked the idea of my porcini mushroom and asparagus ravioli, but poor ravioli, it was drenched in a mushroom sauce that buried all of the wonderful could-have-been summer flavors (Giada would be so sad). most of the foods are deceivingly filling though for the small portion size! (bad dollar to portion ratio, but good filling to dollar ratio!) 

our service was fine too - nothing spectacular, but nothing to complain about.  he said buonasera and grazie. 

on a nice summer's evening, it seemed like the ideal fit of a meal. i enjoy hanging in belden place to pretend i'm in europe - if i did come back, it would be perhaps for a drink and dessert, or to visit the next door Plouf ;) otherwise, my search for the go-to italian restaurant continues!
author: Diana L.

description: This is not a place to take a foodie.  If you're looking for atmosphere you cannot beat Belden Place.  You literally feel transported into a parisian scene.  Really stunning.  I found the menu to be lacking in variety, but the company more than made up for it.
author: Krista C.

description: They say it's your cheapest ticket to Italy - for 3 pieces of ravioli for $20 I'd rather save that 20 for my Europe trip saving fund. I'd recommend the place just for their dessert sampler and maybe their grappa! Probably better off heading there with coffee and sweets on the agenda.
author: Kavita S.

description:
What better than a rare beautiful and warm San Francisco evening to venture to the al fresco eateries of Belden Place.  I anticipated a great evening under the hanging lights sipping some chilled white wine.

We had outdoor reservations.  To our dismay we were seated inside and downstairs.  Needless to say I felt a little neglected.  The whole point of coming here was to enjoy an evening outside.  For times sake we took the inside table.

The menu was very Italian.  The black squid ink spaghetti reminded me of my recent trip to Venice.  I had the Sand dabs with a balsamic reduction, which was a bit too acidic.  Good thing I had wine to wash it down!

All could be repented during the dessert course.  Since there were a few of us, we ordered 3 deserts to share.  They were generous in portion (after all they should be at $9.50 a pop).  I was really looking forward to the creamy Panna Cotta, which unfortunately had the texture of mixed yogurt..... Think non fat yoplait with fruit. Their signature dessert, Tiramisu, was good, but nothing to rave about.

On the next beautiful warm night in SF, I would love to venture back to Belden place, but perhaps to a different restaurant.
author: Ashley Q.

description: I've been to Cafe Tiramisu twice, and neither were memorable experiences.  The food is good, but nothing to brag about.  And with prices like these, there are plenty of other finer dining establishments in SF that you really shouldn't have to settle for less.  They do accomodate fairly large groups, so that's a plus.  And if anything, you should try their dessert sampler, which gives you chance to try all of their desserts!
author: Mai S.

description:
I'd never actually been down the Belden alleyway, and probably would have missed it if my uncle, a long-time SF resident, hadn't pointed it out to my folks when we visited the city.
Although touristy, it definitely has its quasi-European charm, with its lunchtime outdoor seating, Italian speaking waiting staff and beautifully presented dishes. This place is supposed to be known for its seafood, and while very fresh... I'm a little disappointed, but they were not very memorable in terms of taste, although they were visually very stunning. We had had a range of items, including the raw oysters, black ink risotto with scallops, buffalo mozzarella and heirloom tomato salad, mixed grilled seafood, linguine a la vongole and finally, seared ahi  over spicy shrimp risotto. Of all of these dishes, the only ones I really enjoyed eating were the oysters and the salad, both of which I could find elsewhere or make at home (not enough scallop with the black ink; grilled fish item from mix was rather dry, and the general mix was good but not special; the linguine also lacked outstanding qualities, with the pasta being a little too dry and too much; the spicy shrimp risotto was like risotto mixed with Sriracha and topped with canned tuna fish since the fish was not so much as seared as it was fully cooked). But, though not impressed with the food, the waitress and management were very accommodating; example, my grandfather was not familiar with any of the menu dishes and has for a long time considered linguine a la vongole his favorite Italian pasta dish. It was not on the menu, but management whipped it up for him anyway.
I've been told that at night the outdoor seating does not exist, and really the charm of Belden is the canopied front shop seating (note, if you come at 12, you may have to wait a while but if you come at 12:30, forget about it. This place is very popular with those working in the Financial District, so clusters of co-workers and small business lunches line up beginning at 12. Try to get there at the very latest, 11:45); so, if I were to come back it would only be for lunch.
In summary...
5 for customer service
5 for atmosphere
4 for presentation
3 for food... and though everything else was outstanding, I really have to emphasize and warn about the pretty but lackluster food that priced at $20/person for lunch! I would not object to coming here again, I did have a lot of fun, but be forewarned... this is about the relaxing, 2 hr dining vacation experience than the actual food itself.
author: Jessica L.

description: I have lived about 3 blocks away for over 5 years, and have never been to Cafe Tiramisu until last weekend - weird!!  But I finally tried it, and it was good.  Not great, but good.  My friend and I shared the green salad and the Bufala(o?) Mozzarella to start, both of which were yummy.   Then I had the rigatoni with sausage, spinach and goat cheese, which I really liked.  She had the cheese ravioli, which looked really good - but I didn't try a bite.  We were too full for dessert - will try next time.  Would love to come back when it's warm so we can sit outside (it was tooooo cold that night I was there, even with the heaters)!  Bottom line, cute place in Belden Lane, with solid food.
author: A B.

description: Just had dinner here recently, and i'd have to say it was pretty nice. Ambience was definitely the kicker, it felt very euro authentic, not to mention all the foreign accents whirring by in the alley it shares with a number of other restaurants.  Have a few glasses of wine, which were appropriately priced.  started w/ an endive & pomegranite salad which was standard.  A daily special of linguine with pumpkin in a mushroom ragout proved quite tasty. Also had a chicken that was fresh. gobble gobble! I'd like to try some of the other restaurants to find best of belden.
author: Michael J L.

description: Been there quite a few times now and always enjoy.  A little pricey for an outdoor cafe and if its a chilly night the heaters don't reach the outermost tables.  The inside is just not the place to sit.  Food is always good and service terrific.  One of our go to restaurants escpecially if you can latch on to one of those groupon or discount promotions.
author: John M.

description: GREAT place for the atomosphere of Belden place.  Try the dessert sampler plate ($7 per person) - You get bit sized portions of 10 desserts.. Mmmmmm.  Watch out though, the hostess has too much attitude to "just seat you for dessert" so if that's your plan, don't tell them!
author: Jared F.

description:
We were supposed to eat here during our last trip to SF, but we didn't have time. Luckily my bf remembered this place during our trip to SF this past weekend.  I wasn't sure what to expect with the mixed reviews, but I'm so glad I ate here because it was one the best meals I had this weekend! 

For starters, we had the black ink risotto with seared scallops and the dungeness crab ceasar salad (recommended by the hostess)...both were really good. I've never seen my bf clear our a plate as fast as he did with the black ink risotto and seared scallops! I'm kinda picky with ceasar salads because they're usually drenched in dressing, but this particular one was perfectly dressed -- pretty much the entire salad was lightly coated with the dreassing and topped with a bed of crab meat and parmesean.  For our main entrees, I had the ahi tuna with spicy crab risotto and my bf had the braised short ribs. The spicy crab risotto was not so spicy, but I didn't care because spicy or not, it was so good! I felt the ahi tuna and the risotto paired together really well. The braised short ribs was done exactly the way we like our short ribs - so tender that you don't really need a knife.  (Hey, I just noticed that we ordered pretty much the same thing as Joe H.'s review below! I guess we have the same good taste in food!) After all that food we didn't quite make it to dessert. I was bummed out because I saw a few items I really wanted to try, but I was seriously way too full and I didn't think I would be able to walk back to our hotel, or anywhere at all! We loved the food so much that we can't wait to go back!

I had to -1 star because our server was kinda weird. He didn't seem so friendly at first, I think even the people at the table next to us felt that way, but he improved over the course of the dinner. The place is super small and crowded, but I guess that's part of the Belden Alley experience. Hopefully you'll get seated next to people you don't mind talking to because the tables are so close that you 're pretty much dining with them.
author: Cat T.

description: I don't normally order chicken but I had to since they ran out of the pork chops (it was only 12:15pm on Wednesday) and they were out. So I opted to a chicken which was a second recommendation from a friend, and surprisingly, it was good! A whole chicken thigh and leg that had a smokey and rosemary fagrant, with sides of greens and potatoes. i devoured almost all of it. Plus, we chose to sit outdoors under the canopy since the weather was extremely nice today, sunny and warm.
author: Oanh N.

description:
my gf and i had dinner here for our valentine date.  sadly to say, we were not impressed by the way we were accepted.  we made online rsvp which clearly stated that a table would be reserved for our occassion.  upon our arrival, an employee insisted we take an outside table.

after that problem was resolved, we were almost ignored of by the waiter except to serve our meal and when i gestured for attention; while everyone around us were regularly being attended to. why should one ask for his glass to be refilled? isn't that something a waiter should do automatically?

finally when my main course came, my rack of lamb was still red when i had requested it to be well done. so it was sent back into the kitchen and it still came back to me a little rare on the inside.  not wanting to make a big deal out of it, my gf and i decided to finish what we can and asked for the check. 

maybe it was because of our appearance. although we are both adult w/ professions, we do look very young for our ages; and possibly ignored because we didn't look like $ to them.

advice to those thinking of dining here, don't go if you look young w/out the dough + its not worth what you're spending.
author: Chamrearn S.

description: bleh. What a shame this cute little alley adorned with lights and Euro-ambience houses such horrible restaurants.  Inattentive waitstaff, mediocre food (no thanks for the luke-warm Stouffer ravioli), warm champagne, lousy tables and trashy hostesses. bleh. At least I was the only one who didn't have to use the bathrooms downstairs which all remarked smelled like  the inside of a compost bin.  bleh
author: Jane I.

description: I really liked this place the first time I came here, when the chef made all sorts of vegetarian versions of dishes for us. This time there were not as many veggie options, but my pasta was actually really good, and either I was really hungry, or the portions were smaller than typical American restaurants, and I happily cleaned my plate. Oh, and don't bother to get 2 desserts -- for the same price you can just get the dessert platter -- which has one of EVERYTHING on their dessert menu! Great value for the money -- and great desserts.
author: Antara B.

description: I love Belden Place. I think all of the restaurants are great--the food, service, but honestly, it's really about the ambiance. I won't go on and on about the lovely little alley that is a little slice of European charm, but I'll just sum up by saying that Cafe Tiramisu is truly lovely.
author: Sophie D.

description: Very AVERAGE!  The portions are extremely small.  If you want to fill up, you should either eat before hand, or order double!  But the flavor is okay.  For the price, it's worth it.  If you do not order appetizers or desserts, it's about $25- $30 a person.
author: Carrie-C N.

description: The food here is great I love the steaks and seafood.  The best part is the dessert.  If you get the desert sampler it's enough for at least 4 people.  Yum I would definately come here for just coffee and desert if it were a little closer to home.
author: H Y.

description: Went there for lunch recently after getting recommendation from coworker. Very cute, solid food, so-so service. The waiter wasn't too polite, but in the scheme of things what concerns me is the food. My veal medallions with lemon caper sauce was spot on. It was a beautiful sunny day so we sat outside and the nice breeze that was coming in made it a very picturesque afternoon.
author: johanna a.

description:
For the cost, you can definitely find better Italian food in SF.

The food was pretty good, but I don't think it was worth the price. 

Also, they don't have any vegetarian selections, so you pretty much have to request plain pasta w/sauce (or whatever veggies they have in other dishes).
author: Sapna M.

description: This place is amazing. The food is fantastic. The staff was great. Perfect atmosphere...Highly recommended.
author: Kristen v.

description: I really loved this restaurant!  My boyfriend and I went there one evening when we were out after work after hearing about the famous Belden Place.  It was between this and the Spanish place and we chose to go the Italian route.  Well, I am so happy we did.  I have to say I have never thought salad was so good, but the organic salad was so delightfully tasty I wished I had a huge one of those.  I ordered the pork chop and my boyfriend the veal scaloppini.  We were both very happy with our meals.  No, it wasn't huge portions, but in this restaurant I was not expecting a giant meal.  I felt very satisfied with the meal and the service.  I thought the dining room was gorgeous.  For desert we had the cream profiteroles with two dipping sauces.   We loved the entire experience and will definitely go back again.  Next time we're going to do the desert sampler!
author: Angela W.

description: This food is vile! Mushy, grainy canned cannellini beans on stale toast, ravioli cooked and plated hours ago reheated in the microwave with some sort of flavorless goo, chocolate cake from a box paired with mismatched sorbet. And all this with a side of snotty waiter who can't seem to make eye contact whom mistakenly thinks he works at a restaurant anybody cares about. I was even eating a meal paid for by my husbands company and I felt ripped off!
author: vivien c.

description:
Interesting location [in an alley somewhere in financial district w/ lotza Christmas lights], great food, pricey! Tourist trap...somewhat, although i thought the food was outstanding.
Ive been here once, and i tried the crab cake, crab chowder, and crab salad...gosh, the crab chowder was awesomely good...the best ive had so far!
Honestly i came here to try the dessert [tiramisu...duhh] since im a dessert freak, but i decided to get the dinner as well and am glad that i did. Speaking of dessert, they had a bunch of tempting menus on the list and my friend and i just couldnt make up our mind...so we decided to get the sampler...it was definitely a smart move on our end!!
- tiramisu: very light, creamy, rich...yummmm...it tastes rather dreamy!
- creme brulee: it had the absolutely perfect amount of burnt taste in the crispy caramel crust...it was that good!
- almond canolli, gelati&sorbetto, and the chocolate panna cotta were just as good.
- warm chocolate cake: was kinda disappointing...it didnt have the gooey chocolate running out of the cakes, which all chocolate lovers dream...which i craved so badly that night...sigh!

All in all, i had a good night eating here and would love to come back more often if only it isn't as expensive as it is....
author: Natalia T.
