description: Well, it's certainly called Cafe Tiramisu for a reason; they have great tiramisu.  Everything else is just okay, especially for the price.
author: Erick Z.

description: I love Belden lane! I have only eaten at one other restaurant and I wasn't impressed so I was drawn to try another. Much better! I had the tuna bruchetta to start, the seafood mix for an entree and we shared the creme brule and chocolate cake for desert. The food was all great, and the service was nice as well. We didn't feel rushed at all and were able to enjoy the nice evening.
author: Lisa K.

description: This is a really good Itailan restaurant. I come here very often with my brother and little nephew. All the staff are incrediby nice and sweet! The have soooo many different wines to choose from too! One of my favorites thing is definetely the Mussels! So good!!!!
author: Martha A.

description: The food was soooo yummy! Also great portions! Went here for dinner. You didn't feel like you were overeating.  Good service too. We sat outside which was covered by a tent and we had a heat lamp right over us.  Very cozy.
author: Liz F.

description: Snuck out of work for lunch with the husband... nice place but a bit pricey. We ate inside because I was freezing outside... sorry this LA girl is still not accustomed to the SF chill even after 3 years.  Good attentive service. I had the cioppino and my husband had the seared ahi over risotto. He said his was good and mine was ok - I like cioppino to have a real spicy bite.  I'd return... I like a visit to Belden Place and this little spot was cute with good service.
author: Sandra P.

description: Came here for dinner we ordered soup, oysters,salad and something that had parma ham in it and lobster ravioli and short ribs then my MAIN COURSE (2) dessert samplers, all to myself...YUMMY!!!
author: anny g.

description:
Went here for dinner. I got there a little early, thinking I could just hang out at the bar while waiting for someone. Turns out there was no bar, but they were willing to seat me. Waiters were nice enough, although some hovered more than I wanted. The tables are pretty close to each other which became more of a noticeable fact, especially as the place got packed around 7pm. This place filled up pretty quickly, esp. for a Monday night.

As for the food, they give you a breadbasket and some pesto/garlic spread which was awesome. The bread wasn't anything special, but I couldn't resist spooning the spread on it. I ordered the quail which is a new entree on their rotating menu. Very juicy and served halved...well-portioned, wrapped in pancetta and served with a grilled polenta side to fill you up, crispy sage and caramelized onions in a balsamic reduction. For dessert, we shared a good-sized creme brulee, served with strawberry slices/glaze and an almond touille cookie on the side. The creme brulee wasn't very smooth that you'd expect - it sort of resembled a runny cottage cheese...it tasted alright though.

Friend had the gnocchi with braised rabbit sauce and seemed happy with it, although he ate it quickly and enjoyed some of my entree. On another note, the cioppino and crab ravioli entrees were popular dishes for many of our neighbors. Cost of dinner for two w/ tip and no alcohol = $70.
author: Reeny L.

description: I was taken here for a first day at work commemoration by my boss a few years ago, and loved the flavors.  The food is rich, creamy and delicious.  We ordered ravioli and lasagna, which were great.  Also had the tiramisu (well, duh :) ) for dessert.  The place is tucked into one of several of the financial district's alleys, and is small and intimate.  It's a bit pricey, gets crowded quickly and is a bit noisy amidst all the hubbub, but a great treat for the taste buds.
author: Megha S.

description: Their desserts are so YUMMY!!!!!!!!!!!! The food was so so.  So the stars are all for the desserts.  I rather eat at Caffe Macaroni Sciue Sciue for great italian food...more authentic italian than the americanized junk out there
author: Alice T.

description:
I haven't eaten here since I started working in downtown in January 2005.

I am glad I went again today (for work).

Meal re-cap:

Appetizers:
Black ink risotto with seared scallops - recommended. Risotto is perfect texture and the scallops are just lightly cooked, very tender.
Monterey Calamari stuffed with crab and served on Italian garlic toast - Not as good as the risotto, but an ok dish. Nothing special here.

Entree:
I had the Black pepper crusted ahi tuna over a spicy shrimp risotto. A vast improvement over the dish I remember having two and a half years ago (slab of grilled salmon or something. It stands out because I remember it being very tender... almost as tender as the scottish salmon that Aqua used to serve). The tuna was only slightly seared and for the most part rare, just as I like it, but the highlight of the dish is the risotto. The texture of the rice and shrimp is perfect. Not really the spicy shrimp as described though.

My friend got the short ribs, which was an absolutely monstrous plate. It would be a good entree if you are starving. Didn't ask him how it tasted as I was too focused on my dish.

Dessert:
My friend's Profiteroles looked amazing, but I had the warm chocolate cake. It came with a hazelnut "soup" and a scoop of chocolate ice cream. The dish is pretty sweet for my tastes, but not too sugary. I did like dipping the chocolate cake into the chocolate hazelnut soup. It reminded me of dunking oreo cookies into chocolate milk for that soggy texture.

Service - Standard. If you've eaten in Belden Alley before, you know what to expect.

-1 star for not being able to seat us outside and putting us all alone in the overflow dungeon downstairs. I had a reservation too! The air was stuffy and smelled of detergent. Regardless, the food was good.

Total cost - $210
- 5 people, no wine, 2 diet cokes, 3 coffees.
author: Joe H.

description:
I have been meaning to complete my San Francisco reviews for some time so let me get it started with my review on Tiramisu. 

I thought this place was great and I like the way it was situated in the middle of the alley.  It was real easy to daydream about being a wise guy and having a family business meeting all while enjoying a tasty rib eye.  The waiter even had a thick Italian accent and it would be a safe bet to think his name is Tony, Furio or Gino, or some other stereotypical name.  I don't usually stereotype people's name but it fit in with my daydream so leave it alone!

It is a bit crowded in the patio area but 'tis nothing to complain about understanding the need to utilize space in SF.  We started with some appetizers and they were all very good.   I had a medium rare rib eye that was a generous portion of meat positioned in the middle of some wine sauce and mashed taters.  I thoroughly enjoyed it and felt like I got a whole week worth of protein in one sitting.  I think I unlocked the secret of Tony Siragusa's gargantuan size.  He's a big, fat-assed football player turned sideline commentator for those of you that neglect watching NFL football.  Everything was quite delicious that evening so we decided to try a dessert that would gently lull us further into food coma.  There were a lot of choices being thrown around so the waiter suggested we try the dessert sampler platter.  I heard of this platter before and my wife's purported feat of eating the whole platter by her self.  I was curious to see this platter of goodies so I was glad we ordered it.  When it came out I could hear moans of excitement.  The platter had everything from tiramisu and chocolate dipped biscotti to sorbetto and connolis.  The dessert platter was a big hit and the platter was more than enough to serve 4 people.  So, this begs the question, did my wife really eat a whole platter by her self?  According to one living eyewitness the answer is "yes".  After this was disclosed she got mad and ate the eyewitness so with no substantial proof and a fear of getting eaten alive the legend lives on.  Just kidding honey.
author: DC R.

description:
check out their menu here: http://www.belden-place.com/view/menu/cafetiramisu/

i guess you could say i love italian food.  one thing's for sure..and that's that i love pasta, bread, garlic and olive oil.  i decided to give this place a try after seeing other yelpers giving it a good review for the most part.  i've got to say, they have a mouth watering tiramisu and i hope it wasn't just for that night.  i mean c'mon! the friggin name of the place is cafe TIRAMISU...how can you go wrong ordering the one thing on the menu that describes the place, right?  anyway, we ordered plenty of dishes but unfortunately this time around i wasn't able to try everyone's food but i will list the ones i did try...

Seared Ahi Tuna with Risotto: i give this one a 4/5 rating.  tastewise it's delicious.  the inside of the tuna is raw  but i eat sushi/sashimi all the time so this is not anything that will make me not want to eat it, but for the weak minded people out there i wouldn't go for this, unless you're weak minded trying to unweak your mind.  the risotto also has an awesome flavor to it.  a bit salty but still none the less very tasty.  an awesome main course dish if i do say so myself.

Veal Scaloppini with Lemon-Caper Sauce, over Florentine Spinach & Parmesan Risotto: i give this one a 3/5 rating.  it was good overall but lacked a little ...i duno... but something was missing.  the veal was soft  and tender, the spinach was flavorful, the risotta was a bit salty, yet still good overall.  i guess there isn't much to say about this one except i guess that it would be a good dish to try but nothing to cry over.  i suppose the risotto from the ahi tuna was superior to the risotto that came with the veal though.

Tiramisu: this one gets a 4/5 rating.  i can't say i've had better tiramisu, but i know there's going to be one out there that i like more than this one.  however, when i do try that better one i know i'll rate this one a 3 and that one a 4.  lol..i guess i'm never satisfied, but this tiramisu is definately a must try.  it comes on a large plate (as does everything else) with 4 thin square walls of dark chocolate on the perimeter of the  cake.  not too sweet, which is rare to find...trust me, and you can taste the liquor inside cake..which is awesome.  i think this is possibly the best tiramisu i've ever put in my mouth...so to speak.

Almond Cannoli with chocolate mouse:  this one gets a 3.5/5.  i've had better cannoli, but this dish gets points for presentation as it is a very attractive one.  the cannoli are about 1 in long each (uber tiny) and you get about 3 i think?  it comes with a sauce and some chocolate mouse which is tasty too.  not over sweetened either which is also good for those trying not to attract diabetes to their bodies.  overall good, but probably won't be ordering it again in the future unless someone treats me to one..  will it be you? i doubt it. hah.

gelati & sorbetto combo:  this is good too if you like ice cream.  i give it a 3.5/5 as well.  i'm not much of an ice cream fanatic but if you were this'd probably be a good one to order being it is home made and all.  i guess i dont have much to say except that i know i will never be ordering this because i could care less about sorbet's or ice cream, but don't take my word for it.  try it out yourself, what've you got to lose?  well...i guess you've got $10.50 to lose, but o well, it'll definately be more of a mystery if you're wanting to try it and don't.

and that's my review of this place.  i'm hella tired so i'm gonna be signing off.  have one more review to do but that can wait.  i suppose ill leave you with this note:

TRY CAFE TIRAMISU AND ORDER AHI TUNA!

until next time....EAT MORE FOOOOOD!
author: Jack N.

description: Had lunch here with some of my co-workers couple times.  The food and service was average.  Just like any other italian restaurant.
author: Pikachu P.

description: Wow this place is great!  I felt as if I had stepped into a cafe in Italy. The place was magnifico! I started with a crab salad followed by my pasta dish, yummy and eneded with a lushes dessert filled with fruit, and a creamy sauce. The service was excellent and the guys treated me like a princess. Hugs boys! You guys are awsome.
author: Eli R.

description:
Based on the setting, I expected a lot more.  Very European alley type setting.

Food and service left a lot to be desired.  The bread was solid and tasted like cardboard.

I ordered the Ahi Tuna Linguine, which was small in portion, and so-so in taste.  The pasta was dry, and the ahi was minimal.  I ended up eating really slowly, so as to slow down my appetite, all the while filling up on the cardboardlike bread.  

The others at our table pretty much had the same complaints.  Even the less hungry ladies complained of the small portions, and they too, were filling up on bread.  

The most appetizing dish amongst our group of four, was the Ahi Tuna Risotto.  

Service was also quite poor.  After our initial orders, we had the hardest of times flagging down a waiter.  Even when we were able to get a waiter's attention, the simple task of bringing us a wine menu was made quite difficult.  

For the money, there are a lot more tasty, satisfying restaurants in the area.  I would definitely not return.
author: Jesha C.

description:
The weather was nice so we decided to walk down to Belden Place for dinner.  We had a short wait even though we made a reso on open table before we left the house, they sat a walk in table before us but no big deal we only waited like 5 minutes anyway.  I didn't like the way they dumped us as the table, I was thinking perhaps I should teach them restaurant skills 101. First the guest sits down then you hand them the menu....DUH  You don't throw the menus down and point at the table!  I knew I was in a tourist destination restaurant by the time I sat down.  And all the tables were at different heights and wobbled all over the place.  But, the wine list cheered me up, very nice selection. We ordered a fairly decent Barbera not bad for only $42.  But I haven't seen wine glasses big thick and cheap like theirs since I was in college.  I'm sure they must serve crystal glasses for their more expensive wines that are 400-500 and up.  Oh and then Maurizzio our waiter yanked my partners menu and mumbled something about spilling olive oil on it.  Thank goodness my partner didn't hear what he said because he would have been pissed! 
The food was pretty good the Mozzarella Salad and the Black Ink Risotto
were pretty tasty!  For our entrees we had the Crispy Chicken cooked under a brick and the Beef Short Ribs, both were really good.
It wasn't a total disappointment although I will never go back, to many other options that I like on Belden Place!
Oh and by the way, take your time ordering because they bring the food out so damn fast your head will spin!  I don't mean to be so negative, and I know this is just an outdoor cafe.  But can't the management change all the damn burned out light bulbs that are strung outside??
Total bill with tip was around: $155 for 2 ppl
author: John M.

description: My friend took a bunch of us here after he won alot of money in Tahoe. This place is great. How could you not like it. I'm a sucker for the clams and the little lights hanging out side. I miss europe
author: Pink G.

description:
this place is so ROMANTiCAL!

my boyfriend and i love coming here for a nice night out (especially great on a beautiful day or night in the city -- who doesn't live eating outside?).  it's found on a darling little alley way along with several other european style restaurants.  

the food here is simply INCREDIBLE, the menu changes according to the season and the food that is freshest at the time.  i have been here many times and don't think that i have ever ordered the same dish and i have never been disappointed in what was presented to me, i never thought "oh man i should have stuck to my favorite ribs!"  in my mind they really can do no wrong with their menu.

if you are look for a great place for a date, a place to celebrate a special occasion, or just somewhere with amazing food you should definitely stop by tiramisu.
author: Preston N.

description: This place is amazing, Great decor, wonderful people and beautiful out door seating.  I stumbled on this place roaming around the downtown area on a beautiful sunny day. I liked the look of this alley and at first i roamed through the different restaurants, and then decided on this one. The were having a dining around special and it was a very good diner choice.  The roasted corn salad was wonderful.  The pesto with olive oil was delicious. I am not a Salmon eater, but for some reason i wanted to try it out.  It was a choice that i did not regret. The salmon was wonderful. After we had our dinner, then came desert.  It was spectacular.    The regular menu pricing seemed a bit high but the food is amazing.
author: steve a.

description: Great atmosphere- great service and excellent food! The appetizers we had was the stuffed zucchini flowers and bruschetta- very, very tasty. Also, the red wine and fresh baked bread with the olive oil was delicious and a great compliment to the meal. We had the New York Steak, Veal Scalopini, Pappardelle and Oso Bucco-- all the dishes were so very yummy! Dessert was just as tasty and satisfying as dinner- we had the sampler platter which included creme brule, raspberry sorbet, tiramisu, etc... We'll definitely be back soon. The bathrooms were very clean. We had a fun time- Giuseppe, the host was very welcoming and entertaining; and, the wait staff was quick and accommodating.
author: MaryAnn H.

description: I had a reservation at Cafe Tiramisu and the guy who greet us was just an ass. He was not accommodating in any way.  We asked to sit outside (they have about 40+ tables outside) and he wanted to stick us in the corner.  It was early, maybe 5:30/6pm.  He didn't have any other customers there, or waiting to be seated.  We ended up eating at Plouf next door where they were more professional.  I wish I had his name to publish, but I will never go back there!
author: M G.

description: Situated in the cozy Beldon Lane, Tiramisu is the perfect date place. The food is delectable and you must order the dessert sampler. Luscious! We had an attentive waiter who made sure our needs were taken care of. It was a splendid experience. Highly enjoyable.
author: Dawn L.

description:
I have been going to Tiramisu for at least seven years, and I have always had an absolutely wonderful experience.  (I will admit that friends of mine know the owners, but they only know them because my friends ate at the restaurant so often.)  I have eaten at Tiramisu with vegetarians (though I doubt there is every anything vegan on the menu) and with ravenous meat eaters.  The menu always pleases.  The food is always exquisite, well paced, and the wine list is immense.  They always offer recommendations to fit our price range, even lowering prices to fit as well.  
I highly recommend the Caesar salad with lobster, any of the raviolis, and do not leave without getting the dessert sampler.  It is huge.  For four people, we often order only the sampler for 2, and cannot finish it.  They also do a cocktail with espresso and sambuca which is amazing.

PS, I just had a small wedding reception dinner at Tiramisu in their basement semi-private area (other guests walk through to use the restroom).  It was wonderful.  They created a pre-fix menu from our favorites and my group had our own private waiter.  Everyone had an excellent time, and I couldn't be happier with the evening.
author: Kay T.

description: What an extraordinary meal at Cafe Tiramisu!  I arrived with my family, a table of seven diners, for a birthday luncheon, and our expectations were far exceeded once again.  From our knowledgeable and friendly waiter Pietro, to the gracious and generous proprietor Pino Spinoso, to the outstanding meal, we had a dining experience that will be remembered for a long time.  Each member of the family ordered a different entree - there were pasta dishes, seared ahi, braised short ribs, chicken - and each dish was more delicious than the next.  We enjoyed the very reasonably priced wine and champagne from an extensive list, and then we topped off our lunch with the dessert sampler, too divine!  Thank you Cafe Tiramisu for yet another exceptional meal on one of the best restaurant streets in San Francisco, Belden Alley.  To fellow Yelpers, you can't miss with this one. Ciao!
author: maria e.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE! I probably wouldn't know about it unless Donna took me. Well, my dream came true last night. Donna and I went to support her friend, Gill's fundraising event at this very restaurant. We had a charming waiter (beautiful eyes, totally Italian) serving our meal. The food was DELICIOUS! You want authentic, European style, this is the place to be! Ladies, tell your man to take you here, the setting is like Van Gogh's painting of "Cafe Terrace at Night." I had Cioppino (seafood stew) and Donna Yee took pictures of this place, so check her out if you want pics. Donna had their Ravioli. The table next to us had an annoying lady. I don't know if she was joking or not, but she blamed me and Donna for having to order dessert for herself because our dessert sampler looked so good. Okay, with all due respect, if you do not wish to order dessert because you're fat, then don't. But don't blame me because you feel guilty for being weak that you had to order dessert. I'm fat too, well for an Asian girl, but I'm not going to pass up great desserts, where I can just burn it off by running the next day. ROFL.
author: Julie T.

description: My partner and I (pictured in our picture together, Byron Hancock) have been going to Cafe Tiramisu since it opened in the early 90's! The food is quite good, the atmosphere always lively and the owner(Pino Spinosa) is a client of mine at my hair salon(Utopia Salon)  Cafe Tiramisu is reasonably priced, an attentive wait staff(most or all are Italian, for a very authentic feel!) and the desserts(especially their signature dessert the Tiramisu) are to die for!! I would highly recommend Cafe Tiramisu for a night of fine Italian dinning!
author: Len H.

description: The meal starts off with some better than average bread with some good tapanade to go with it.  But save some bread if you order Cioppino.  It is a delicious stew with mussels in the shell, juicy shrimp, pieces of fish and scallops.  It has crunchy bread soaking in it as well but when you're done you'll want more to soak up the rest of the sauce.  All very fresh and flavorful.  Service was superb.  A very classy place.  I sat indoors but I agree the pedestrian street is a plus if you like to sit outside.  SF generally is chilly though - especially at night.  A sidenote is that the people eating there were friendly and interesting.
author: Matt K.

description: i wont lie, i was already into 3 glasses of wine when my date and i arrived here... so when our food came it seemed pretty good to me. service was attentive and food seemed decent, plus i like the whole alley thing. if you're in the area and in the mood for italian, this is an ok choice. festive atmosphere brings it up a notch.
author: Michelle I.

description: I really wanted this place to be a unique experience, but it is just okay, nothing special in San Francisco. The food and service were good, but the problem is the tab: it adds up quickly with appetizer and a bottle of wine, and felt overpriced for the value. With so many places in San Francisco to choose from, being average in food and service and above average in price is not so good.
author: John K.

description: i'm not quite sure why this place averages 3 and a half stars - i think the food here is great! i know the service is bad, but it does at least seem like the servers are hurrying around and trying really hard to cover all customer demands. the short ribs here are GREAT, and i recommend any dessert with their hazelnut ice cream on it. this place is located in the popular belden pl alley, so its always crowded on friday and saturday nights. you should definitely make reservations. sitting outside isnt too bad either, because the heat lamps are adequate enough to keep the patio warm.
author: Angie K.

description: Belden Place is like a bad habit that you just can't kick - you keep coming back even though you shouldn't. I keep trying different restaurants on the alley and they consistently disappoint. We recently tried Cafe Tiramisu after being heavily solicited by the hostess. We ordered the salmon and the chicken cooked under a brick - both were underwhelming, flavorless, small portions. The waiter was rude and inattentive. I would give it one star but I still find the alley charming and the people watching interesting. And like that bad habit, I'll probably keep coming back for more on Belden, naively hoping that this time will be different.
author: Cher E.

description: I work down the street from Belden Place and Tiramisu is one of the best restaurants in this little alley.  Everytime I've eaten there, I've been entirely satisfied with the food.  The wild boar pasta was the best pasta I've ever had!  They make all their pasta from scratch.  Usually I don't like crab cakes because they're too bready or mushy but the crab cakes there are at least 90% crab, just the way I like it.  And they have a nice combo of fluffiness and crispiness.  The only problem with this place is that it gets filled with suits during the lunch hour and you get crammed into tables and have to bump elbows with strangers.  It also gets really loud and it's difficult to hold an audible conversation.  And once my friend found a rock (yes, a rock) in her cioppino.  She could have bit into it and broken some teeth.  When she notified the owner, he gave the table free desserts...which actually was one dessert cut into four pieces and put on four plates.  As a professional restauranteur, I think he should have given her a free meal.  My goodness, there was a rock in her dish!
author: Mahogany G.

description: Went here two weeks ago when we had that heavenly warm weather which stretched into the evening. We shared a few different things (oh yes, and the bread with pesto was a lovely way  to begin). Oysters with mignonette and horseradish- not the best,  but fleeting and delicious (one a piece) we had the caesar salad with dungeness crab- lightly dressed, perhaps not lemony enough, with nice lump crabmeat and a perfect amount of parmigiano on top. The real star of the evening was the ravioli-about 7 large ravioli that were the absolute cat's pyjamas-nice homemade pasta, perfectly cooked and filled with porcini mushrooms and ricotta in a butter based sauce with -drumroll- slices of black truffle! So swoony. we shared the ahi tuna with vegetables and risotto but all I could do was think of those pillows of love. Desserrt was tiramisu, of course and it was very good. Oh yeah, youu could eat dirt by the way in Belden Lane, it's so dreamy and Parisian with the lights strung so beautifully across...
author: Isabella R.

description: I came here for dinner on a weeknight. It was quiet around 6:15PM and then as the night progressed it was packed. My friend and I started out with the steamed mussels in a saffron-fennel broth. The mussels were huge and juicy. Then we both had the lobster ravioli in a light tomato cream sauce with a sprinkling of cavier on top. The portion size was decent - I got 6 huge freshly made raviolis. Each bite was delectable. I almost couldn't finish my entre as I had half of a huge pot of steamed mussels. Then for dessert we were debating whether to get the tiramisu and we ended up getting the gelato/sorbet instead. There were 2 kinds of gelato (vanilla bean/hazelnut) and raspberry sorbet contained in a bird's nest (a crunch sweet shell). With every bite you would have part of the crunchy shell with a spoonful of gelato/sorbet. The two elements really complimented each other. By the end of the meal, I was overly full. But it was a great meal and the service was decent. This restaurant would be perfect for a dinner date. Prices on the menu were average for an Italian restaurant in the financial district.
author: Candace F.

description: I think at least half the fun of this place is sitting outside and watching the Belden Place restaurant hosts aggressively push menus into the hands of helpless passersby. It's got a great atmostphere (although the seating below stairs is a little weirdly hot and humid) and good food. Tasty pesto and bread, entrees a bit on the small side, but with a nice balance of flavors (we had the ricotta gnocchi with truffle, as well as the ravioli, which, as everyone says, is small, but delicious!). We had a WONDERFUL dessert: warm pear and hazelnut tart with vanilla ice cream and cinnamon sauce, perfectly paired with Graham's Tawny 20-year-old port. Mmmm! My only complaints: our waiter neglected to bring us our salad (not a big deal to us - we just went straight to dessert and had salad at home), and the busser kept trying to whisk my plate away, when I was clearly trying to sop up every last bit of sauce with my bread. Ha! I wasn't sure if he was trying to instill manners in me or just trying to send us on our way. Other than that, a totally nice place, if a bit pricey for the food.
author: Adrienne S.

description: Delicious and great value.  It was loud but not prohibitvley so - it was good for filling in the awkward gaps in a semi-business lunch, or one that you want to keep professional.  The portions are pretty large and fresh all the way.  Good timing too - was there for just under an hour at noon, was seated right away and served promptly despite elaborate orders.
author: Lauren S.

description: The tomato buffalo salad is the best in San Francisco.  Also sitting outside in the fresh air is a pure delight.  Excellent place for a business lunch.
author: Julia M.

description: This place was recommended to some business associates by the concierge at the Ritz-Carlton, so I didn't really have a say in where we were going for dinner.  If I did have a say I would've avoided this place at all costs.  It just seems like it's positioned to capture the tourists with its location in the alley-like Belden Place with its outdoor tables and strings of lights.  Places like this remind me of the scene in the French restaurant in "National Lampoon's European Vacation" where the chefs are in the kitchen microwaving frozen meals and passing them off to the oblivious Griswolds as haute cuisine.  Unfortunately, my instincts were correct.  My risotto with scallops (plural) was really undercooked risotto with scallop (singular), cut in half to look like two scallops.  It was awful.  The cheese ravioli was only marginally better, but was so over buttered/oiled that I could FEEL my cholesterol going up.  The tiramisu for dessert, their "signature," was soggy - I've made better myself.  The waiter was "faux" Italian, but genuinely bad.  Stay away.
author: Ryan W.

description: I went to cafe tiramisu because me and my friend felt like Home made pasta. As we walked into the alley we found that we should check all the menus and talk to all the hostess who are outside offering the menu. After our search we decided to go for homemade pasta and sea food at this place. Honestly, the only person we found nice,friendly,attentive,and polite in the whole place was their hostess a Columbian chick. She said they made their own pastas and that cafe tiramisu was the right place if looking for great pastas. She offered a nice table inside and proceeded to sit us. It seems like the owner/waiter an older man was not in his mood that day. As we were waiting for almost half and hour for our cocktails, the whole time he was rude and poorly cared about how was our food. Or anything at all..... Just Go somewhere else, eventhough they have a nice sales/person outside they should be consistent and offer a better costumer service since their prices are so high too, and yes, the pastas were good.
author: Kate D.

description: I generally do not express positive experiences but the Chicken Milanese  was a pleasant surprise - fresh, crispy with just the right amount of green topping. My lunch was excellent. The only thing that was unpleasant( and there has to be something) was the detergent odor from the bus persons clothing! Maybe a little less Tide in the wash! Excellent service...
author: Rudy G.

description: i love belden place and cafe tiramisu is a delight.  the food is consistently good though not standout, but the ambience is as close to a little street in florence as you're going to get in sf!
author: Roshni R.

description: nothing about this place really qualifies as stand-out, but i have no specific complaints, either.  the deserts (i sampled three) were quite tasty, but my entree was a little rich and the portions were huge.  the service was unnecessarily slow, but i have definitely gotten used to that when it comes to eating lunch in the fidi.  my recommendation would be to skip this place and head down to b44 for a more exciting belden alley experience.  but if you like standard italian fare, it is probable that this place will sit well with you.
author: calamity d.

description: duck risotto was awesome.. i could eat that for days. the $9 per person dessert sampler was this huge assorted plate with creme brulee, fudge, ice cream, and other random things though i'd stuck with getting just the creme brulee.. i love how i got a table despite it being a rather busy friday night!
author: ally o.

description: Such an adorable location. The staff was very friendly and very accomodating, especially since I was late for the reservation. The food was most delicious! The house salad was not a plain greens with tomatoes, but it was fresh mixed greens sprinkled with pomegranate and grapes, giving it a sweet flavor that blended with the light dressing very well. The crab and lobster ravioli was most delicious! The downside of the dish was that the crab/lobster wasn't cleaned well, so you had to be careful and spit out the shells. However, the flavoring was so tastebud-teasing that the shells became a minor issue. My friend had the sea bass, which was buttery. It was a little fishy for my taste, but nonetheless, it was good. The tiramisu was a must, given the name of the restaurant, and it was made perfectly! A little overpriced, but it was worth it. The dishes were well-presented, although it wasn't anything out of the ordinary. The staff was polite and not over-attentive, which allowed me to enjoy the presence of my company. The ambience was fun, although at times, I could not hear what my friend was saying. This is a great place for good food, if you're not in a rush.
author: Dana S.

description: The food is excellent.  On Friday they had this crab medley plate which, upon thinking about it now, still makes my mouth water.  And I love the outside bistro seating in good weather.  That being said, the service was a bit inhospitable.  I've been here twice and had the same waiter, some older looking gentleman.  Seems like if you dont order a bottle of wine (as oppose to the two glasses we ordered) this dude immediately becomes indifferent.  Then we said we only wanted to order some appetizers, and his mood shifted from indifferent to down right unfriendly.  We sat down before 5pm and there was no other table seated outside, so it's not like we were taking up space from a potential higher paying customer.   I noticed that the waiter treated the three-top who sat next to us later in a similar fashion when they ordered only non-alcoholic drinks and appetizers.  Anywho, the kicker was when the waiter chased down the alley a couple who had just left the restaurant  and accused them of dine-and-ditch.  Turns out their signed credit card receipt was in the billfold next to the dinner bill.  So, not the most friendly service.
author: brewgirl b.

description: I have to admit that when I was here it was with a big group of friends and I just wasn't paying that much attention to anything. I absolutely refuse to admit that alcohol played any part of that ignorance.   So what I recall is that we were all happy, the food was good and no one was at all disappointed.
author: Misti L.

description: A usual lunch meeting spot for our office. My favorite dish is the veal scalliponi. Other dishes are good too.
author: M K.

description: A nice treat for a recruiting or a summer lunch (i.e. something where a higher power is picking up the tab).  They definitely have options for vegetarians - from meal sized salads to a couple of veggie entrees, and the crowded outside space (and equally elbow to elbow inside space) makes for a true Belden-y experience.  The food, though, is pedestrian at best - go for the atmosphere, not the eats.
author: Anjali K.

description: This is based on one visit, so take it for what it is. I lunched there today with two colleagues. I had the Baby Greens salad with goat cheese and carmelized walnuts along with the salmon. The salad, for $8, was ridiculous. There was no more than 1 teaspoon of goat cheese, and likely not that much, on the salad. There was about 3/4 of one walnut included. The salad dressing was too heavy on the oil, and therefore flavorless. The salmon was good. Not great, but it was cooked appropriately, with a nice polenta cake included. My colleage had the mozzarella salad, which looked delicious, with a good amount of mozzarella and some nice arugula. He also had the chicken. It looked large and appealing, if you're into chicken, but it was not only pink inside, there were parts of it that was actually blood red. Uh, excuse me? Overall, I expect more for a $30+ lunch, per person.  Makes me think they don't care too much. They don't have to, of course, as they have the location down. Oh, well. Maybe it was a bad day in the kitchen.
author: Noelle O.

description: Nice spot in the French quarter of SF, it makes a lot of difference if you are seatting outside on a beautiful night or inside. It can be very romantic being outside with the lamp heaters warming you in this trendy alley. As far as food is concerned, decent and commonplace, not worth the price for the food. Wine  is 5 star and I had Tiramisu  which was great. Service is fantastic, may be because it was approaching the closing hour. Overall, I would have given it a 3 for the super-pricy-not-so-exciting-food, but the Euro-alley garners one extra star.
author: Kingshuk g.

description: This restaurant was recommended by the Campton Hotel Concierge. It was by far and away one of the worst restaurants I have ever experienced. I was very disappointed because we paid more than $100 for a dinner for 2. We went on a weekday and they only had once soup to choose from--artichoke soup. I love to try new taste combinations but this soup was as bad as it sounds. I have never eaten any soup as bad as this. It was quite bitter with a horrible aftertaste that no amount of bread, water, soda, or liquor could remedy. Every restaurant has at least one bad item so we were hoping for some solid hits with the entrees. While waiting for our orders, I finished a diet coke and had it refilled only to find out that this restaurant charges $3 for each diet coke including refills!! Maybe I would not have minded so much had the waiter acknowledged this before slamming refills on my table one after another. I had the rack of lamb. This entree was good, they gave you a decent amount of lamb and paired it with a mediocre side dish. My wife had their special, Halibut with beans. You heard me right, beans. As I said before, I love to try new tastes and flavor combinations. I was a little hesistant but went into it with an open mind. Do yourself a favor both at home and when you dine out--never under any circumstance combine fish and beans. I don't know if they ever tasted this dish but the combinations was painful. The fish was so well cooked that it had the consistency of  leather and we had to use my steak knife to cut through it. It also tasted like leather as well, actually, it tasted like paper, because it was very bland and had no taste. The beans were straight from a can of "pork and beans" from your neighborhood grocery store.  I don't know what else to say because I was so sick afterward that I could barely stumble back home. The service was absolutely poor. It was outside dining and our waiter was standing next to us the entire time. It would have been great if he was actually paying attention to our needs. He only had one table to wait on, ours. He spent most of his time monkeying around with the other waitors, putting each other in headlocks, making jokes, and have a good time. This would be acceptable behavior if he was out enjoying himself after ours at a bar, but he was not and obviously was not paying attention to his duties as a waiter. Suffice it to say, I've been served by 4th graders in a high school gym that did a far better job than our waiter and his merry band of pranksters at this restaurant. After the awful meal, we decided to go with the namesake dessert, tiramisu. How can you name your restaraunt Tiramisu and not be absolute masters with this dessert. The tiramisu had the appropriate taste, not too sweet like many others but it was the soggiest stuff I have ever eaten. This is my favorite dessert that I order from almost every single restaraunt that I eat at. This was somewhere above the average but nothing that I would ever name a restaurant after. The presentation was great with sauce strewn back and forth on the plate and a few sliced strawberries along with the tiramisu covered on four sides by black chocolate. It was just truly a crushing experience to sink by teeth into this soggy sponge cake. Although if I had to choose, soggy tiramisu is better than rock hard tiramisu. As I said, the flavoring was accurate, but it felt like they left it in a refrigerator that was turned almost to he off position. This may seem a harsh rating for this restaurant but consider that I spent over $100 for this meal during my stay and also ate at Nieman Marcus and Ana Marana for less than this amount while enjoying possibly some of the best food of my travels, I have to give my humble opinion not to waste your money at this establishment. It may be good when compared to restaurants of its class, but if you are to compare it with restaurants in the SF area, it definitely deserves no more than 2 stars and nary a second look.
author: Tommy L.

description:
Although I've been going to Caf Bastille for over ten years, I never made it into Tiramisu until I went with friends last month.  I had never actually noticed their menu and was a little surprised by the prices, they were up there.  The food was ok, I was really disappointed by my $35 steak, which was drowned in a bland and unsalted sauce that made everything else on the plate soggy.  The steak would have been great on its own, too bad it was swimming in bad sauce.  The service was good until the end of the evening, when something inexcusable happened.  The hostess and manager/owner got into an argument about tips and wages due to the hostess.  The argument followed them around through the dining room for a while.  From a distance it seemed like the American hostess was out of line, I assumed this because I figured the Italian manager/owner knew better than to argue out in the dining room in front of patrons, but when the argument got to our table I overheard the manager/owner backing down and agreeing that she was right about the money she was owed.  The whole scene of the manager/owner trying to cheat the hostess in front of everyone was pretty ugly.

I wouldn't go back, the food doesn't live up to the prices, and although our service was fine, the scene in the dining area was definitely amateur hour.
author: D C.

description: The risotto was delicious, great flavors mixed together.  The artichokes under the sand dabs were more delicious than the fish itself.  The buffalo mozzarella salad was delicious- it comes with red bell peppers marinated in a sweet sauce, arugala, proscuitto.  Except for the vanilla gelato, the desserts were terrible (we ordered the dessert sampler).  Do not order this, unless you want to be disappointed by most of it. The service and waiters were good.  I was happy with the restaurant, aside from dessert.
author: Nisey D.

description: Had thought this was a more upscale type of place. It was really noisy and nothing special. Food was only ok.
author: Jennifer S.

description: i threw my sister a surprise wedding shower here and it turned out really well. made a reservation of 32 people. they set us up on the bottom floor. we felt like we had our own room, without have to pay an extra fee. worked with olivia, the event coordinator, to set up the short menu. everything was great... and the food was very good. plus i planned it all from los angeles...
author: Chris G.

description: Food was good, nice little ambiance, staff was friendly. Owner or manager mingled with many of the guests. Had reservations for New Year's eve and was seated promptly. Prixe fix meal was changed slightly from what was originally on their website, but they charged less for it to compensate. Can get pricey really fast, but overall no complaints.
author: Juan M.

description: Decent, fun place on a temperate night.  If you sit outside, it'll be very noisy and there will be smoking.  So, sit inside, as close to the window as possible, so you'll feel like you're outside without all the irritations.  It's quieter inside too.  Make sure you eat here on an expense account because it's damn expensive for what you get.  Appetizers were the best value.  A heaping mussel plate ($15) with the largest mussels ever.  I thought I would be scared, but they were tasty.  The oyster appetizer was underwhelming and the oysters were small, smaller than the mussels.  Strange.  As for the main entrees: my seabass was so overcooked, it tasted like halibut.  Erg.  The assorted seafood platter was horrifying: the most gigantic crawfish (or is that shrimp?) ever with the head and arms still attached (I don't want a gigantic insect like thing sitting on the very top of my plate like it just killed the other items there), and the remaining items weren't appealing, either.  The scallop risotto was a thimble full of risotto with maybe two scallops on top.  It was damn tiny, and you had to laugh.  And the ahi tuna was nice, kinda like if you can't decide between raw and cooked, so you get both, seared on the outside, raw on the inside.  But not a lot of it on the plate.  Thank goodness the appetizers were so large!  The desert cheese plate was 5 small pieces of cheese, four grapes and one strawberry slice on an enormous plate, reminding me of a modern art gallery.  The saving grace was the tiramisu, the best I've ever had in my life, and I always get tiramisu when it's available.  But that's not enough to eat here.  Just get appetizer and tiramisu, avoid the entrees.  And if they try to seat you in the basement, just walk out.  The only reason to go down there is to use the restroom.  The atmosphere is horrible, horrible down there!
author: A P.
